The food and drinks are great, and the staff members are always friendly and awesome. I especially recommend the pork and green chile taco. So good! So. Good.
author: Hollis M.

description: Had breakfast tacos that were delightful, our server was excellent and the make your own mimosas were a hit.
author: Samantha S.

description: Great restaurant! It is large so wait can be minimal. Food it great drinks are better! There is a section that can be rented out for private events.
author: Justin H.

description:
Surprisingly good. Was disappointed to find out that people I didn't know had selected basically one of the newest, least authentic and most commercial place on Valencia street, but discovered the food and service was good!

I shared some smoked mac and cheese with a friend as well as an order of guac and chips. None of that make it by your table BS, it was amazing, chunky and generous. The smoked mac was amazing, and for my main I had a lobster enchilada which was hot, cheesy and delicious.

As much as I wanted to hate it, it was good.
author: Jordan C.

description: Hair in our food. They didn't charge us for the meal but said that the hair being there was impossible and implied that I must have used my friend's hair to fabricate a claim. Which is stupid because the hair was in the guacamole and had to be from the guac.  DO NOT GO THERE IF YOU WANT HAIR IN THE FOOD AND THEN BLAMED FOR HAVING HAIR IN YOUR FOOD.
author: Egemen Ö.

description:
One of the few places in the Mission I had not been to until last week. Was home all day with the roomie working from home and watching Millionaire Matchmaker so we decided to catch a $5 uber to get some dinner. 

He had just been here a week before but gladly came with me again! I ordered the shot and beer to start with. Waitress was a bit confused when I asked her what the beer and shot was since it literally says on the menu that its rotating and how else would I know what it was but it was their cider and a shot of mescal. I would honestly skip this and the way she answered made it sound like its not really "rotating." I choked down the cider and made my roommate drink the rest of my shot. It was not happening. The bar had lost my order so the waitress gave it to me on the house for the extra wait and I honestly did not even notice the wait. Super nice! Otherwise its $9. Would stick to the sangria. 

I wasn't that hungry but I got the lobster enchiladas and was soooo full after. Stupid brain! Asked if I wanted rice and beans (extra $) but the waitress said the enchiladas are so rich they don't need the sides so I opted out. There is a ton of sauce though so I ate it with the chips. Huge pieces of lobster! 

The chips and salsa might actually be the best part of the meal to be honest. Chips are so bomb! I would only come back for their happy hour otherwise. So many better food and drink options on the block! Oh and my roommate said the restaurant was too dark and I said it was too loud. I loved how dark it was and he didn't even notice it was loud. To each their own!
author: Tiffany V.

description: Fave spot for yummy, low key drinks and food with girl friends. West of Pecos always delivers on delicious food and drinks with a great atmosphere. Hit the bar seating and skip the wait!
author: Katie A.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF! 

Pros:
It's big so getting seated is easy. 
There cocktails are delicious. The bartenders are super sweet and the bar area is great -- I love sitting by the window and people watching. Plus they usually have sports on (yay!).
Ambiance is dark and romantic, but the large space is also great for groups. Somehow it doesn't get super loud.
Staff is super sweet, and the owner walks around and talks to people, which is fun and refreshing.
The food is SO. GOOD. I mean SOOOO good. I've been here so many times and tried so many things and everything I've tried is delicious. The skillet cornbread?! UGH. I'm drooling right now just thinking about it. 
The decor is super cute and the vibe is very friendly.

I can't really think of any cons :)
author: Julia O T.

description:
Came for brunch/lunch. 

Next time: order squash enchilada (dinner only), guacamole with crab, fish tacos optional. 

I like those better than the fried chicken, mushroom taco, and cornbread. 

Limited menu but still a lot of the favorites. 

Pro tip: the same fried chicken on the menu is still available, it just is under the breakfast/eggs section and served with churros (like a play on chicken and waffles), but you can skip the churros and syrup. 

Pro tip #2: they can do carrots instead of chips with the guacamole. 

Pro tip #3: ask for the house made habanero sauce.
author: Mike G.

description: The staff was great, but my fajitas came out burned and it seemed the norm.
author: Carol R.

description: We went here for my friend's birthday, partially because they could take reservations for a large-ish group of 6 people.  We ordered the spicy margarita pitcher, which was pretty good.  The food was just ok though.  We ordered the mac and cheese to start, which was heavy, but not super flavorful.  I got the fish tacos, which was pleasant, and the corn.  Because of food trucks and street food festivals, I have weird cravings for grilled corn.  While this was ok, it definitely doesn't compare to street faire grilled corn that's lathered in parmesan cheese.  My boyfriend got the seafood enchiladas which were unique and filling, but really could've used something to balance it out.  In general, the food was ok, but I probably wouldn't go back unless I was with a group.
author: Jenny C.

description: Great atmosphere and service! The squash blossom taco was very unique and excellent! The croissant french toast was also great! Will definitely visit again!
author: Sharanya P.

description:
The brussels sprouts were REALLY good. I was doubtful ordering something as blecch as brussels sprouts but amazed how they prepared them here. The chili mac and cheese and pork taquitos were also delicious. For the main course, I had the crab enchiladas. Very rich, but a bit overcooked.

Will definitely go back.
author: John R.

description: Probably my most frequented restaurant in the Mission. Love the atmosphere. Delicious food. Good cocktails at the bar. Always great service.
author: Dejana B.

description:
We had brunch on Sunday, the coffee was great, the huevos rancheros were great, the shrimp ceviche was great (the salsa verde was particularly awesome in it) and my girlfriend liked her squash blossom puffy taco quite a bit too. All quite welcome experiences to soothe our longing for Austin Tex-Mex (my gf was born and raise in Austin, I lived there about 10 years off and on). 

HOWEVER - the queso was really really disappointing.  The 4 stars are for everything but the queso, which was definitely a 1 star affair - I'd happily go to my grave never seeing this glop again, let alone eating it. 

Torchy's queso in Austin approaches the Platonic ideal for queso, everyone knows this is true. We asked for the chorizo to be omitted, so in fairness it might be a little better for carnivores, but it was:

1) nowhere near hot enough
2) wrong texture - goopy and sticky even when hot (probably not enough sour cream -- is there even sour cream in it?)
3) bland - it should have salsa in it, or be served with salsa so that diners can adjust to taste
4) the chips are dusted with some kind of chile powder or paprika that is unpleasantly bitter

Seriously, West of Pecos - you have something pretty great going, please please take a quick trip to Austin, eat Torchy's queso every day you are there, come back and do your best to rip them off. If you hack together a passable Torchy's style queso we'd come back again and again to satisfy our regular queso cravings.
author: Sebastian H.

description:
I really, really wanted to like this place.   I live in the mission and have been here several times.  The food is good, the decor is cool, the location is excellent, the drinks aren't bad.  The the attitude of the people who work there is just off.  Even the receptionists feel a bit cold as they say hello.

I'm really not sure how to put my finger on it, but there is a bad service vibe here.  Gotta be something to do with the management they've hired.  My friends and me have all agreed - stay away as it's bad mojo. 

If you have talk with the employees and remind them genuine, sincere friendliness matters, let me know.  We'll all give it another go!
author: Daniel S.

description: I came here on a double date with my friends and my boyfriend and had a really good time. Our waitress was super nice and recommended some good dishes to try out. I really enjoyed their cocktails and especially  their guacamole! I don't remember what I got as my entree, but it was overall a great first time experience with friends. I remember passing by here before and didn't think to see that it was a restaurant before coming here. Glad to find out that it serves delicious foods and a great atmosphere to drink, eat, and hangout with friends. Would definitely come back again if I'm ever in the area.
author: Victoria K.

description:
This was our first post-dinner cocktail stop after finishing our meals at Gracias Madre. The restaurant was packed with people as it was Dia de los Muertos weekend. It was a little cramped in the bar area but we were able to eventually squeeze in our party of 7 at the long bar. 

The cocktail menu primarily focused on tequilas and bourbons. I tried both the classic and prickly pear MARGARITAS. They both tasted fine but not exceptional. I wanted my prickly pear margarita to have a more spicy kick to it since it had 'serrano peppers' in the description. The PIMM'S PUNCH was served in a rustic, metal cup but  the alcohol was rather strong and overwhelming. I enjoyed the sweeter, fruitier taste of the LAYLA cocktail (and so did my guy friends!). Overall the cocktails were simply A-OK for the price and you can probably find better drinks elsewhere in the Mission.

The atmosphere proved to be great for conversation between our large group. Although I think this will be an ideal place for medium-sized group gatherings (5 ppl or less) due to its smaller seating areas. 

From fancier drinks to full screen TV's for football viewing, West of Pecos is a perfect combo of classy and casual in the Mission. I might come back to see if their food impresses me.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Very impressed not only with the food, but also the service. 

We got guacamole and chips, fried chicken and chili relleno. All were good. The cocktails were fantastic too! 

But my five stars are for the service, the amazing, gorgeous lady who waited our table was very sweet, went out of her way to recommend stuff and was sweet as honey. Now, that's the kind of sevoce one would expect. She is Rebecca, the lady who wore glasses. She sure deserves a reward, praise and a raise! Great job Rebecca, Thanks to you we will be back again...
author: Rocking V.

description:
Good place for happy hour after work, decently priced drinks $6 sangria. Good place nice drinks and upscale Mexican food before going out in the mission on weekends. 

We got: fried chicken, mushroom and beef puffy tacos, sangria

Get again: mushroom puffy taco was the best and beef puffy tacos second. Chicken was okay but the sides were yummy! Try the butternut squash enchilada.
author: Kristin C.

description:
I'm almost hesitant to review West of Pecos for brunch because it means the secret will be out about how AWESOME it is. Here's why:

1) No wait. None. For 6 people, at 11:30am on a Sunday? Unheard of! We could've shown up at 12pm or 1pm - same. There may appear to be no tables available when you reserve online, but if you email they're very prompt. I didn't even need to do that in the end!

2) VERY cost-effective. Every dish was well under $15, most were around $10 - and of course it was all really tasty as well as vegetarian-friendly.

3) Excellent service. We were very well-attended to (they were often coming around, we asked for hot water which was a little unusual and they made sure to refill those too, they saw I was cold and closed the doors that were previously propped open) and made sure to tip extra because they deserved it. 

SNACKS
* Carrot Cake French Toast (cream cheese frosting. $8) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#svuomVWB8Ah0oXe5zH6nIw
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#_BQfDZu70GRK8ILfo9r9DA
How can you NOT order this? Two of my favorite things in the world in one, and they make it work. The texture was more dense like carrot cake, but the edges of the bread were crisped like French Toast. The cream cheese frosting, raspberries, maple syrup, and glazed pecans were awesome, awesome, awesome together.

* Biscuit & Strawberry Jam ($3) - 3.5 stars
The jam is great - light, a little tart. The biscuit was soft and fluffy on the inside, with a thick shell, but was a bit dry.

BRUNCH
* Two Pork Belly Austin Breakfast Tacos (scrambled eggs, maple-glazed pork belly, shredded cheese, pico de gallo, flour tortillas, avocado, chipotle aioli. $10) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#5HwcWC73YaajuKoDOXn6kA
up close: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#_islhVp7CmGvwdkVGn1IMw
The tortillas were amazing! Thick, freshly made, that texture that's soft yet holds well, that crackles just a little bit when you pick it up and bend it around the toppings. This was a huge standout for me in the meal. Most of the taco is filled with eggs, which are big, light, fluffy. There is a giant slab of pork belly on top, and a big slice of avocado. While all the ingredients were great, it was a little imbalanced with mostly eggs. Also, the avocados & pork belly on top - while it looked great - made it hard to eat because they were such big pieces placed neatly on top of the eggs.

* Polenta con Chorizo (aged cheddar, eggs, smoked cream, corn, veggies, home fries. $13) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#pAaa-FiwmUn4ZxrXGhAhKw
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#nSiXZgRDqW_VzQ669qFFxQ
This was a very uniquely made! I was expecting a thick soup-like polenta on the bottom of the bowl, but they actually fry the polenta into two slabs. I liked that! A big of crunch, a chance to break open the poached egg and let the yolk run over it. There wasn't as much meat as I'd hoped in the soup, maybe 2 big chunks, but it was soft super tasty. 

LUNCHY
* Pair of Baby Kale Tostadas (black beans, guacamole, tomato vinaigrette. $9) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#W5jfn0H-6XwolV6i_s155g
I tried a bite of this and it was great! Lighter fare, but great balance of flavors.

Brunch/lunch menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ
Drinks: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/west-of-pecos-san-francisco?select=zf8-3MnDpltyc0uGAwR6mQ#9Y_1KZZGsYmGHtOKdh-0HA
author: Ziyan C.

description: Went on a Saturday evening. Comparable wait, but it was worth it for the food. Got the flank steak fajitas and they were amazing! The gauc is delicious! Will definitely come again and recommend!
author: Bella C.

description: Good service but from the perspective of a born and raised Texan, this is not Tex-Mex.  Perhaps Cali-Mex fusion or faux Southwest might be more appropriate.  The tacos we ordered (porky and green chilies, honey duck and beef brisket and queso) were bland and dry.  The pork tasted like reconstituted meat, and they forgot to add a pork flavored bouillon.  The beef only had a splash of queso--real Texans would pour it on.  The cornbread was nice and buttery but misplaced.  Y'all won't find such a thing at a Tex-Mex place in Texas.  Maybe at bbq place but that's an entirely different genre.  And then the portion size.....anyhoo, stop playing with my heart West of Pecos.
author: Amy J.

description:
So, this seems to be more of a dinner place. Many yelp reviews speak of the green chile mac & cheese, crispy brussels sprouts, chile relleno, etc. These items are only served during dinner hours. 

Yet, I happened into here for a weekend brunch. Around 1pm on Sunday afternoon, we were looking for a place to eat- decent prices, sit down, no crazy long wait, and can sit a group of 4. We came across West of Pecos when walking down Valencia, so decided to give it a try. I like how it's good for groups, the tables are big, and there's outdoor seating. During the day time, this place is well lit due to the open doors and natural lighting. 

SERVICE: 
Service is friendly, and they constantly refilled our water.  I asked the waitress for recommendations, and she said the pork belly tacos and cuban sandwich. I'm always in favor of trying foods I usually don't make at home, so I went with the breakfast tacos. Dat pork belly can draw you in. 

FOOD: 
Two pork belly Austin breakfast tacos: scrambled eggs, maple-glazed pork belly, shredded cheese, pico de gallo, avocado, and chipotle aioli on a flour tortillas ($10)

I like the different flavors. The maple syrup added a touch a sweetness to balance the savoriness. The porkbelly was crispy and tasty. The taco could have used more pico de gallo. (I like sauces, so it seemed a bit dry) The chipotle aioli was good. I asked for the aioli on the side, but it still came on the taco. The flour tortillas were about 6-8 inches; I asked for corn tortillas but they didn't have them. Nevertheless, I still cleaned house and took these tacos to the dome.

The ultimate question: "Would I come here again?" 
Um...sure. But with so many other good Mission restaurants, this place doesn't necessarily stand out. But there's decent prices compared to some of the cray cray stuff out there. It's a good place to hang out, chill out, and catch up without any pretentiousness.
author: Joanna L.

description:
loved this place until last friday. the crab enchilada made me really sick all weekend.
probably wont be back.
author: courtney s.

description: The happy hour deals are great! $5 guacamole, queso chorizo dip, $3 for two tacos, $5 wings. Everything we ordered tasted good but unfortunately nothing stuck out. Everything seemed to lack an extra pinch of salt or flavor. However the cocktails were good and strong.
author: Norine L.

description:
Great place to grab dinner and drinks with friends!

Food: Delicious, but wasn't floored.  I got the steak fajitas and they were average.

Drinks: Great margaritas (without too much sugar)
author: Lily C.

description: Awesome brunch place. Drinks are on point and the brunch dishes classic with a tex-mex twist. NOTE: It's Tex-Mex, not standard Mexican fair, so do not judge it on that scale. The flavors are vibrant, the food taste-y, and the drinks get you waste-y. One of my favorite brunch spots in the city.
author: Demarco G.

description:
Came here for a birthday brunch with two girlfriends. I reserved via Yelp and asked that they set the table with a simple birthday message and we arrived to find a nice card at the table reserved for us outside.

To start with we ordered the cheese dip and biscuit. The cheese dip was amazing as cheese dip usually is, and the biscuit was warm and came with a delicious spicy butter along with strawberry jam. 

For our entrees we ordered coffee-rubbed brisket hash, eggs benny and pork belly tacos. The brisket hash was my favorite - it had a delicious salsa verde and a ton of potatoes and brisket. I would say that the pork belly tacos were probably my least favorite - it was really just scrambled eggs and bacon in a tortilla. It was still good, just the least unique out of the dishes. I generally judge my brunch spots based on whether or not the food they offer is something I could easily make.

Everything on the menu sounded so good, we'll definitely be back. I appreciate tasty brunch spots that also take reservations!
author: Cary L.

description:
Really good Mexican/ New- Mexican/ American food. I went there with a couple people from work and we got food and drinks. I had two glasses of the Cabernet Franc which was really nice and smooth. A couple other people got cocktails, which looked really good. I hear their whiskey is good as well.

We started with chips and guac and the guac was AMAZING. Warning- they say on their menu that chips are gluten free, but I asked the waitress and she said there is actually 10% flour in the chips. So if you are actually gluten free and have celiacs, don't eat the chips.

I ordered the crab and avocado toastadas for my main course. They were so delicious and fresh. There were two on the plate, which would be the perfect amount for a normal person, but I eat a lot and could have had 3. I also tried some of the brussel sprouts (side dish) which were excellent.

The ambiance was also great. Cool lighting and wooden tables. Two tables outdoors, which I love. The bar area is kind of separated from the main seating area, which is nice.

I would definitely come here again.
author: Jenna G.

description: Really good food (crab enchilada, chips and salsa) .  Our waitress and the manager were great.  Good tequila options :-)
author: T A.

description: Had a friend come visit and decided to go with my gf recommendation of this establishment.  We all loved the food but the puffy carnitas taco was the !!!!  Can't wait to go back and try the crab guac! We had a sea food allergy person in the party but next time nothing stops me from crabamole!
author: Aldo B.

description:
I had a few friends in town, found myself in the mission, and was looking for a good sit down restaurant. I stumbled upon West of Pecos.

It doesn't quite fit into the scene of the mission - definitely looks new and spacey. This is compared to a lot of the other hole in the wall restaurants. I think this is someone of a con, as it's losing the mission culture. It definitely feels like "the white mission."

Food was amazing. I got the buttermilk chicken, and would recommend it hands down. The mashed potatoes were great.

Also would recommend the $6 modelo beer - it's 18oz!

Overall, I'll probably be back. It's a bit spendy and doesn't quite fit with the mission feel, but the food was delicious!
author: Dylan R.

description:
The pork enchiladas were probably the best enchiladas I've had in my entire life, if you go there, I really recommend them. The queso and chips were very good as well.

Atmosphere reminded me of New Mexico.
author: William S.

description:
Tyler MacNiven, winner of Season 9 The Amazing Race, is the owner of West of Pecos - he was there when I went Sat 7/28/12.  He lite the candle for us, when I asked if he was on the show he introduced himself to us, shook our hands, & let me takes some pics!  Super nice guy.  He also owns Woodhouse Fish Company, SF.

Food we tried:  I saw someone's blog & read the menu online so I knew what I wanted to try.

Cornbread in a small skillet $6 - comes with a small scoop of butter on top & syrup on the side.  It has corn that you can see & eat inside the cornbread!  Yum!  Get it.

Green chile mac & cheese $8 - small skillet filled with creamy mac & cheese, little bit of green chile.  We liked it.

Arugula salad $10 - big enough for 2, or for 1 person's entree.  We liked it.  A bunch of goat cheese, sun-dried tomatoes, candied walnuts.  

Texas ribs $14 - Only 6 ribs, tender, some blackened on the top, a bit spicy.  I liked it.

4 dishes & 1 drink $56.42 before tip.  

There's a bar area, & 2 dining rooms.  Separate bathrooms available.  Women's had a candle in the shape of a cowboy boot, kids book on the wall on Pecos Bill.
author: Ann L.

description: Love this place. Get the queso and avocado dips to start. I usually have a Devils Tooth cocktail and a Chicken Enchilada.
author: Connor M.

description:
Yeeehaw! West of Pecos, you sexy, wild-western cowboy you!! 

You've lassoed me, my entire office and all of our swoonin' hearts in like a herd of longhorn cattle lazily grazing on the wide open American prairie of yesteryear! Replacing that lousy metaphorical prairie grass with your delicious South-western fare and heavenly libations, you've made strong, champion bulls out of us all, and we're ready for our second, third, fourth and forever rodeo, so don't ever go closin' your saloon doors--please!!

As an event planner in LA and current office manager at our company here in SF, I am extremely impressed with West of Pecos' level of professionalism, courtesy and mastery in putting on our office holiday party this year. Not only were the servers, hostesses, bartenders and owner all extremely responsive and helpful, but they made the evening even more fantastic with their fun personalities--thanks again to the entire staff, and special shout-out to Caitlyn, Lisa and Kelcey! Lisa helped me coordinate the entire event, and she was very quick to respond and patient with all of my questions :) Kelcey was our amazing (and quite beautiful) server/ new best friend who kept the party going!! 

Now for the food & drinks. Two words: epic and delicious. Exactly what you'd want from your TexMex cuisine. Everything had so much flavor and quality. Our favorites: messy Texas ribs, butternut squash enchiladas and the west of pecos fish tacos. The salsa and guac were also entirely on-point.

By the end of the night our introductory howdy how had completely transformed to howdy how in the How-can-this-place-kick-so-much-ass, and I can't wait to get back to my new favorite Mission restaurant. As good as it gets.

One more time, out of pure enthusiasm, yeeeeehaaawwwwwwwwwww!!!!
author: Brian K.

description:
Disclaimer: I know nothing about what "authentic" tex-mex or Mexican food is supposed to taste. All I care about is good food, good service, and how I feel after the experience is over. While a fourth thing I care about ($$$) hurt a little here, Pecos gets the 5 star and review. 

Traveling from NJ in San Fran for the first time, phone's dead, long day of touristing with a 9 1/2 month old son, and hungry. Dire straights here. This place looks decent so we give it a shot. The staff is so welcoming that we go with it. Manager (Lisa) offers to charge phone in office. Overall, she and the staff were super attentive.

My green chile burger was amazing. Whatever wife got was great. Staff was great with my son. Bread pudding and churros were delicious. Will return and recommend every time.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I had such a great time here. Our waitress/hostess was extremely friendly and relaxed and the atmosphere was the same. The cocktails were incredible and so unique. There was also a great beer list, and everything was very reasonably priced. I ordered the brussles sprouts and mushroom tacos. Both were amazing, but the taco was unlike anything I had had before. It was sweet and salty and fresh. 
I would absolutely recommend for anyone looking for outstanding food, reasonable prices, and good atmosphere.
author: Tamera C.

description:
I came here for weekend brunch with two of my girlfriends right when they opened, so it was really empty.

I got the Duck Confit Eggs Benedict ($11), which they seem to have replaced with just Ham. They were good, but not amazing. My friend got the Bloody Mary ($9) and really liked it. The food was pretty filling, prices were good, inside looked cool, service was fast, and there was lots of seating. So a solid, chill sit-down place overall, especially as a backup on Valencia street where restaurants can be overpriced/overbooked.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Bringing a little Wild Wild West flava to The Mission! YEEEE HAWWW!!!!

Brought to you by the man behind Woodhouse Fish Co., comes West of Pecos, a Tex-Mex restaurant serving Southern Comfort fare. All plates are meant for sharing which is perfect for groups as West of Pecos has a  ~100 person capacity with a bar area and two dining rooms. 

On my quest to try all of the "Hot New Businesses" on Yelp, I needed to figure a way to convince a special someone to come along with me. I saw West of Pecos had avocado on the menu so I sent Mr. Avocado Lover, a link to the menu and said, "Look, they have an Avocado & Lobster Salad on the menu...your favorite!" SOLD! Yes, I'm a conniving biatch. *Muahaahaaa*

F O O D
Since summer is just around the corner we wanted to keep it healthy. The items we ordered are not what I would have normally ordered. Y'all know I would have gone for those messy Texas ribs. MmMm...

*SCORCHED CORN ON THE COB w/ Sweet Chili Crema & Dried Lime ($6) - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ReeiGTEamR1ScmzAdH7s4A?select=QGXs0fEg9Ug3PutqRd45yw
A rendition of the elote (Mexican corn), the melding of the sweet corn, salty cojita cheese, sweet chili cream and lime was like a fiesta in my mouth; however, the corn needed more char to fit its title of "scorched" corn. 

*AVOCADO & MAINE LOBSTER SALAD w/ Watercress, Romaine Lettuce & Whole Grain Mustard Dressing ($18) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ReeiGTEamR1ScmzAdH7s4A?select=ydJNK4GGZPgRHlIxTJ2dwQ
Knowing how much Mr. Avocado Lover loves his avocados, I didn't want to fork his dish. He said he liked (tossing) his salad and it was overall a "4". He's a seasoned veteran in the salad tossing department so I'll take his word for it. 

*WHOLE FISH FAJITAS w/ Curtido & Plancha Sauteed Green Onions ($22) - 4.5 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ReeiGTEamR1ScmzAdH7s4A?select=OS5i4CgAE7NDvRt_1Seliw
The whole fish fajitas were ridiculously good. The fish was perfectly grilled then stuffed with coleslaw and served with curtido (pickled cabbage). The skin was crisp and the flesh tender. Paired along with the crisp, tangy coleslaw, spicy aioli and a squeeze of lime, it was a dish PACKED with flavor! I opted for the flour tortillas because I hate the rubber band texture of corn tortillas. I wasn't keen on the flour tortillas though because they were unusually thick like naan. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ReeiGTEamR1ScmzAdH7s4A?select=9ovMgUxH80pNfMYXNSuqcA Nonetheless, this dish proved that healthy can STILL be good!

Do NOT forget to order one of their artisan tequila cocktails. THEY'RE A MUST! The Mezcal Mule w/ Ginger Beer & Fresh Lime Juice ($9) was deliciously refreshing from the tinge of ginger beer. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ReeiGTEamR1ScmzAdH7s4A?select=LNIugsiO4XegtE9o6ogG4Q I can drink most guys under the table but just half sent me to a giddy stage so it's definitely a bang for your buck. 

S E R V I C E
Super friendly, down-to-earth, and attentive, the entire staff is doing a wonderful job considering they've only been open for less than 2 weeks. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
West of Pecos will have you wanting to throw on your cowboy boots and chaps with its Wild Wild West theme: country wooden furnishings and flooring, the large Texas longhorn skull adorning the wall and a painted bull skull in the bar area. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ReeiGTEamR1ScmzAdH7s4A?select=0IMhM2RJ7KhxuLtMHnLWjg NO bare-booty leather chaps please!

With a large dining area, West of Pecos is good for large groups. 

P A R K I N G
Difficult street parking. Take a cab or public transit because there's no nearby parking lots. 

Welcome to The Mission, West of Pecos! Now, if only you can get a mechanical bull, it will be all good in the hood!

*Cue in "Ride 'Em High Ride 'Em Low"*

YEEEEE HAWWWW!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I came on a Saturday afternoon, and was seated immediately. Customer service was great, and very attentive to our requests. The food and drinks were good quality, but the menu's were very limited. Also a little pricey for the amount 
Ex: ordered a burger and fries, but there were only 4 French fries 
Definitely Recommend, but not the place for big esters or if you're expecting a good portion
Also, The $40 margarita isn't worth the price, small quantity (came in basically a beer mug with small glasses that were supposed to allow for 5 drinks) and average taste
author: Breanna J.

description: Great fish tacos and great cheese dip!!  Nice atmosphere and reasonable prices.  Highly recommended.
author: Max S.

description:
I'm a bit shocked at all the positive reviews of this spot.  Maybe we hit it on a bad night?

Worst guac I've had in a long time. Unripened chunks of avocado with corn in it???  It was $10 and a pretty small portion to boot. Kept adding lime juice and salt to no avail. Corn should not be in guac!!  It is a cheap filler and those two flavors don't work together. 

The tacos were just as bad. The brisket was smothered in some kind of syrupy BBq sauce. You could have put leather in the taco and it would not have made a difference. The fluffy shell was not my thing either. Too doughy and no flavor.  At $5/taco this was way off the mark.
author: Chandler H.

description:
WoP is a great way to be closet bougey. Best way to tell people you are "grabbing Mexican in the Mission", when you'd rather hang out on Valencia than Mission St.

Food is legit, Fish Tacos and pork sliders were tasty, burger was surprisingly mediocre (kidding, this is a Mexican joint!) - careful not to OD on the chips and guac! Get the chips and guac, its beats Rosa Mexicano's!

Overall experience ex-food is awesome! Who doesn't love real hardwood tables, tall ceilings, snakeskins in the bathroom and being surrounded by other yuppies happy to play $30/head for Mexican in the Mission?
author: Roger L.

description: Walking around the Mission and stumbled upon West of Pecos. Glad I did! Great service and YUMMY food. I ordered a carnitas puffy taco, maple roasted brussel sprouts, and a glass of Lodi red wine. I was completely happy with everything I ordered. Loved the ambiance. I'll be back for sure!
author: Mickey D.

description:
This place is good for groups. I went to West of Pecos last night with a group of friends for Halloween/ Hubby's birthday dinner. I requested a table where we could see people and also be seen in costume. The large windows gave us a good view of people milling around the mission in costume so we were really excited about that. The ambiance is on the rustic side. 

I chose this place because I really wanted a prickly pear margarita. When I got my margarita it was strong. Don't say I didn't warn you!

Although I like the quality and flavor of the food I find that the portions are either too small or large. I ordered the pork enchilada and it came nice and hot on a small cast iron skillet. The portion was too small for me and I would say I eat normal portions when I go out. So, I wasn't thrilled with my entree. However, my husband's entree the ribs came with slaw and baked beans. His portion was much larger so much that he couldn't finish it and he usually eats large portions. The only portion that seem to hit a nice medium is our friend's Fish Tacos. They were really good, fresh tasting and not too big or small.
author: Kelly H.

description:
we got to Sunday Streets early, this time it was in the Mission. Naturally, we were hungry so we made our way to West of Pecos... BEST DECISION everrr

AMBIANCE: we walked into this very "OC" reminiscent Mexican food spot, meaning it was super clean and "fancier" than the average City spot. it was pretty large and open but we sat closer to the bar. it was a long booth with small round tables along side it. the decor was a mix of dessert icons, wooden chairs and tables, chilli peppers hanging from the ceiling, cattle skulls and horns, rot iron candle chandelier, and leather skins as portrait. i felt like i wanted to buy some cowboy boots from Wasteland so i can wear them here even though it's casual and no specific attire :)  

FOOD:  SO GOOD. seriously. I'm from San Diego and i'm very critical of Mexican food and dont really care for classic mexican food but this spot has it on point! i got the DUNGENOUS CRAB BREAKFAST CHIMICHUNGA, my cousins got the BREAKFAST PORK BELLY TACOS, and HUEVOS RANCHEROS. i would rank the goodness in that order too. the crab chimichunga was so light and flakey on the outside and contained collared greens, bacon, scrambled eggs, mascarpone, and green chillies. i enjoyed every bite! oh and it was also larger than the plate in length. The maple glazed pork belly tacos melted in our mouths. the scrambled eggs def gave it a breakfast touch to differentiate it from regular tacos. for dessert we got a side of CHURROs that came with mexican chocolate dipping sauce. deeee-freakin-licious. the BLOODY MARY was also nice and spicy :)

PRICE:  average per plate is $12, but you get what you pay for!

SERVICE: the waiter we had was sooo nice and accommodating. we asked if we could get a side of Churros since we saw there is a dish of Fried Chicken and Churros and he was more than happy to accommodate.

PARKING: street parking in the mission, well you know how that goes.
author: Veronica E.

description: This place is really well decorated and is just dim enough! The food is good, def more tex-mex than Mexican which is a great break from all the traditional Mexican food spots in the Mission. The margaritas are delicious but I wouldn't say they are strong. Def a great spot for a date or a birthday dinner. Great ambiance and you won't be disappointed with the grub.
author: Brittini S.

description:
I've come here way too many times to count. The menu has changed quite a bit  since their initial opening, and there are some things that I really enjoy on the current one and some things I miss from the original; one being the Maine lobster salad for example. But all things aside, I am a big fan of this place. The ambience is very much in keeping with its Tex Mex cuisine, down to the steer horns and poncho-like blankets adorning the walls. 

If you have time, come for the Happy hour (5pm-6:30pm): $5 Sangria and frozen margs, $5 starters, and $3 for an order (of two) tacos!

The current dinner menu satisfies. I've had the BBQ chicken (huge portion and juicy all around), flank steak, and the chile relleno. All of the above have left me pleased. The green chile mac was good, but definitely under seasoned. A few dashes of hot sauce fixed that issue and added a nice kick. 

A go-to drink for me has been the Pecos Punch (not sure if it is still on the drink menu) but it is a blend of rum and other good libations. Definitely on the sweet side, but comes in a glass carafe - meant for sharing... unless you're trying to get after it that evening. 

Overall, great restaurant. If you're looking for a cute and trendy but unpretentious restaurant in the mission that has a playful menu, this place is your spot. I took my, very particular father here and he could not have enjoyed himself more. That alone ensures this spot is a winner.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
We got there and was waiting list of 20minutes. 
We went to the bar order drinks (greyhound good) and fish tacos since we were very hungry! The fish tacos *** uhmmm, really good! It came out super fast and as soon as we were done they called us to the restaurant. 
We ordered ceviche and New York stake. 
Ceviche was nothing special, but the ny stake was pretty bomb! The service was good but the only think that was bothering me was the lights! Too dark... Can't see the food that well or the face of the people's.
author: Kim K.

description: Good margaritas and guacamole, the place was warm but not too crowded: great for some after work drinks, even on a Friday.
author: Hélène A.

description:
I am starting with 3 stars because the hostess needs a reality check.  She was not at her station for a good amount of time, so we waited for someone to greet us for several minutes.  She then seemed very upset at something and gave us attitude about the wait time.  When we checked on our table, she responded "are you on the list?"  "yes we are".  She replied "then i will call you."  that is not what i asked!  So me being in the food industry would not eat there.  The hostess is the first person greeting customers and she should not treat people like that.

The food and drinks were good for the price.  Moscow mule was not what you expected, but decent.  Long wait for food in drinks if you sit in the bar area.  Over all good food and drinks.  $10 for a margarita and $10 for moscow mule.  Puffy tacos were fluffy flour tacos, 2 is enough for 1 average eater.
author: K B.

description:
Been meaning to try WOP for some time now but only got around to it the other night.  

Ambiance: Slightly overdone (IMO) with the cowboy hats, lassos and chili pepper light fixtures dimly lit. I felt like I walked in to a themed restaurant somewhere/anywhere outside the Mission or even SF. But nice wooden interior. Location though, is great. 

Food: I hate to say it but it was rather disappointing. I personally don't care if this isn't authentic "Tex-Mex" or not but everything was just a bit bland. Granted, we didn't order any of their main dishes (just several sides and starters) but we felt most of our dishes needed to be injected flavor. For example, the mac and cheese had overcooked noodles and was loaded with crumbs which contributed to the overall blandness. I'll have to say though the burrata and heirloom tomato salad was nice. Great wine/beer/cocktail options. 

Service: Friendly, timely; no complaints in this department. 

Still, I might give them another go at a later time. Perhaps brunch.
author: Esther A.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in the mission. I am from Texas so I have strong opinions about TexMex. They got it right though, these are the flavors of the great spots in Austin. The staff is friendly and the food and drinks are exceptional. 

Tip: You can get chips and salsa for like $1, instead of spending 10$ on the guac which isn't their best offering.

Things to try: The ceviche-yes!, Green michelada, encheladas (green or red), the happy hour tacos!, the wings, the street corn
author: Shara M.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night at 7:45pm, and even though we had a reservation, we still had to wait about 30 mins for our group of 3 to get seated. 

Because it was Tuesday, we got tacos and I personally got two of their puffy tacos. The taco was different from your traditional corn/flour tortilla. This one was thicker (hence the "puffy") and had a texture more like naan bread, but I enjoyed it quite a bit. It seemed to pair well with their very flavorful toppings. 

Though it was crowded, the service was good and the food was tasty, so I would still come back.
author: Connie C.

description: Best mexican place I have ever been in my entire life. The service is great, cool decorations, and interesting twists to the Tex-mex cuisine. I definitely recommend this place to whoever happens to stop by in the wonderful city of San Francisco.
author: Benjamin G.

description: West of Pecos was recommended to me by a coworker, so I headed there on a Tuesday night to grab some dinner and drinks. My boyfriend and I both had a spicy margarita - mine with mezcal (Mohave) and his with just tequila (la flama verde). Both were delicious! We also had the queso dip with chorizo to start. For our main corse we had puffy tacos, one crispy carnitas and one bbq beef brisket. I preferred the carnitas! We also had fish tacos which were pretty good. I love the vibe of this restaurant and I will definitely come back!
author: Teresa C.

description:
If you're looking for a good brunch come to West of Pecos! I loved the margaritas, the spicy one is delish.. Hubby got the fried chicken and churros.. what a brilliant combo. I had the fish tacos - delishh. 

Looking forward to coming back for more!!
author: Monica S.

description:
On most occasions I come here to sulk in the happy hour they offer. Duck tacos, tequila, margarita deals are killer in this place and they definitely know to make your mouth ooze as you wait for the crazy night they are about to give you...

Waiting was also never an issue, coming to this place you get an awe by the decor all around the place. Artifacts like snake skin and skulls rest amongst the top of many corners. Chili peppers disguised as intimate lighting gives you this yearn of wanting to touch it (but don't they really don't like that). 

This is definitely a fancy Chex Mex. I've also tried their regular menu and the salads always give me a crave to try more. Definitely for a date BUT they have a great divider that separates the bar area to the dinner area so friends too can enjoy.
author: Ladonna A.

description: The service was good but the food could have been better..  my burger was pink inside not well done like I asked ... Got another one though ... Fries were pretty decent for the nine steak fries they give you.. I wouldn't go back
author: Adrian H.

description:
Made it to West of Pecos on a recent work trip, which in all fairness, was filled with fantastic food and drink. 

Another disclaimer: I'm not really a Tex-Mex type of girl, so you may take this review with a grain of salt. 

And speaking of which, I am a girl that DEFINITELY knows her guacamole, and after reading a few glorious review of the dip, we ordered a few for our table. It must have been this particular night, but it was sooooooo super salty, that with the salt from the chips was more than enough. Everything else about it, texture and taste was there. I did still have a few bites, thanks to the tasty Negra Modelo in which I had to wash it down. The queso was decent (I know my queso too) but I've definitely had better elsewhere. I would try both again, as maybe it was an off night? 

I decided on their variation of the Chile Relleno: fire roasted with quinoa and some cheese on top. Sad to say this was a miss for me as well. The quinoa was a bit dry, the relleno was still a bit too crunchy for me, but I did eat the cheese on top. 

Sorry guys, this just missed the mark for me and since I'm only in SF about once or twice a year, there are too many other places to discover.
author: Allie A.

description:
This food was such a nice change to normal San Franciscan food. One cannot find an authentic Tex-Mex restaurant in San Francisco very often (especially now that there's only one Chevy's left!  Haha just kidding about the authentic part ;D).

I came here with a big group of friends for my birthday dinner. There were 8 of us I believe, and they sat us in a cozy corner booth next to the window. We started off with the Pecos Punch to share. Man this was awesome! Basically a huge pitcher for all of us to share - the perfect amount. We ended up getting another pitcher - a margherita I believe, to share. 

The "Must-order" appetizers:
-Grilled Corn on the cob - DEADLY DELICIOUS. The rub on the corn is so addicting, consisting of chili butter giving a red appearance. Sometimes until this day I still think about the corn and try recreating it at home!
-GUAC AND CHIPS - A MUST!!!!!  Sounds typical, but they included very ripe avacados, and the best part was small baby heirloom tomatoes (chopped in half) that were just scattered in the guac...really, a special guac that one cannot order anywhere else!
-Mac and Cheese. I remember all of my friends liked this one. I thought it was pretty good, but the two appies above have a special place in my heart.

The "Must-order" entrees:
-Fried chicken. I love the flavor of this chicken since it had brown sugar...man it was great!
-Pork Chop got great reviews too.

The only thing stopping me from coming back is parking in the Mission District. But this is great for a night out with friends!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: West of Pecos is a Mexican restaurant with pep. The fish tacos where a tastegasm in itself. The dessert (churros) were crispy and tasty, and don't even get me started on the Nachos with homemade guacamole as a starter. Nice service, although when asked questions about the meals, our server was a little sparse with giving answers. A restaurant with a nice atmosphere for a reasonable price tag.
author: Luka K.

description:
Everything about West of Pecos was spectacular! As a walk in on Friday night, we were surprisingly seated right away even though our entire party wasn't present yet. We actually sat at the table for a good 30 minutes at least before the others showed up, but the waitresses were so kind and understanding and refilled our drinks constantly. 

As for food, we ordered the guacamole and the campfire cornbread skillet for appetizer, and the fish tacos and the fried chicken for the main courses.

I must say that all 4 of these dishes were truly amazing that I think they are equally as recommendable depending on your personal preference. The guacamole is a definite must because of its freshness but the cornbread was just divine when eaten with the syrup and butter. On the other hand, I personally love fish tacos and ze rally enjoyed the perfect texture of the fried fish strips in my tacos, but the fried chicken was one of the best I've ever had. The chicken was tender and the breading had a sweet finish due to the brown sugar buttermilk. Paired with the collard greens and mashed potato, it was divine. 

This is definitely a restaurant worth trying and one I will be coming back to!
author: Luby H.

description:
I went there with 3 friends. I ordered the prawn fajita for dinner. It didn't have any beans on the side. My ordered came and it was a tiny plate, and a small side of guacamole and tomatoes (for $18). It was probably the smallest Fajita I ever had in my life. The 3 pieces of bread that they gave me was not well cooked and oily.

This was my second visit to this place. I remember that the first time, we had lunch, and they charged $10 for just chips and salsa. Many places give that for free as appetizers.

I wouldn't recommend this place. The food is way overpriced. And the food is below average for a Mexican restaurant.
author: Eric E.

description:
Texas is a big state.. and West of Pecos is considered Far West Texas... So even though I'm from Texas, I may not be a good judge on authenticity here.. but I was very disappointed here.. I got the Biscuits and sausage gravy.. Normally one would expect eggs, biscuits, sausage, and gravy.. This is what makes sense.. and thats what kind of came out.. but if you read the menu carefully, it is  "sausage gravy". So I ended up with biscuits and eggs covered with gravy and small pieces of ground up sausage.. Not enough sausage by any stretch of the imagination, and the flavors of everything just ended up tasting like gravy. Thats right.. gravy.. and I left hungry.

So why 1 star? I sat at the bar, and the bartender was rude. When I asked for the check I gave him my card at the same time.. When he came back with the bill, he didn't even bother handing me the bill, and instead threw it down on the counter.. I barely said anything to him, voiced no complaints, and did nothing to call attention to myself.. So I see no reason to get rude service..
author: James S.

description: Undercooked, stinky crab... when we complained to the waitress she disagreed, then we suggested she ask the kitchen if the crab was frozen to which they replied that it was fresh. We asked that the crab dish be taken away because it stunk like old fish. The waitress acted like we were crazy for saying it tasted bad/old & didn't even apologize or take it off the check. They also rushed us out of there. Not a good experience at all.
author: Olga S.

description:
Can I get a HIGH FIVE for West of Pecos?! You bet! My experience at West of Pecos in Mission was awesome! 

The Chopped Harvest Salad was impeccable and unlike any salad I have ever tasted! The salad was chilled and each bite of the crisp lettuce, jicama, corn, crispy garbanzo beans, avocado, queso fresco, cilantro vinaigrette was bursting with flavor!

Our server was wonderful and the ambiance was very Southwestern.  Definitely a place to chill and have a beer or two with chips and salsa.
author: Nell C.

description: The food here is not bad food it is decent food. Not a foodie place at all. But the price is way too high for such small dishes. Fajitas are tiny no rice or beans and def not shareable. The service was extremely slow. Drinks were the only redeeming thing. Wouldn't recommend this place for dinner. Just drinks and small bite.
author: Kellis J.

description:
Just ok. 

This place is hokey and the food is ok - not great. 

What's surprising is that it's more pricey than you'd expect AND the service is more hipster than you'd expect. That's probably more of a function of the location than anything else.
author: Stephanie M.

description: As obnoxious as it was during the Dreamforce convention who basically had the run of SF all week, WoP managed not just to accommodate an extra party added to my reservation for 2, but the service was unflinchingly attentive. Even the owner was on the floor working. As for the food, I am leary of TexMex and queso anything BUT I was pleasantly surprised by the food here. Carnitas and beef and queso street tacos were tasty, except the honey duck (too weird), chips with guac/queso, and maple brussel sprouts were excellent too. More refined than the average TexMex. I wouldn't mind adding this to my list of repeat visits. The Roadrunner cocktail is to die for and I don't even like Mezcal. Count me as a convert!
author: C P.

description: Meh. Everything just had something slightly wrong with it. Fish tacos were just a little too fried and battered. Chips were just a little too salty. French toast was just a little too wet in the middle. DIY lemonade was cool, but I'd rather get my lemonade pre-made by an expert or bottle instead of having to fiddle with the ingredients and still ending up unsatisfied in the end. Should've known it would be underwhelming when it had no wait on a Sunday at 1pm!
author: Kathy L.

description: Pretty good -- nice place. Great queso dip, good for salad eaters who are out with Mexican food fans.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
The food here is delicious. I had the wild muschroom tacos, I scarfed them down so quickly I practicly inhaled them. The ingredients are so complimentary to each other and the pomegranate is a delightful suprise, but the queso anejo is in my opinion, what really makes the taco so savory. Though I'm not supposed to eat cheese I would gladly risk my health if this taco was all I could eat for the rest of my life!
 I was a bit skeptical at first of the rice because it was green. Glad I took a chance because it was so good.
author: Angela S.

description: Love the Modelo beer in the big mug.  Plus it is just a darn good light beer, very tasty.  They have great guacamole.  The food is small portion for a big price so I am not too happy about that but I've been here several times with friends and always seem to have a great time while I am there.  I also love the grilled broccoli with garlic.
author: Liz D.

description: Food was good and came out quickly.  One item we ordered was never brought.  Unfortunately, our waitress did not return to our table between taking our app and entree orders, and the time we finished these 30 minutes later.  This provided no opportunity to ask about our missing item, nor to order a second drink.  So, I've given one star for the very bad service.
author: Eric W.

description: I have been visiting Valencia Street every so often for ten years now. It has been growing over the past decade and now has a big restaurant scene. Most restaurants have nice interiors with clever menus. I always walk by these new restaurants when I am on Valencia always wanting to try them. Today I walked by this one and decided to try it. The interior was dimly lit and dark. The menu had American food staples like fish and chips, kobe beef hamburger, fried chicken, pork chop, and ribs. The prices were average, but definitely not cheap. I got a coffee-rubbed barbecue brisket sandwich that came with fries and slaw. It was $14. I enjoyed it. I also got a "Do It Yourself Arnie Palmer." I got this at Woodhouse FIsh Co. I guess it's a new trend to have "Do It Yourself" lemonade and Arnold Palmer. I would come back here again, but first I must try some more new restaurants on Valencia.
author: Denise C.

description: The burger on the lunch menu was great..  the chicken on kids meal should have more kid friendly food (in my opinion)...  he was expecting chicken strips and he didn't like the seasoning on it either... kids can be picky! The service was a little slow, and they did forget to add avacado to my burger..
author: Sonia K.

description: Smelled like vomit and waitress spilled water all over me. She promised to take a "a big item or two" off our bill, bill came back with everything on it. Called her out and she took the cheapest item off of it. Guess she thought we were too drunk to notice. Shady and shifty service.
author: Louis H.

description: The queso is great and the vegetarian tacos are awesome.  I would order both of these again.  Our server was really nice and helpful.  We enjoyed our visit.  The crispy meat tacos was also tasty (I think this was pork).  The steak one was our least favorite, but it was still good.
author: Erich B.

description:
Fantastic!  We popped in on Saturday with the kids and friends and had a wonderful time.   The service was great (and they were very accommodating of our strollers), the food better and the drinks best of all.  And it wasn't too expensive? We'll definitely be coming back.  Some highlights:

1.  The queso dip was spot-on.  We're veggie so we skipped the chorizo (they were happy to leave it out), and the dip was exactly, perfectly what I wanted from a queso dip, with the right amount of spice and a great consistency.  Should have ordered two.

2.   The guacamole was also the bomb, with big chunks of avocado and a great hand on the seasoning.  Really well done.

3.   The Micheladas!  I've never had a green Michelada, but it was deliciously spicy and tangy, with a smoky-salty rim that added to the flavor.  Even better was the red Michelada, which was one of the best I've ever had.  Whoever's working the bar needs a raise.

4.   Fish tacos.  I'm not usually a fan of breaded and fried fish tacos, but the red pickled cabbage provided the right amount of acid, and the sauce was really delicious.  Still might rather have grilled fish, but I'd eat these tacos again.  Be warned: they bring you three hulking tacos, could have easily split the dish between two people.

5.  Kale Caesar Tostadas.  This dish was a bit of an innovation, with black bean and avocado tostadas covered in a kale caesar salad.  It ended up being heavier than I'd expected, but it was a great salad, and it seemed to last forever.

6.  Chopped Salad, with fried garbanzos.  A+ on this one, a excellent mexican version of a chopped salad with jicama and garbanzos for texture.  I might get the dressing on the side next time (they gave me too much ), but a really great choice for anyone looking to reduce their waistline (like me).

I'm also quite fond of the look of the place, and of the open-air vibe.  If I had one suggestion, it would be to change up the music!  I love classic rock, but when I'm in a cantina I should be listening to Willie Nelson and the like.
author: Cody V.

description: Great service, delicious and flavorful tacos...only thing that needed more zest was the guacamole!
author: Yas G.

description:
Pretty good drinks and the bartenders are nice.
The Fried Chicken is tasty!
author: Charlie H.

description:
Missionites, you are cruel to take West of Pecos down below 4 stars, this is as solid a 4 star place as there is in the hood.  We went there multiple times when they opened and have returned every few months, never disappointed.  Tyler, who I didn't realize was the owner, is also a super-nice guy.

They do a great job of upscaling and California-izing Tex-Mex cuisine.  I love their queso with chorizo, it's heaven on earth with those salted chips.  I could eat it with a spoon.  In fact, I might have.  Same goes for the green chile mac 'n' cheese, every bite is sumptuous.  As for entrees, my fave is the ribs; amazing flavor with the apricot.  Everything is worth trying here, if it sounds good it will likely taste very good.

Make sure you try some of their margaritas.  They're really good, never too sweet and packs the right punch with every sip.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Alright joint, wasn't my choice as I was meeting up with a friend of mine since I was in town. He'd already gotten a table w/his friends by the time my gf and I arrived and it was a half circle booth that was going to be way too cramped for 7 adults to eat at (drinking or hanging out would've been alright). With that said the staff seemed friendly and cordial and not at all troubled by us throwing a chair on the end. 

The "table" got margarita pitchers to split while I ordered a couple local brews, I did have a little bit of their guac and queso dip which tasted pretty awesome, especially since the chips were also seasoned.

I ordered the pork trio and was not disappointed at all, all 3 had their distinct tastes but were all good. Would highly recommend it. Everyone else seemed to devour their food pretty quickly as well (I know my gf had the artichokes and someone else destroyed the fish tacos in short time). 

Service was attentive and they had no problems splitting our check 6 ways (evenly) at the end which was a good way to reduce hassle for everyone.
author: Wayne Z.

description:
I've been meaning to go here many times now since they opened . Perhaps it's good that I waited as chef August Schuchman formerly of of Lark Creek in Larkspur, who was at Woodhouse FIsh Co (same resto group as West Of Pecos) is behind the menu now. Everytime I've shown up it's been a gangbusters crowd and wait so I'd opt somewhere else. With a few people from out of town visiting, we made sure to have resys first. A group of 6 of us filled one of the larger booths by the window. Every table was squarely packed. They're obviously doing well. 

After much conversing we ended up with:

-Grilled Corn On The Cob
chile butter, marshall farms honey, sea salt

-Crispy Carnita Pies
ancho chile braised pork shoulder, nopale-corn salad, tomato vinaigrette

-Green Chile Mac And Cheese
cave-aged cheddar, anaheim chiles, cornbread crumbles 

-Texas Style Chile
braised buffalo, smoked crema

-Braised Pork Shoulder
corn cakes, red onion jam

-Bacon-wrapped Jumbo Gulf Prawns
hatch chile mayonnaise, arugula, salt and pepper mango 

-Margaret's Pork Chop
arkansas black applesauce, mashed potatoes, baby carrots, turnips, radish

-Roasted Half Chicken
creamed corn, fennel pollen, gravy, braised black kale, ancho chile butter

All super tasty. I can see why the place is popular. The western themed fair with a twist plays well. The drinks are pretty good too and pack a wallop. It's super crowded and loud so it you dont dig that scene or arent in the mood, id say look elsewhere. Service is off and on since they're so crowded but for the most party they took care of us. Id say go in a big group so that you can try a lot of things. Just make sure you make resys or dont mind waiting with a drink at the bar/
author: Kim N.

description:
One of my new favorites!   

Make your own lemonade was a fun but not best lemonade of my life. But it kept me entertained for a bit so I'm willing to look past it. 

I shared a plate from each of the three sections and I honestly couldn't decide which one i preferred. Eggplant enchiladas, crab artichokes and the honey ribs. Incredible. 

Churros and chocolate were on point. The dark chocolate they serve is fantastic, however, the lighter chocolate wasn't as amazing.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
The place is beautiful, the staff was very friendly, and the food was quite alright. 

The dim lighting and decorations really complimented the food and aura of the place. 

The staff could not be any better. They were all very friendly and attentive. 

The food is why I give it four stars instead of five. I had the burger, which was okay, but not more than that. The meat tasted just 'meh.' Not bad quality, but also not as good as I would have expected. Nothing against the chef or cooks; it was cooked well. However, the fries that came on the side were not seasoned well. Very bland.
author: Victor T.

description: super happening bar during cinco de mayo, but since it was cinco de mayo, they couldn't make drinks other than what they served on the menu. they had a mechanical bull, and the music and people was great. bartenders were nice, and the food looked good even though i didn't eat here. would come back again!
author: Minerva L.

description:
1 star for coldest best presented Mexican beer in SF
1 star for very great service!
1 star for ambiance (fire place) 
1 star for great queso, guac, and strawberry short cake Sunday. 
1 start for the best manager! He came by with a great attitude to chat about movies, joke a little with us, and make sure we were happy with our food!
author: Charles P.

description: Churros & fried chicken, croissant French toast, juevos rancheros, stuffed poblano chilies & bottomless coffee! Was delightful! Great ambiance & really sweet ginger GM/owner that brought us complementary chips & guac for helping him with the Christmas lights! Will recommend to friends & definitely come back!
author: Lindsey D.

description: I've eaten here 2 weeks in a row. This time I skipped the unhealthy queso and cornbread and had the chopped salad with chicken. Holy smokes, all I was saying throughout my meal was, this chicken is SOOO MOIST! One of the best chicken I've had, salad was refreshing and good! Guacamole was good too.
author: Karen T.

description: To the owner... BRIGIE was amazing! You have done a fine job hiring her. She cater to everyone's need in a timely manager and I was with a party of 12.. Lisa on the other hand seem to have a attitude which was VERY noticeable to the entire table.. might need to have a talk with her! Please keep hiring people like Bridgie
author: Ceciles K.

description: This was an interesting mix of goofy and interesting. We went for happy hour which seems like the right time to try things - the pork taco was pretty tasty and a good deal for $2.50. I liked the queso as well, although it was too salty. We'd originally ordered it without chorizo to keep it vegetarian, but it came out on the side. I was glad, as it turned out to be quite tasty. The drinks lineup looked appealing.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Great food prices and service.  Fried chicken and fish tacos were great.  Ceviche also good
Great selection of whiskeys
author: V N.

description:
If you were annoyed by a huge group of giggling Asian girls, that would be us. A group of old classmates came together on this side of the Pacific, and we had a big reunion, which was plenty of reason for the giggles since we grew up together and some of us haven't seen each other for more than 10 years.

We were looking for a brunch place that takes reservations for a big group -- that turns out to be a bit of a challenge in SF, but one of our friends managed to find one here at 11am. That it turned out to be delicious is just another plus.

I got the poached eggs, which really is eggs benedict with duck confit. Forget everything Anthony Bourdain said; it was very delicious, and the sage hollandaise sauce was the star of the dish.

Everyone else seemed to be super pleased with their food, and the restaurant was more than accommodating for us loud bunch of excited girls. I can't wait to come back to brunch again.
author: Alice C.

description: Hands-down my favorite brunch spot in San Francisco. The menu changes frequently and the dishes are always seasonal and fresh. They have a full bar and the spicy margarita is my fave. The staff is super friendly and service is always fantastic. Definitely deserves a 5 star rating!
author: Kim O.

description:
All my fish taco lovers throw they hands in the ayer! West of Pecos has some of the best I've had in a long long time. Just delectable. The chipotle aioli really took it there.

I got the squash soup, and thought it was yummy. I tried the roadrunner and the mohave margaritas, loved both!!
author: Cassera C.

description: Since my first experience, I have even been back a handful of times at all hours and the experience was much improved. They have a fun happy hour. The tacos and chips are delicious. The service is attentive without being overbearing. Everyone had a happy disposition. I'm a fan and have recommended it to many others. I'd love it if there was more seating in the bar area.
author: Betty V.

description:
Had a great brunch here. Prices are standard for the area (~$13/dish), if not on the cheaper side. We were initially attracted by the storefront - the restaurant has a great ambiance. It was surprisingly quiet for a Sunday brunch in the Mission. It was not even 1/4 full at 11:30am. We walked by our usual haunt, Luna Park, afterwards, and it was packed as usual. The quieter atmosphere was refreshing!

The food was good. My friend has steak and eggs on an english muffin which looked amazing! I had a crab frittata, which was also quite good. Half of the menu contains avocado, which I love! I also love the DIY Arnold Palmer - you get to adjust the lemon:tea:sugar ratio to your precise tastes :).

Our waiter was friendly and hipster-handsome... Service was good and everything came quick. (You'd think it'd be a given since it was not crowded, but I've been to places where there are only like four souls in the restaurant yet the service is nowhere to be seen...)

So glad the food lived up to the thoughtful decor! We will be back!
author: Rachel Y.

description:
Oh man, the queso dip. It's like melting a bottle of tex-mex cheese wiz in the microwave, but so, so much better. Order it. Or order two, like we did. I swear, I could have licked the bowl clean. 

For my main, I ordered Margaret's Pork Chop. First of all, who is Margaret? Does she cook the chop? Was she the pig? Or was she the tragically lost first love of the owner of West of Pecos, and she just really, really liked pork? Curious minds would like to know. 

Second of all, the chop was really good. It was juicy and not at all fatty. I hardly needed to trim off anything before eating. The flavour was rich, having kept the bone in during the cook time. It was awesome.

I wish I could say the same for the mashed potatoes that were underneath. They were pretty lukewarm. I also tried some of my neighbours grilled asparagus and it was just so, so good. I used to think I didn't like asparagus, but it turns out I'm just picky as to how it's cooked. This was tender crisp, easy to bit through and hard to forget.

I'd certainly head back here to try some of the other menu items, as well to have even more of that wonderful dip. If only I could have had some bottled to take back to the East Coast with me.
author: Shannon H.

description:
I think the main benefit of WoP (see what I did there?) is that it's big. Despite that it's still pretty crowded but if you have a group of like 8 or so people you can manage here if you get to the bar early enough. 

It's a little pricey but most of what we had was pretty good. I thought the Mezcal Mule was tasty and the guac, while at fancy bar prices, was great.

I shared an order of the fish tacos with some of my friends. On the plus side, they're huge. An order could be too much for one person. You even get a solid slice of avocado with each one. The downside is that they're kinda under-salted, over-battered, and the tortillas kinda suck and fall apart. So maybe don't get them, but the waitress said the brisket sandwich was her favorite so I guess that'll be next.
author: Misha T.

description:
DDDDDDDDDDelicious!

Atm: First thing I noticed was the awesome bathroom... =P. The faucet was an old fashioned water pump... haha that def. made washing hands more fun. 
The place had wooden tables with big cushion-y chairs. Very open space, cool tex decor-with hanging chilies and carved statues. Open kitchen and they have outdoor seating right outside their restaurants as well.

Food:
Def. for meat lovers-great meaty choices. Pork Ribs-huge portion, comes with beans, and very spicy.
Fried Chicken-fresh watermelon salad was super refreshing. Corn-was tangy and spicy. Super delicious!!
Burger-slight dry, muffin bun. Spicy too. The bacon was apparently the best part of the buger. 

Overall, delicious food and fun decor. =)
author: Yuchen Z.

description:
As a Texan who has lived in the bay area for almost 15 years now, I have to say this restaurant really speaks to that split SF/Texan split personality in me.  Since I've been away from Texas for so long and only really visit twice a year,  I can't speak to if this is the what Texas food has evolved to, so my impression of WOP is just like what the restaurant's site says, 'southwestern inspired...'  I'd also add to their description as, Texas inspired and a little upgraded, but that's just my opinion!  

Things I love and are yum about this place that matter to me as a Texan:

The portion sizes! It's big but not sooo big or too insultingly small.  
The Queso! (cheese dip)  
Chip refills!
Friendly service (always always always, not one bad experience yet!)
Strong margs at a reasonable price (bonus, awesome happy hour prices!)
The fried Chicken
Brisket is on the menu (in an enchilada but hey, that'll do!)
ALL the sides, esp the skillet corn bread!

I also highly recommend West of Pecos If you are looking for a spot to host a little dinner party.  There's a separate room called the Saddle Room which can be closed off to make it more private and cozy.  Ask for Nicole, she's the manager who assisted me in making reservations for our event.  Nicole was very attentive throughout our huge dinner, quick to help with any extra little requests!  She was great through and through, big Texas gold star for her!

Anyway, good stuff, the best happy hour, and sweet dinner event spot!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I came here for the messy, sticky ribs.  It's a long story, but bottom line, I could not find a bbq rib place with sauced ribs in the vicinity of 16th mission bart,  but I did find saucy ribs on this menu.  that's how we ended up here. 

when we arrived, I realized this was a fancy tex-mex kind of place, but the ribs were exactly what I wanted.  And they were delicious!!!!  they were large and meaty, had that black charred   goodness that I like and they were messy and sauced.  Many of the other rib joints have the dry rub.  The beans that came with them were good. I didn't try the cole slaw b/c I don't like mayo so I passed on it.

We did order the skillet corn bread.  I didn't like it.  For one, the texture was more like cake, light and airy; that was unexpected and not in a pleasant way. The corn bread had some spice to it, so when you have the texture of cake, but with spice, it was no-bueno. 

for the record, my friends ordered the fish tacos and they liked them very much. I was very satisfied with my ribs. They also get bonus points for having Mexican Coke. 

If the corn bread had been delicious, I'd give them 5 stars.  I will definitely return here.
author: Cheryl D.

description:
We were tired and hungry and all the places we wanted to try had long waits.   We saw an empty outdoor table in front of Pecos and we went in to see if they had space.  it turns out that there was a 45 minute wait for a table outside and a 30 minute wait for an inside table BUT we could eat at the bar with no wait if there was room.  Tonight was our lucky night - we popped our heads into the bar area and got a high top table right by the open window - almost as good as the table outside. Our girls night out was getting even better.  

 We ordered guacamole and chips, fish tacos, pork flautas, and a prawn dish.  The guac and chips were TDF; we would definitely order again.  The guac had pearl tomato halves in it, and also a nice lime kick; it was fresh and the chips were multi-colored.  The fish tacos were delicioous - the batter was a little thick but it was crispy and tasty.  There were 3 tacos and each had generous portion of fish, an avocado slice, picked cabbage and a yummy sauce.  All the flavors melded really well together.  We can't wait to return!
author: Bebe W.

description:
One of the best dining experiences I've had in SF! Came here for lunch after seeing it on a couple of sites as a must visit in the mission. To start the place is huge, multiple seating areas that can fit a group of any size as well as nice outdoor seating. The decor is amazing, great decorations that make you feel like your at an authentic tex-mex restaurant, and he skylights did it great justice as well bringing in some nice warmth and light. I was already impressed before I even saw the menu.
We started off with some chunky guac and a pitcher of sangria. The guac was phenomenal, great flavor, and a chunks of peppers as well to give it that kick. The sangria was on another level. It came in a chilled vase and was a good size as well giving my gf and I 4 glasses each. It had a different taste to it, bit of cinnamon and other spices, my gf said it even reminded her of an got horchata. I decided to go with the Cuban sandwich for my meal. Wow is the best way to describe it. The pork was so tender it melted in my mouth, flavor packed and savory. The bread was also great toasted to perfection to give it a nice crunch.  And on top of everything being on point the waitress and staff are so good, personable and smiling the entire time, their attentiveness was very appreciated. I highly recommend this place, you gotta give the sangria a try!
author: Josue V.

description: Dios Mio! Best Tex-Mex I've had in a long time. Their hit sauce is SERIOUS. Amazing burger. Good vibe. Gotta love a place that features a rattlesnake over the urinals.
author: Keith R.

description:
3.5 stars

I'm from Texas so first of all, let me say that I don't really think this is Tex Mex. Tex Mex restaurant would never have fried chicken on the menu!

But maybe Southwestern? Anyway, I really liked the decor. Very appropriate. The wood tables and chair also went well with the theme. We did get reservations for Friday evening and prob a good idea since there was quite a crowd.

Their cocktails were very good:
-Pecos margarita
-Sangre (margarita/sangria)
-Devils Tooth (bourbon my fave!)
-Rodeo Ghost (mezcal)

Food:
-Queso and chips (with chorizo.. very good!)
-Pork belly and egg flatbread (this was ok but unique)
-Brown Sugar Buttermilk fried chicken (very good. It's actually half of cornish hen which I've never had, but tasted just like chicken)
-Chile Relleno (this was ok)

I enjoyed my experience but hubby was less enthused. The service was slow also. I found myself waiting quite a while for drinks/food. But not too terrible. 
Other than that, it's not a bad place.
author: Vol T.

description: Probably the best fried chicken I have ever had--- with churros!!!!!! And the puffy tacos were amazing
author: Chelsea O.

description:
I'm not sure what exactly lies geographically West of Pecos but I'm guessing it involves tequila and dressed-up Tex-Mex. I'm not sure why I have this intuition, but it may have something to do with the cocktails and food I had at this restaurant. 

We ambled in here with a group of seven or so, and parked it in the bar. The atmosphere has that Tex-y Mex-y vibe with plenty of wood and metal. The staff is super friendly and on-point.
