The cocktail list is... interesting. Whatever you do, don't get the Black Rose. It's a Fernet drink gone terribly wrong. But the other drinks I tried here were good. Good enough, at least. They do have Mexican Fernet, which I give them props for. 

The food here is decently tasty. I scored a chile relleno plate which was a decently tasty take on this Mexi-classic. The chili seems to be the thing they push as a house special, and it's paleo-riffic. If you want a bowl full of spicy meat, this will do you right. 

While they didn't split up the check for our group, everything else about our experience there was up to par. I'd definitely roll in again for a quick, easy, tasty, Tex-y meal.
author: Don B.

description: A great place for happy hour until 6:30. They have good spicy margaritas and the puffy tacos are to die for. Definitely recommend for a happy hour with friends and coworkers. :)
author: Erin D.

description:
I do not eat meat, so I ordered the Kale Tostadas which were amazing! Also ordered the Maple Brussels Sprouts and felt worried that they would be too sweet because of the maple... but nope, they were divine! (I could not stop eating them.)
Cannot wait to go back to try the Butternut Squash Enchiladas. 
I've also heard for weekend brunch that they serve Huevos Rancheros! Yum!

 Parking is tough, but do take a peek at their menu- definitely worth a try!
author: L S.

description: Had a really good experience at the bar.  Food was delicious, the margarita was great (and I'm supper picky about margaritas) and Pedro (the bartender) was super attentive.
author: R X.

description: Got the braised chicken enchiladas and a Michelada and it was good, but nothing special. It's just one of those places that is good to eat once in a while, but if I have friends from out of town visit, this won't be on my list of places to tour with them. I do have to say that the mashed corn they had on the side was delicious! Other than that, one of those places that looks great and the ambiance is great, but the food is okay.
author: Mayra E.

description: Sooo good!  This place is great.  Great margs.  Great guac. Great tacos.  Great churros (don't tell my trainer).  Great service!
author: Corey H.

description: Great for vegetarians, for latinos a delicious habanero sauce!! Great service!! Love my chile relleno and my spicy Mac and cheese. Great mezcal or tequila's selection!!
author: Arturo R.

description:
3.5 Overall Stars - 2 stars for food, and 5 stars for drinks. 

West of Pecos claims to serve family-style, sharable dishes when in reality, sharing is difficult for most items. The menu contains interesting sounding, modernized Tex-Mex dishes which fall short in the areas of execution, flavor, and quality of ingredients. 

Of all the things I tried, the only thing I would actually pay for again are things with pork shoulder and the mac n cheese. Come for the drinks (happy hour M-F), not for the food.

FOOD 
* GREEN CHILE MAC N CHEESE ($6): This was good, but didn't really taste special. It was probably one of the better things we ordered, good value, and a good side to share.

* BRAISED PORK SHOULDER ($11): Tasty, flavorful, and fork tender. I would get this again although the portion was very small. 

* GRILLED CORN ($8): $8 for 1 cob of corn? Wow, that just seems kind of ridiculous. Plus, the corn was not particularly fresh, very heavily covered in honey, so it tasted a bit rubbery and artificial. 

* ANCHO AND APRICOT PORK RIBS ($16): Good flavor, but kind of tough.

* FLAT IRON STEAK ($19): Really tasty! Unfortunately, it was also too chewy.

* MARGARET's PORKCHOP ($17): Unevenly cooked, very dry at parts, unmemorable, a bit small, and pales in comparison to Nopa or Seven Hills.

* WOODHOUSE GRILLED ARTICHOKE ($17): Typically, I am not a big artichoke fan and didn't like anything about this dish. I thought this was boring, overpriced, needed sauce or flavor, and fresher seafood.

DRINKS: (5-6:30PM HAPPY HOUR)
* MEZCAL MULE ($9): Smoky and comes in a cute little camping style cup!

* PRICKLY PECOS MARGARITA ($9): Spicy, fruity, you can't go wrong. Similar to drinks at Cantina - I could drink this all day :)
author: Jess C.

description:
#49

Great place to have brunch in the heart of Mission District. Had a fritatta for the first time. And had it with crab to boot! DELICIOUS! Very meaty it was! 

My poor friend was hung over and though he said his breakfast of scrambled eggs, two sausage links and potatoes were tasty, he did not look like he was in the mood to be up and out of his bed!

So you can guess by now my buddy did not have an alcoholic beverage, and being the bloody mary lover that I am, I of course opted for this.

Sounds pretty perfect? ALMOST. I unfortunately had a piece of hair in my frittata :(. BUT how they handled it was exactly how every establishment that makes these kind of accidents should handle it. Brought me out a new order and compted me my bloody mary. Chef came out to apologize and everything for the rest of the meal was forgotten! 

Enjoyed my brunch here and though there seemed to be a plethora of choices along this strip, I'd come back here. 

Thanks Pecos!
author: Mari A.

description: We had a great time.    Loved the New Mexican style food. Great ambiance outside with our own beehive fireplace.   We'll be going back.  The Christmas Huevos Rancheros were good and the carnitas puffy taco was amazing.  The chile con queso with chips was a great way to start.   All in all a great place for brunch
author: Bob B.

description:
I went there for brunch and had the best artichoke dish ever. Woodhouse Grilled Artichoke with dungeness crab and shrimps was incredible!!
The service was great too. I would love to go back for dinner and try some drinks.
author: Fumie N.

description:
The drinks here are amazing... I'll come back to this place again just for the service...

We came here a few months ago for a friends bday... made reservations, came there on time... they didn't have our table ready, so we had a few more drinks... 30 minutes passed by and there seems to be some sort of confusion, the host realized and gave us chips and dips... maybe another 15 mins before we got our table... I dont think anyone minded the wait cause did I mention the drinks are amazing?... I like places that realizes their mistakes and can apologize... I've been to some crappy places like Gracias Madre and Kabuto and boy does the service here rock!
author: Nathan D.

description:
I can't remember the last time I moaned "Oh my god" like that...well, with my best friend, and in a public place, anyway.

Oh, my, god! The grilled artichokes stuffed with shrimp and crab were absolutely incredible. I'm surprised Ms. Alyssa V. and I didn't get kicked out for our lavish display of food affection.
author: Katie B.

description:
Good place to come when wanting a change of genre in the Mission. The decor makes you feel as you were in Texas. Nice plave with great customer service. 

I order a moscow mule and the drink was made perfect. We then order apps of guacamole, cornbread, queso dip and prawns wrapped in bacon. The prawns were the best app by far! Very flavorful and simple.

We ordered fried chicken and fish tacos for our entres. The fried chicken was very good along with the mashed potatoes. I would order that again. The fish tacos were good, but there was too much cabbage for me. It would of been nice to have some diced onions or tomatoes in there to add to the flavor.

Overall, great place for a drink and/or food as they have a decent size bar as well. Will definately come back!
author: Satish P.

description:
They put avocado in basically every dish...no way you can go wrong with that.

Drinks, service, food, vibe are all fantastic. This place is budget friendly too. Been here a few times already, and definitely see myself going back again.
author: Yukti G.

description:
It's quite busy here on a Friday night!

 After we left Speakeasy, we needed to get our noms on. The original idea was to order a couple of appetizers for the table. You know how they say, "Don't go grocery shopping when you're hungry?". It should be, "Don't let a hungry yelper order, particularly if you are staying within a budget." 

The Mac and cheese is perfectly cheesy with a slight heat and a nice baked crust.

The pork belly was grilled to perfection and balanced the brussel sprouts well. Jalapeños add a kick to this savory dish. 

The roasted pear salad was OK, but then I'm not a big salad person. The brown sugar fried chicken was moist and had a great subtle sweetness that made it more than finger licken good!

Ribs and baked beans and slaw. Who can mess up this Texan dish?

The bar and wait staff were friendly even in a packed house. They even graciously took 7 cards at checkout! Not many places would take the time to do that. 

Service was great. Food was great. Drinks were great.
Only downside? Finding parking nearby.
author: Anny P.

description: Went for dinner & drinks with my friend.  Great atmosphere and wine.  Happy Hour apps were good.   A solid place for meeting up and hanging out.
author: Kim P.

description: This place is pretty good. Staff is friendly and the food came quickly. Ordered the green chili Mac and cheese and the green chili burger with onion rings, bacon and avocado added. Burger was super juicy and delicious and the Mac and cheese was tasty. :) I'd come back if I'm in the area.
author: Alicia M.

description:
There are opportunities to make or break a customers day and they will remember both. 

The staff at West of Pecos went above and beyond "good service" and showed genuine commitment to being exceptional. 

Thank you for your efforts.
author: Jared W.

description:
With so many great eats in the Mission, West of Pecos definitely lived up to my expectations for a delicious meal. Friends and I had dinner there on a busy Saturday evening. As usual, the Mission was lively (although that made for difficult parking). Thanks to our friends who had made reservations though!

WOP has a great wood decor with dim lighting and an open kitchen. It was pretty packed with people both in the main dining room and on the bar side. They even have two tables outside the giant double doors that are next to mini fireplaces and have heat lamps overhead. 

There's a nice cocktail menu for those who like their spirits and libations. I'm not a tequila girl and bourbon isn't too much up my alley, so I went with the Goldrush which had sparkling wine in it. Liked very much and probably could have had a few more of those, but behaved myself. 

Our group started off with some queso and chips. Just something to snack on before dinner....good for what it was. For the main event, I went with the Lavender & Chipotle Duck Breast. The duck was plentiful and cooked perfectly. The lavender flavor was very unique and I'm pretty much a fan of floral accents so it was a hit for me. The duck was also accompanied by a warm arugula salad candied pecans. Yum-o! Bf got the Flat Iron Steak. It was cooked exactly as he ordered it. That came with a stack of onion rings. The onion rings were thinly sliced with just enough batter. Another friend ordered the same. All the plates had great presentation and on point with the flavors. Great meal over all!
author: Liv A.

description: Came here for a late dinner and got fish tacos. Visually they were very appealing. However, my limes were dried out when I got them. The tacos were a bit sour with the sauce that they used. The green chili mac and cheese was really good though. The service was good. Wait staff was kind and when I asked if we could switch tables to avoid the draft coming through the door they were absolutely happy to do so.
author: Julie L.

description:
3/29/13 Dinner

Food 2*, Service was attentive and friendly so overall 3*
Kitschy, rustic Texas decor is interesting. Seated promptly for 7pm reservation. Surprised they don't give you chips and salsa here, maybe that's not Southwestern style? Anyway, poring through the menu nothing from the starters appealed to us. I love avocado but am not sure about "pea tendril"; nor am I sure about "blistered chili" salad. Jumbo Gulf prawns sound good but why wrapped in bacon?

Skipped starters and dived right into mains:

*Margaret's Pork Chop: very thick cut, about 1", tender and juicy although the meat itself is tasteless. The Arkansas applesauce is tasty and that was what made the pork good. Not crazy about the turnips that had a plastic taste. Baby carrots were roasted.

*Cast Iron Burger: the beef patty is thick and cooked medium rare but a bit dry. The cheddar cheese didn't look or taste like cheddar. Came with greens and french fries. Mayonnaise was deceptive--it's so much more spicy than it looked.

Then we realized guacamole and chips was listed under "Sides" at the lower right -hand corner of the menu. Too late. That was the quickest meal we've had. No alcohol and dessert. The food is just not my cup of tea. Might come back for drinks, but not sit-in.
author: Matt Y.

description: I've been to the bar here twice now and the chips and guacamole is my go to. It's simply amazing. The taco's are also a favorite, you really can't go wrong. The cornbread is amazing. Definitely pop in here if you are walking by!
author: Lisa S.

description: I visited here with a group of ten people for my friends birthday. We booked at table for 8pm, it's 9:15pm and we are yet to be seated. The servers have been extremely passive aggressive when enquiring about our table, they have let the previous table sit and continue drinking after they had finished their meal, despite us standing at the bar and constantly asking about when we can sit down. We have been told 'it might be a while' so here we are, starving and safe to say my good friend is not having the best birthday. TERRIBLE customer service, they should have told us that they couldn't take our reservation so we could go elsewhere. We are now searching for a place in the mission to eat....in the rain. Please take my advice. DON'T GO HERE
author: Lucy M.

description:
I love this place! It honestly doesn't get enough hype. The bartenders here are the best. They replace any drinks I don't like and are always willing to try alter the recipe to something more my style. 

Things to try:
Agua fresca and make your own lemonade 
Guacamole 
Mac n cheese
author: Tulsi M.

description: Had the fried chicken and churros on New Year's Day and am still recovering from awful food poisoning I got from the chicken--5 days later. I could tell as I ate it that it wasn't fully cooked, or was bad. Careful with food handling!
author: Cindy P.

description:
Came here for an event and Tyler (owner) was so accommodating and amazing.  The food was off the hook - from the sangria to the margaritas to the guacamole to the duck tacos to the pork tacos to the puffy tacos with shashito peppers!   

Great service and great food.
author: Matt T.

description:
Arrived around 7:30pm on a Monday w no reservation and was seated immediately. 

Ambiance: Lighting was kind of dim. The only thing that stood out to me was the huge skull on the wall and the cute fireplace tables outside. 

Server: Really nice and checked up on us a few times. 

-Crumbled Goat Cheese & Beet- Probably the best thing I had here. I don't think you can really screw this up. And, I love beets. 

-Green Chile Mac & Cheese- Good. Had a bit of a spicy hint, but not spicy at all. Would be 10x better if it had more of a crusty bread crumb top. 

-Brussel Sprouts & Bacon- Okay. Nothing extraordinary, but went well with the Mac & Cheese.

-Crab & Shrimp Stuffed Artichoke- Wasn't that great and the artichoke was really salty. Will not order this again. 

-Flan- Texture was really thick and was served in a slice like pie. I'm not a huge fan of flan so I can't really give an unbiased opinion. But the cream and the cookie served on the side were good. 

-Strawberry & Rhubarb Crumble- Served with goat milk ice cream on top. The crumble crumbs/morsels were amazing!! Too much rhubarb in the crumble and not enough strawberries. Otherwise fantastic.
author: Mae D.

description: West of Pecos is great! I've been several times, and I'm never disappointed. I think it's important to know that the food is NOT Mexican food...it's Tex-Mex. I feel like if you were to go there expecting Mexican food, you would be disappointed. It's different, in a good way! My favorite, guilty treat is the queso & chips appetizer. Last night, we had the corn on the cob and prawn fajitas which were good. I got the sangre del toro cocktail which was sour and not too sweet. We made a reservation for 6 and when everyone got there, they sat us right away. They also accommodated our extra 7th person. They have some booths and regular tables and chairs. They set us at one of the booths which was nice. The staff was friendly and on top of it! Even though our server was busy, the food runners and other staff were hands-on and helped us with everything we needed. The environment was lively and fun! I think this place is great for a date night or for a group!
author: Gina R.

description:
Brunch review! (Because, take note, THEY DO BRUNCH! Apparently that's a recent development, so I'm giving it the all-caps treatment.)

My brother and his new wife invited whoever wanted to join them the morning after their wedding for brunch at this place, and I'm so glad I was able to shake off my hangover enough to make it! 

I think my dish was called Pecos Poached Eggs, and it had poached eggs and pulled pork and tomato on some kind of bread or muffin or something, and was amaaazing. Best possible hangover food, and would totally order it up sans hangover, too. Same goes for the Bloody Mary. So money.

I also scored a few bites of my neighbor's french toast, and it was excellent - thick, just the right texture (soft, with a little crisp around the edges), and flavor to the bread itself, so it was good even without the syrup. It also came with fresh fruit, so every bite got a nice cool pop of freshness.

We had (hung over) people arriving at all different times, and West of Pecos was super nice about accommodating everyone, taking and bringing out orders as people arrived, and letting us keep our party together even when like half the table had already eaten and were just hanging out.

They were a great spot for a big group, but there were lots of people eating there in twos and fours as well, so I feel like I can safely recommend for whatever you've got going on. Also, this was my only time there, but I heard from some other folks at the table that they've also got a great happy hour with well-mixed cocktails and a quality beer list, so I'll be checking that out next time I'm in town!
author: Kristin M.

description:
Rolled in here after Sunday brunch to the bar which was pretty inviting: wide, long, open, clean...not overly crowded.  The drinks were on point but the bartender was a little less excited than I was.  I usually do not get cocktails but I opted for the Pisco Sour and it was delish ... (I had 2).  I ended up seeing people ordering food and every plate looked amazing...that I started getting hungry even after a large meal.  So I ordered the Guac and Chips...oh lord..it was so good.  The guac was so fresh..and I think it pretty much reflected on the quality of the food here.  I will definitely come back for dinner (which I have seen pretty packed).
This is a great bar though to catch the game and the noise level is just right to carry a good conversation with friends.
BTW: the bathroom is super clean, large and semi hi-tech and it really impressed me.
New favorite place on Valencia!
author: Helen C.
Tina F.

description: I liked the venue...western and ten-mexy. Food was ok. I had a burger. My friends had Huevos Rancheros and Cuban Sandwich which they both enjoyed. Blood Mary was different...a bit of Santa Fe touch.  Menu was limited, but you'll find something and have a good time.
author: Daniel G.

description:
I'd previously avoided West of Pecos because I think I must've looked at their menu from when they first opened, and there wasn't really anything to eat -- but I was pleasantly surprised last night! 

Even though it's true that most of their entrees DO have meat, there is a chestnut and squash-stuffed chile relleno entree that was very tasty, and my partner and I made an excellent meal by sharing that along with the brussels sprouts side (possibly the best brussels sprouts I have ever had), the mac 'n cheese (a little spicy for me, but my partner loved it), and the delicious Harvest Salad. They also have roasted pumpkin enchiladas, which I'd like to try in the future. Also, it's not on the menu, but you can request the queso without the chorizo in it, and that's what really got the four stars for me. SO DELICIOUS! I'd actually be happy going there and just ordering my own bowl of queso and chips with one of the delicious strawberry-cucumber-mint agua frescos. Okay, maybe two bowls of queso! 

I also want to note that the reason we were there was for a birthday dinner, and even though we were a large party (maybe 14 people?), we received excellent and friendly service. I'm glad we finally tried this place, and I plan to come back.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
Tried this spot for Brunch in December and loved it! Here's a vegetarian's perspective--

Highlights:
1) Baby Kale Tostadas, surprisingly filling! I don't remember what was in it now, but it was crispy and delicious!
2) I know it's simple but their scrambled eggs are damn good.
3) Jam (w/ biscuits). I like the Jam over whatever sauce they come with. It was so tasty--seemed like the jars sold at farmers markets.
4) Their hot sauce. My friend even bought a bottle.
5) The price! Great value brunch
6) Spacious + outdoor seating with heaters. I want to sit there next time!

Words of warning:
I didn't LOVE the stuffed peppers, but the cheese on them was quite nice.
There's a Michelada drink on the menu that seems cool at first but is actually pretty hard to finish. I recommend sharing before deciding to get your own.

Extra props for selling Thistle juice during the day!!
author: Neeharika B.

description: Loved it! Birthday reservation for 6 at 6:30-  great service, yummy food and drinks, fun and mellow vibe.
author: Cynthia F.

description:
** 4 stars -- except that my two friends' stomachs felt unsettled after our meal **

The guac was really good, though I feel like they could have given us more for an order. 

The veggie scramble was different, and I liked feeling like I was eating healthily despite the veggies being covered in cheese. 

My husband got the ribs, which I also liked the flavor of.

Our waitress was really sweet and just the right amount of attentive.

I liked the decor, and the high ceilings made the space feel not stuffy.

As noted above, I would have given this place more stars, but both my husband and friend separately complained of stomach issues after this meal.
author: Jess L.

description: Atmosphere was typical great Mexican patio dining, but still indoors. We had the chicken and churros, and the fish taco. Both were impeccable. Monster Bloody Mary was yuuuuge but felt a tad watered down. Compensated with a thick slice of bacon. Will be returning shortly.
author: Jake M.

description: My boyfriend and I love this restaurant!  When we first came to San Fran, this restaurant was there to receive us...with guacamole, queso, fajitas, and margaritas.  The guacamole dip was unbelievable, made with real avocado.  The fajitas were sizzled to perfection.  But the best part was...the pitcher of margarita (and the salted rim).  My boyfriend and I are still regulars at this establishment.  I actually almost brought my friend from home there (didn't quite make it, but that's a story for another time.)  Anyways, West of Pecos gets a 10/10 on my rating scale and believe me when I say it was good food....after all, I do only like nice things.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I was truly amazed by this place, considering my mom lives in Santa Fe! Just a few months after visiting her for the first time, it was spectacular getting to try a sopaipilla with chilies hanging from the ceiling right back home in San Francisco!

Their seafood wood-grilled artichokes were to die for, and their grilled brancino with pork belly was also pretty good. Who doesn't love bacon-wrapped prawns?

Not gonna lie, please try out their jalapeño tequila cocktail: their La Flama Blanca! Man, oh, man, it is also tasty!

This was the 1st of 3 great, new places my date and I were adventurous enough to try during this particular weekend. They were all very good, so we must keep being adventurous!
author: Garett T.

description:
How can anyone read the menu in this ultra dim place? Hahaha we had to shove two candles together and it still took a bit to read.

Ordered their green chilé mac and cheese [bit too dry IMO. Needed more cheese], corn on the cob sliced neatly into four pieces slathered with a sweet and tangy brown sauce [must try!], and flautas stuffed with crispy pork belly!! It had green chile sauce sprinkled with feta cheese on top [I think it was feta cheese...remember the dim lighting!] and all other kinds of sauces mixed together. 

....I think I had died and gone to heaven. 

Every time I see any type of mule drink, I have to order it. Mezcal mule is obviously tequila incorporated and since I'm a gin girl, I thought it was mehh.

Best Mexican restaurant ever! Good job West of Pecos!
author: Stephanie S.

description: Not authentic Mexican, but there's no shortage of that to me found in the Mission. But this fresh take with a focus on local ingredients is really very good. At reasonable prices. We've been there twice now on our visits to SF and would recommend it. I love the fish tacos and the crabamole, made with fresh Dungeness crab. My husband digs the lobster enchiladas.
author: Julia S.

description:
Disclaimer: This review is purely for the bar and not actual dinner.

I love the vibe - very laid back yet trendy, casual yet classy and romantic yet airy. 

The drink selection is quite vast and unique - my favorite is the Mezcal Mule (made with fresh lime juice and ginger beer). It's smokey, moderately spicy and sweet - a combo that sounds like a recipe for disaster but is actually quite the opposite. 

And the Queso dip with chorizo is quite possibly one of the best items you could have after a night of drinking-related debauchery. Thus, it's the perfect complement to the Mezcal Mule. The pork carnitas and duck tacos are a close second. 

So the next time, you're on a bar-hopping spree in the Mission or just want a bar to catch up with friends in, consider West of Pecos. 

Happy drinking, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Update on West of Pecos.  BRUNCH, BRUNCH, BRUNCH!

They just started brunch a little bit ago and it's been quite impressive.  First of all, they have a fresh tomato bloody mary with grapefruit juice. A lighter version of the traditional bloody mary that is perfect for rough mornings.

West of Huevos is completely delicious.  Their red chile sauce is so delicious - I find myself mopping it up with anything I can get my hands on!  I also think their new additions of salads to the menu are a perfect compliment.  Lastly, I can't not mention their chorizo sopapilla OR their french toast.
author: Liz B.

description:
This weekend was my second visit and it was just okay. Unfortunately it wasn't as great as the first time.

My husband ordered the Eggs Benny and he liked it very much, I ordered the harvest salad with grilled chicken and it was just okay. In all honestly it was definitely not worth $16.

The butter lettuce with a dash of sweet corn and 1/4 of avocado with a few measly bits of roasted garbanzo beans were $10 and then the dry chicken to top it off was $6.

If I'm going to pay that much for a salad it have better be great and this was subpar. Also the service was not as good as last time. I had asked for some balsamic vinaigrette and it never made it to my table.

Overall my whole experience this time around kinda left me thinking that I'm not sure if I'd make my way back here again. 

In a nutshell this joint is just average all the way around and if I can get better food and service somewhere else then I will.  

For now I'm leaving West of Pecos 3 stars and if I visit again I hope things improve.
author: V W.

description:
We went here with friends and ordered the chips, quest, and Guac which were all delicious. Slightly disappointed in the house margaritas. For $10, you would think we would get more than a tiny glass. 

The tacos were so-so but not great. Would return but only for happy hour.
author: Emily A.

description: Group of 5 with different plates and all were pleased. Friendly service and tasty sangria. Steak for the fajitas a little dry but flavorful. Nice ambience but it was a rainy night and they keep the front doors open which caused the the interior to be cold enough I kept my jacket on through dinner. I would return.
author: Brian M.

description:
Really solid place!! Tasty American Tex-Mex food. The best dish I sampled was the mac n cheese with green chilis. Great twist on an old American favorite.

A+ for the knowledgeably, friendly staff, prime Mission location, and gorgeous decor / interior.
author: Amber K.

description:
Excellent lunch! Weve been several times and we enjoyed the harvest salad, incredible guacamole and delicious fish tacos. The harvest salad is one of our favorites in the City. Husband had the Road Runner margarita and loved it. Especially the ice cube. Sat outside with our pooches. Service was A+

Still craving the salad and guacamole
author: Ottis M.

description:
The only reason this place is receiving a star is because of the waitress who was extremely helpful.

However, the food was utterly atrocious!!!  The chicken mole enchilada was horrible and the fried chicken I ate (more like I sent back) was so charred and dried it was un-edible.  

I will never waste my time in this place ever again.

Hoping that our waitress finds another place to work soon because I have no Idea how long this place will last.

Which goes to show,  "Y" reviews seem to be more and more worthless.  This place has 4 stars... How is this even possible?!?!

So the day after the review, one of the owners reached out to apologize for the bad experience I received.  He wanted me to give them a second chance by offering a gift certificate so I can try them out again.  I thought wow that was extremely thoughtful.  However offering and giving are two separate things.  He said he would immediately pop the certificate in the mail.  I know mail service is slow but I have yet to receive the certificate :p  This is being written weeks later :/
author: Rigs R.

description: This place is great! Ordered the Mac n cheese, artichokes, fried chicken, ribs and burger. We loved everything minus the burger (a bit undercooked). If you have room definitely order the bread pudding!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Thank you Lisa & Pecos grew....
We rented the private room to celebrate my parent's anniversary and everyone loved it.  The food was great (yum, those fish tacos), the drinks were on point, and Lisa and team made the event stress free and pleasurable for all of us.  
To find a location in the city that isn't crazy overly priced for private events and that has a relaxed feel with ample room for guests is hard to find.  Oh, and no "cake cutting" fee allowed us to spend on money enjoying food and drinks at the restaurant instead!
We'll be back for guac, margaritas, and fish tacos :)
author: HR W.

description: This place isn't terrible, but since you're in the Mission, you're far better off choosing a hole-in-the-wall that won't break your wallet. If you do want anything, I recommend the chile rellenos or fish tacos. Both are done really well, but don't expect large portions. For the price you're paying, you get decent food, but not in a high amount. The cocktails are also pretty solid, but again, overpriced and in small quantities. Service is decent, but it could be improved with more servers. The ambiance is really cool though. Think modern Mexican. Overall, very meh. The mezcal mule comes in an awesome cup, though.
author: Danny C.

description:
Not sure what to think about this place.  The food was pretty good, but somehow unsatisfying.  My first thought for this review was "Just ok, like a fancy Chevys, but with worse chips and more than twice as expensive."

But of course this place is in another class than Chevy's and provides a pretty interesting experience over all.  I also want to give them credit for very nice drink program (cocktails were very good, the giant mug of beer was fun too).  Everyone liked their food, but agreed that our food just seemed to lack the vibrant flavors we really craved.

So the reviews and pictures got me interested, but the result was a bit of a let down.  Maybe it's the fact that there is such an enormous amount of really fantastic similar (pan Latin cuisine let's call it broadly) food in the area that makes this pale a bit by comparison.
author: Patrick S.

description: Honestly one of the worst places I have been. If it take 20 mins to get your drink and your queso / apps arrive before the drinks there is something wrong!  Queso came out cold as f! If you want to get tex mex save ur money and buy a ticket to austin!!!!
author: Susan E.

description: Second time in two weeks that I have come to this fun place ...food is always great and the service is impeccable even under pressure and understaffed our server Katie roast the gave 100 cent..The runners and hostess were all super friendly and took care of us even as crowded as the place was... One of my favorite places to go in the mission. The fajitas are delicious the maple glazed brussels sprouts are to die!!! Ask for Katy she's amazing...
author: Roberto R.

description: Great restaurant for Tex Mex food, good drinks, and fun vibe. Go here with my friends often because it is reliable, casual, and fun. The owner, Tyler, is always there and one of the nicest/coolest guys in San Francisco.
author: Hamrez S.

description: Came here for brunch and it was fantastic. I had a Frozen Margarita and the Hash with a over easy egg. It was so good I will be scared to order anything else in fear of not liking it as much as the hash. The other people I was with had the huevos rancheros and they were almost as good as the hash but that is tough to beat. If you like huevos you gotta try it.
author: Kyle F.

description:
Was really looking forward to trying this place since I grew up in Texas, but ended up being rather disappointed.  Came here with a friend who also grew up in Texas, and my girlfriend who lived there as a child, and we all agreed that while the concept of each dish was spot on, the execution just wasn't there.  Like so many other places in San Francisco, the flavors are far too muted and bland.  Items that should have been spicy weren't, and I can't count how many times the word "bland" was used during our dinner.  The queso was also watery and pales in comparison to the queso at Tacolicious which is much more authentic.  

If you own this place and are reading this, I really dig what you're going for here.  Good Texan and southwestern cuisine are really needed in San Francisco.  I also know that if you properly season/spice food in this town, you'll have more than a few complaints from locals who insist on everything being bland.  That being said, take a cue from Mission Chinese Food and actually start seasoning your food the way it's meant to be seasoned.  Sure, you will get a few complaints, but you'll also acquire a devoted group of customers who grew up with these flavors and miss them.
author: Joshua W.

description:
OMG. Every single day since we ate at WoP I have been craving their skillet cornbread with chili butter. I feel like I NEED it more than I need lots of other things in my life. 

We were waiting on our table at Puerto Allegre (which I love), but I was super hungry and WoP had a shorter wait list so we decided to give it a go. At first, the menu seemed small and my boyfriend didn't see anything he really wanted. However, we ordered a bunch of different options AND all of it was so damn good it  was ridiculous. I wanted there to be endless corn bread. I kept hoping more would just appear...In fact, as I'm typing this I'm thinking I need to drive up there and get some.

The service was great, our waitress was really fun and sweet and had great recommendations. My drinks were strong and I felt that overall the price of the meal was good compared to many other places we've been.

I felt a little bit bad about cheating on Puerto Allegre but I was super starving and West of Pecos was there to comfort me. 

We'll definitely be back (to get cornbread!) for dinner really soon. :)
author: Melisa B.

description:
(See pics) Review #1196. Very solid 4+ stars for the food and drink, super friendly and prompt service. And definitely with a Mission / southern feel.

This place definitely has a good hot kick of each and every dish and drink.

Opening night the full menu was pretty impressive, from cocktails of tequila, Mezcal and Whiskey to liquors just on their own, to beers, and flip over the page you will find a good list of wines. Definitely a taste of Mission style drinks and I had the Pecos Margarita which was quite good with strong alcohol without being too sugary.

The appetizer griddled goat cheese (circular cake look) with arugula, sun dried tomatoes and dried pear was vibrant looking and a good starter and not too strong cheese taste.

The lamb albondigas (meatball style) was with chorizo, spicy tomato and green chile broth and corn. It had some fiery hot taste to the broth. The light broth texture (rich taste) was not something I have seen too often. The flavors were bursting and solid full.

It is not a full meal until you have desserts. They have one and only 1 dessert for the opening evening - the 3 scopes of different ice cream tastes from Tara's in Berkeley. The sweet corn was with great corn chewy; the lavender was floral but not overwhelming. But my favorite was the chipotle chocolate. O-M-G it had the best kick on the tongue. The dish accompanied with 3 house made cookies too. They served (only) dripped Peets coffee.

While it took over 30 mins to get the appetizer then another 10 for main course on their first quite packed evening, the service was excellent as the server kept coming by checking on the drinks and water. As soon as I finished the appetizer and they took the utensils away, they were immediately replaced with another set. This very seasoned without stress looking service easily earned an applause.

They currently opened about half of the restaurant and in a couple weeks will have the other half open mostly for larger and / or private parties. The bar area features big comfy seats while the main dining area can easily put tables together and welcomes bigger groups.

This place fits right in the Mission and perfectly on trendy Valencia with its colorful and up a notch of deliciousness without breaking the wallet.
author: T L.

description: I set up reservations through my yelp mobile app, arrived a few minutes early, but was still seated right away. The servers were great, the food even better. Didn't get charged for the coffee I ordered which was awesome, so I left a big tip. Definitely can't wait to go back and would recommend people to check it out.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Ended up here when tacolicious had a 2 hour wait, and SO HAPPY I did!! Margarita pitchers and queso with chorizo are a great start taco Tuesday. My friends and I were impressed with the service and the food. The food isn't your typical tacos and burritos, but was amazing! The chile relleno was to die for- I barely got any because my friends couldn't stop stealing bites.
I will definitely be back to make this my go-to taco Tuesday spot.
author: Lauren J.

description:
After walking through the swinging saloon doors you feel right at home.  That is, if your home is a refined yet lawless old-western restaurant with sink-right-in leather stools.

You're greeted by one friendly staff member after the next.  And they all bring you exciting treasures - giant frosted margaritas (must use two hands), Mezcal Mules in silver cups, the best corn bread & molasses of your life, potatoes and chorizo queso dip, tangy amazing ribs, carnitas in hand made tortillas, stuffed peppers, all topped off with chipotle chocolate ice cream.

The menu is unique - like nothing I've seen before.  A MUST TRY. Think smoky BBQ meats, grilled veggies, and a hint of sweet peppers.  Great for a group of friends who want to order one of everything tapas style. And rounds of frosty drinks.

I've found my new watering hole.
author: Melinda C.

description: My favorite spot in SF.  Great food, great bar, great atmosphere.  Seriously good margaritas and I also love the lobster enchiladas.  Located right in the heart of the mission district on Valencia.  Also, they have rattlesnake skins in the bathroom.  What more can you ask for?
author: Braxton W.

description:
I use to hate on West of Pecos - but I was wrong. Place is halfway decent yet overpriced.

They've definitely thought about their 'brand' from decor, to menu design, it's all consistent and doesn't feel to gimmicky. 

We had brunch on a Saturday and didn't have to wait at all. The staff was kind and friendly. We both had Bloody Marys (options of tequila, vodka and mezcal) which were standard, not as thick as we like them, nor as strong. The boyfriend really enjoys mezcal bloodys so this was a major selling point for him. 

Food was tasty too. We had the pork belly breakfast tacos - they we're great. It's hard to go wrong with pork belly. Ask for the their hot sauce, it kicks the flavor up a notch. Also got the crab toastados, fish tasted fresh and not at all "crabby".

The major downside here is how small the portions were. We spent about $50, which isn't awful, but we did leave hungry and left in search of bar bites around the block.
author: Sarah B.

description:
My chef buddy brought me here to try the tortilla wrapped burger.

We sat at the bar and the bartender was very courteous and easy going. He handed us the menus and we went straight for the burger.

The key to the burger is the roasted green chiles which give it tons of flavor. The burger itself was juicy and the fries that came with it were moist and crispy on the outside.

Looking forward to trying the rest of the menu.
author: Art O.

description: Really yummy dishes, although the green chile enchilada was too heavily drenched in sauce for my liking.  The guacamole was chunkily excellent!  And the margaritas helped all the heaviness go down.
author: Rick W.

description:
The hostesses at West of Pecos are top notch! We always feel welcomed and taken care of as soon as we get there. 

The food of course is also amazing and they have a good amount of vegetarian options. I never leave feeling hungry and in that note, I never leave feeling sober either :)

Bonus - They are dog friendly and they have a cute little fireplace in the front in case it gets cold out!
author: Kitty K.

description: No negatives about this place. Staff was friendly. I love that they do brunch until 3pm so I had the coffee rubbed brisket with over easy eggs and potatoes - the combo was really good. I didn't look too much at the drink menu and stuck with Corona but I did see some giant draft beers being poured. When you get your check that the bar, they bring you a shot of frozen margarita which hit the spot on the way out.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Two days after Christmas one of my best friends and I decided to get together, do our gift exchange, and pig out. Given that San Francisco is nearly desolate during the holidays, we decided to venture into the Mission and see where we could land without a wait on a Saturday night...when typically we'd face a wait. West of Pecos it was!

First of all- props to a restaurant going all out when it comes to decor. The vibe here is entirely Southwestern...not an inch looks out of place! I love the entrance and the tables with little fire pits. Dibs on that spot next time I come! (Provided its no longer freezing!)

We ordered:

1) Chunky Quac- as an avid lover of Guac...this one takes a step away from the norm. While I'm all for chunks of avocado, the whole baby tomatillos and strips of onion were a little much for me. The chips though? Amazeballs! What is that seasoning???

2) Pitcher of Margaritas...I now have 3 go-to Margarita places in the city. Velvet Cantina, Tacolicious, and West of Pecos. I'll need to do a side by side taste comparison to stack rank them...but we found ourselves another winner.

3) DONT DO THIS. DONT ORDER THE HARVEST SALAD. I really wanted the green chile and pork enchiladas and got all calorie conscious. (Dude- I already downed a basket of chips, guac, and half a pitcher of margaritas...not the time to get smart.) Follow your heart! Follow your stomach! ORDER THE DAMNED ENCHILADAS.

I would absolutely come back to West of Pecos...and this time, order what I want!
author: Annalise F.

description: We came here with a group of friends for our monthly dinner club.  We were so excited to check it out because we had been reading amazing things but unfortunately it was just ok.  Our waitress was a bit forgetful and the food was good but not great.  I forgot the beer that I ordered but it was in a massive chilled glass which made everyone at the table jealous and it was really good.  I think we pretty much ordered almost everything off the menu too.  Our favorites were the Maine Lobster enchilada, queso fondito and pork trio.
author: Blake B.

description:
When I saw the menu and the people and the decor, I thought, Two stars all the way.  No way it's going up.  No way.

So I perused and was annoyed and ordered and wondered how many identical twins of one of my most annoying supervisors could work in the same place.  The answer:  Three.

But a funny thing happened on the way to my proprietary, super-secret way of deciding which business to Yelp next:  I had a heart.  No, having a heart isn't like sleeping with someone because you feel sorry for her, and no, I've never done that, and any person who has done that should be ashamed of herself--and yes, it's usually shes who do this and then wonder why poor guys they feel sorry for can't get the hint.  Having a heart in this case means being generous in the truest, noblest sense of that word.

Normally, it would annoy me that a place in San Francisco doesn't have many vegetarian options, but this time, I sucked it up and ordered one of the two (or maybe there was only one), and it was good.  Not delicious, but very good.  So West of Pecos is solid in an underwhelming way.

And although they looked like the infamous JBL, all of his twins were very kind and not passive-aggressively so, the way the real JBL was and most definitely still is.  Unless he had a life-changing experience.  Or maybe he went back to Russia.  But if he did go back to Russia, I'm sure the returning JBL would be twice as intolerable, because if there's one thing about JBL, it's that he likes to make it seem as if his myriad experiences are unique.  They may very well be unique, but he talks as if he's the only person who has ever been interested in anything, and while he is interested, he's not committed, and that's sad.  If you're good at a lot of things, you're usually not very good at anything.  I think that sums up West of Pecos, but the people are nice.

It's too cold in here, and the seating is arranged in a weird way.  You always see your server, but it's usually pretty difficult (because of the physical layout of the tables) to get his attention.  The old sheriff's badges are cool.
author: John S.

description: Everything was good; but, particularly the Sopapillas -- a little bit too thick, but other than that, the best I've had outside of New Mexico!
author: John W.

description: My friend and I wanted happy hour and decided to go to the mission district.  We parked without a destination in mind and decided that we would walk around and stumble into a place.  We came across west of pecos and it was literally 6:25PM and the sign said that hh ended at 6:30!  Got seated in the bar area right away and the hostess was super nice and quickly took down our orders cause she knew that we only had 5 minutes to spare.  We ordered a total of 4 margaritas, 4 tacos (duck and pork), and guacamole.  ALL WERE DELISH.  When the server came back with our margaritas she said "good luck" which then made me ask  "why are these really strong?"  She replied saying "they are real margaritas."  My friend and I can drink quite a bit so 2 margaritas each was a good buzz, nothing too crazy.  The servers are very sweet and attentive.  I think the only annoying thing about this place is that they have a lot of fruit flies flying around.  GREAT HH PRICES.
author: Mauricia L.

description:
I ended up here for dinner shortly after my last review of the bar.

After finding out that Little Baobob was not serving dinner (I had a coworker recommend their food, but when we stopped by the bouncer told us they weren't serving dinner....very confused) we came back to West of Pecos to give their menu a try. We shared the crispy crudo tacos and I also order the lobster enchiladas. The tacos were good, nothing fantastic. The enchiladas were packed with lobster - impressive - and the poblano cream sauce was also very tasty, but there was too much salt overall. I do prefer less salt than the average American, so maybe this dish will appeal more to others as is.

Today I told my coworker that I went to West of Pecos and we started talking about their cocktails. She told me that "sal de gusano" is salt made from worms. WTF! The Roadrunner cocktail I ordered the previous time I was here boasts "sal de gusano" on the rim. So just a WARNING to everyone. But now I can say in all honesty that I've eaten worms....and liked it.

One last thing, at dinner last night I had the Devil's Tooth cocktail and it was just as utterly delicious as I remembered. So I would recommend giving this one a try....over the worm drink.
author: Lindsey B.

description: The waitress was lovely but the food was inedible. One mouthful and I had to send it back as did my dinner partner. They did refund the cost of our meal  though .
author: Caroline C.

description:
The food and drinks here are excellent. Whereas most mission establishments have a long line, I never have to wait more than 10 minutes here.

As a vegetarian, I really like all of their options. The huevos rancheros is good, and their stuffed peppers are really tasty. Good service - I've been here probably 5 times in the past year.
author: Steven H.

description: Usually not a huge texmex fan but I was pleasantly surprised by their small plates - cornbread,  brussel sprouts and creamed corn! The puffed tacos were okay - the carnitas was dense and hard to get through. Would come back to try more small plates!
author: Sandi T.

description:
We came here for taco tuesday expecting it to be a full house in the Mission. That was our first mistake, it was easy to get a table since it was so empty. It should not be this easy to get a table at a Mexican restaurant in the Mission! We decided on a seat at the bar, which are probably the smallest bar tables ever. But our waiter was on top of things and got in our drink orders for sangria pretty quick. The sangria was very ok, nothing to write home about. 
We started with the guacamole which was really good! Small portion though, just enough for two to split. We also ordered two tacos each and I got the beef brisket and carnitas. These were probably the greasiest tacos I've had. They kept dripping everywhere and were extremely messy to eat. The grease was overkill. It also took our waiter a while to come clear our plates and get us more sangria, so things were just piling up on our tiny bar table. Gave it a try, but safe to say I will not be returning.
author: Alisha K.

description: My second time coming here, my high expectations were met. Great tacos (especially the carnitas and brisket); above average bartenders and cocktails; nice atmosphere both during busy Friday night and chill Saturday afternoon; good host and waiter; and good bathroom though lighting could be better (according to my other half). Let me reemphasiZe that the cocktails are outstanding. Only the guacamole was disappointing, so don't get that.
author: Nix A.

description: The drinks and ambience were great. The bartender, however, was oddly rude. I asked for a cocktail to be made with a certain type of gin and he treated me with such attitude. I don't understand why he was so rude but it tainted our experience and we left earlier than expected because we didn't want to be served by someone so rude.
author: Kay E.

description: Made it in during Happy Hour and the $2.50 tacos were delicious.  Our "Devil's Tooth" cocktails were excellent.  It's not Mexican, more like "Tex Mex," but still very good.
author: Amanda D.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat in the Mission.  Solid menu, great drinks and excellent service. The food is quick, consistent and priced really well. Bacon wrapped shrimp, mac n' cheese and cornbread with a few shakes of their habanero hot sauce are always a good start. Throw some crispy brussel sprouts in there for a little green and you'll be just fine.  

Eat here, you'll like it.
author: Edmond A.

description: Used to love coming here for margaritas and finger food until last time I was with a girlfriend. We asked the hostess if we needed to put ourselves on the list for a table if we wanted to sit in the bar area for a bite and a couple of drinks even though we had been there many times and just went straight to the bar area. It seemed to be a little busier than usual. She said we didn't, it was first come first serve and even handed us a menu to start looking at it while we waited for an open table. Once we spotted one and sat down the bartender came and told us we needed to move because all tables were reserved for people on the waiting list.  Went back to the hostess and she literally walked away from us as we approached. She then started taking to another staff member while we were waiting at the hostess podium. We decided to leave and go down the street to Tacolicious.  Had a great time there and never coming back to this place.
author: Paula A.

description:
I don't see why this place gets people so rustled, but I think I went into it as "going to classy, hipster El Torito" so my expectations were met AND raised! If you want good Tex Mex don't' settle for Chevy's when you could be here.

The ambiance is super Texas-y and southwestern; I loved the lights in the chili bunches and the big cow skull. I remember saying I liked every song that came on the radio (alt/rock, some Foo Fighters, Arctic Monkeys, Cold War Kids) so that's a HUGE plus.

We got the corn on the cob and mac and cheese to share, the BF got the burger and I got the kale tostadas. I'm not really a fan of kale but this was baby kale, which actually makes a difference I guess! It tasted more like arugula and it mshed well with the rest of the tostada. The mac and cheese was milder than I expected, and the corn satisfied my craving for grilled corn (om nom chili butter.) My bf got a little sick the night after we went, but I think it's because he has a weak stomach sometimes with spicy stuff :S  He enjoyed the burger, although was perplexed by the bun. It was sort of like a pupusa with no filing? Interesting texture though.

I would defeinitely go back for a happy hour if given the chance!
author: Raven P.

description: I love the tacos here! The chips and guac are so good! If you come here for the first time you have to try the puffy tacos they're so yummy! The margaritas are delicious as well. I try and come here once a month at least.
author: Nicholas F.

description: I have known this place for 3 years now and every visit has been a light. The food is great (especially the guacamole, the grilled chicken salad and their ceviche) and the service is super friendly. I also like the interior design which is very fitting to the food.
author: Sam N.

description: Such good food.  I've been here probably 4 times and I'm just bummed I hadn't come earlier.  I've been missing out.  The food here is so good.  Breakfast, Brunch, Lunch, Dinner, everything.  I'd recommend something, but you honestly can't go wrong.
author: Jacob A.

description: We had a good time sitting by the bar on a Sunday afternoon. It's quite crowded usually.
author: Tracy D.

description: Bastardization of Hispanic culture. The decor of this place, in the center of a neighborhood that has had its heritage raped by rich white kids, is offensive at best and genocidal at worst. The bread pudding was good but coated in the blood and sweat of the millions of Mexicans who have either died for their land or now toil in modern indentured servitude for Americans, it better.
author: Tyler R.

description:
Ate here on a whim one night and everything was delicious.

It's funny how no longer living in Texas gives you such a deep appreciation for Shiner. And chips and salsa! Their salsa is good, and all the apps/entrees we ordered were happily devoured. Would gladly return, though I think the vegetarian options are on the smaller side.
author: Megan S.

description:
This is the worst place I've eaten at in the Mission, on a quality/value scale.

Maybe even the worst place I've eaten at in the Mission, period.

The ribs taste like they boiled the cheapest pork they could find then slathered it with sticky sweet sauce so no one would notice. 

Almost everything else we had was poorly executed or over-ingrediented.

The best thing was the bottled beer.

This seems like a Southwest themed restaurant more likely to have been found in the Marina or Union street in the mid 1980s. Or Disneyland.

People whined when the Mission got "gentrified" with double-digit appetizers and artisan whatev, but I welcome every Tartine and Delfina along side my cheap taquerias because they bring quality and variety. This place brings neither.
author: Brian C.

description:
Had dinner last night at West of Pecos and it was delicious. We had the fish tacos, which were very tasty and the fajitas, which were even better. The beers are extra large here and it's a great atmosphere to hangout.
Would definitely recommend!
author: Taleen S.

description: Great ambience, awesome drink menu, good chips & guacamole, and friendly service! Came here to kill time before dinner, so we got a few drinks and some snacks. I would definitely come back to try their other food. It's a fun spot!
author: Kirby P.

description: So so good! I came here for a dinner with a couple of girlfriends and was pleasantly happy! We ordered the roadrunner margarita which was a balance of smokey and sweet with every sip! The guacamole was fresh and great (chips not so good kind of stale.) We also ordered the pillowy dough appetizer dipped in honey - holy shit duck fat is amazing! My fried chicken sandwich was sooooo fufilling and I love every bite. I'm scared to come back because it probably won't be as perfect as this time! Highly recommend for a dinner with friends with a great ambiance and super yummy dinner.
author: Juliana O.

description:
West of Pecos is consistently solid. I've been here for brunch and dinner and each meal has been on point. Highlights for brunch include the Huevos Rancheros, Polenta con Chorizo and a fav of mine The Pork Belly Tacos.

On the dinner side of things the lobster enchiladas are really good as well as any of the tostadas. As for the meats the fish tacos, New York steak and burger are all choice!
author: Mike P.

description: Our friends took us here and we loved the food. We just moved to the Bay Area and had yet to find a good Mexican restaurant. I had the braised chicken enchilada and it was so yummy. You won't be disappointed.
author: Kara F.

description: Fluffy tacos are great. Service is very friendly and attentive. It's never been a long wait to get a table even though there have been plenty of people there. The drinks are kinda pricey and the sangria is sub par, but the food is great!
author: Tony C.

description:
Just had lunch here yesterday and we were very underwhelmed with our food. My husband ordered the pork flautas...what a disappointment on the easiest food you could serve. The menu just said slow roasted pork yet they threw in kale and onions and drizzled honey all inside. I even told the server he doesn't like veggies so not to add lettuce or guacamole on top but she didn't mention the large amounts of kale inside each of the two flautas.  Menu needs better descriptions of each item. 
I had the BBQ brisket sliders which were edible but lots of fat in the two little burgers. And they could care a little more about the buns. The sopaipillas were the best thing we got and it was just plain puffy bread. Not going back.
author: Ayrn H.

description:
I went for dinner on MLK Day so the restaurant wasn't crowded and the noise level was reasonable. The high ceilings make the restaurant feel spacious and the tables are set far enough apart so as not to bump into every chair/table/person you walk by. No complaints on the service, either!

We started with the guacamole with chips and sopaipillas with honey, the latter being my favorite. That isn't to say the guacamole wasn't delicious- it was hearty and thick. But I loooove honey, and it's hard to go wrong with any type of fried bread dough dipped in rich honey.

I had the Fire Roasted Chile Poblano Relleno. I'm usually disappointed by restaurant rellenos but this one was fantastic. Just the right amount of spice. The warm farro salad was a great compliment, the dressing light and tangy. So good I took home leftovers.
author: Deanna M.

description:
West of Pecos has HUGE portions and good food, although it is a bit on the expensive side.  The service is really friendly, and they have mastered the balance of checking in with you enough so you don't feel forgotten, but infrequently so you don't feel bothered or rushed.  The restaurant is large and has a steakhouse vibe, which is great for getting a last-minute table (we made a reservation a few hours in advance, but I don't think the wait would be too long without one), yet it still doesn't feel like a chain.

They have a nice beer selection - I had the Wanderer IPA - and I hear their cocktails are great, although I didn't try one last night.  My friend and I ordered 3 plates to share: the enormous guacamole, crispy brussels sprouts, and the pork trio.  The guacamole was bland, and the chips were nothing special either (Casa Sanchez brand is better!).  It got better from there, however, with deliciously fried brussels sprouts up next.  The mayonnaise-y aoli was a bit heavy, but it came on the side so no harm done.  The main course, the pork trio, was awesome.  The confit and braised shoulder were flavorful, and the plantains were plantains (which is the highest form of praise considering how I feel about plantains).  Overall, I enjoyed the atmosphere, the food, and the company, and would definitely go back and try some other menu items and a mezcal cocktail.
author: Rachel A.

description: The food is very good. Fried chicken was outstanding, as was the guacamole with crab. If you like a smokey drink try the Ghost. Only downside of this place is in the main dining area. Poor lighting - its blinding and harsh. WOP, great restaurant, but overhaul your ceiling lighting.
author: Greg K.

description: The cocktail waitress was the highlight of my time here.  She was a fox!  Anyway, cool joint, pretty good food. Lots of Mezcal. Quite possibly the worst hang over of my 27 years on this earth.
author: Chelsey G.

description: Really tasty American cuisine dishes. A bit spendy, ideal for a date night spot. Service was expedient and dishes were filling. I enjoyed the fried chicken platter which came with three different sides (all tasty). Chips and salsa are 1$ extra I believe-- worth it.
author: Alexander T.

description:
First time here, the service was pretty slow, food runners had no idea where dishes were going so the more people the harder it will be for you party. 
The food, however, is pretty awesome. The artichoke dish is amazing as well as the burger. 
Queso and guac are also pretty awesome, especially since most guacs in the it tend to be bland.
author: Jess B.

description:
Edit as of 12/28/13:
So shortly after my not-so-great trip to West of Pecos, one of the owners reached out and asked if I would consider trying the restaurant again and if so he would send me a gift certificate to do so. Being from Texas, it's taken me awhile to make it back, but I said I would give it another go to try the new menu items and recipe adjustments and I like to keep my word.  

We went on a Thursday night and were seated in the bar area right away. They are now serving an amuse-bouche of radish, jicama and something else tossed with chili powder. . . I'm not sure. It was strange and I was concerned the dinner was not going to go well. Luckily the night went up from there. 

We tried the queso again and it was much improved. The thickness was more like typical queso and it now comes with chorizo, green onions and red jalapeños which was a nice touch in my opinion. And the chips were great. Yay for real queso!

I ordered the Coffee Rubbed Brisket Sandwich, which was pretty good. The meat was tender and it came with pearl onions on texas toast. It came some absolutely huge potato wedges (steak fries on the menu) which were pretty great and a side of slaw which was decently tasty. My date ordered the American Kobe Beef Bacon Burger, which comes on an English muffin. We both thought that was super strange, and not Tex-Mex-y, but I heard no complaints as it was being devoured. 

The sopapillas are still missing the cinnamon sugar part, but they were still pretty tasty with the honey served on the side. I didn't get a chance to try the cocktails, so perhaps that's an excuse to return and try more of the improved menu. 

Overall, I am very impressed with the improvements made by West of Pecos. Oh, and the service was very much improved also. Our wait staff was on top of it and very friendly which always helps a dining experience. I still wouldn't consider West of Pecos real Tex-Mex, but whatever it is, I'm happy to say it was quite good this time around! 

Original Review:
Being from Texas I know good Mexican, Tex-Mex and BBQ. West of Pecos excelled at none of those things. 

The do it yourself lemonade was terrible, the Goldrush adult beverage I ordered was mostly ice, the BBQ sauce for the ribs was not good, the hearth roasted pork carnitas was very bland and only half the plate was even tender meat, the roasted corn cherry tomato avocado cotija cheese salsa was basically mashed avocado with some cheese bits on top - no corn or tomato in sight. Unless you count the quarter piece of tomato that had stowed away amongst my pork.

 Oh, the queso was super runny so barely any stayed on the burnt tasting chips and who makes sopapillas without cinnamon sugar? At least they still tasted decent with some honey drizzled on too. 

Lastly, our waitress was pretty MIA which never makes for a good experience. Needless to say, we will not be returning to West of Pecos.

Original rating: 1/5
author: Emma A.

description:
I was skeptical. Prices seemed high. But it due to some combination of it being Easter, 420 day and Hitler's birthday, our go-to Mexican place was closed. 

Anyway, this place did win me over, as their fish tacos ($15) checked all the boxes - beer battered, with avocado and some sour cabbage for that sour kick you gotta have. Also, the tortillas were browned to perfection, just like I do at home. Definitely a cut above your average tacos. Good service, good atmosphere. My buddy also enjoyed his corn bread and chili.
author: Nick C.

description: Hands down one of the best spots in the mission. Brunch game is next level, fried chicken and churros were a game changer. Dinner: Grilled artichoke was one of the greatest things to enter my mouth in a long time. Make sure to get the ribs as well. Cucumber Jalepeno Margs were also on point. Will be returning shortly
author: Max M.

description:
Straight away, let me say I did not eat here, just had a night cap with friends on Valentine's day. Valencia St. was hopping at 10:30 at night and when we spotted the open outdoor table near the fireplace we headed in. Not so fast, pardner! The hostess was nice enough at first when she thought we were coming in for food but then dismissed our desire to sit outside. When we were similarly ignored at the bar we just went ahead and occupied the outdoor table. Our buddy took our drink orders and brought them back to our table himself. Okay, cocktails were good. I had a mezcal shot and it came with a little glass of sangrita (spicy and good) and a slice of orange. No coarse salt, like in Oaxaca, but decent. My friends had beers. Nothing to rave or complain about.

So why the two stars you might ask? It reflects the restaurant as a whole. It is a stunning example of "fakeness", ersatz, imitation, non-genuine fakeness of a Tex-Mex experience. The whole dang place. I might expect this type of staged, easy theme, blingy restaurant in, say, Kansas City or Cincinnatti, or yep, an airport! But on Valencia Street in the heart of The Mission? In a city known for artisinal, bespoke, GENUINE cuisine and decor? Frankly, we were horrified from the cheesy gas chiminayas to the crummy toilet paper holders made out of fake branding irons. Are you kidding me? Is this what we can now expect to happen all over the Mission? 

I am a big fan of The Woodhouse Fish Co. Which I have learned is behind West of Pecos. I am surprised. Like I said, I cannot address the food, but here in S.F. we dine out not only for the food but for the physical experience, the pleasure of our surroundings. This place is a reminder of all the strip mall restaurants that have attempted to lull Americans into feeling a sense of place. Fie! Fie, I say!
author: Lynka A.

description: Stopped here for dinner last night and was greeted by a very helpful hostess who checked on us throughout the evening to make sure things were going well.   It was very busy and I was impressed by this level of service.  In addition... food is awesome!   Steak fajitas and an amazing salad with the best dressing ever.   Super cold beer and a very fun crowd.   There are so many things I want to try on the menu.. that I'll be back.
author: Sarah F.

description:
The food here wasn't bad but I think the restaurant itself is somewhat misleading.
This is not Tex-Mex. As a matter of fact there is nothing really mex about this place at all. The food does not match the brand (or the price for that matter). It is more of a glorified american bbq joint. Most of their food is very heavy. However, If that is what you are looking for then I don't think it is a bad choice. I do have to admit that their cocktails are pretty good too. 

Not an overall bad experience, but I most likely will not be making a second trip to West of Pecos.
author: Derek H.

description: I watched the foulest crap go down here at this restaurant! I wanted to try the food here and was waiting to order. I watched the owner kick out an older gentleman and his SERVICE dog! The older man tried to explain and was cut off abruptly! Apparently the LAW doesn't apply to this hell hole! I walked straight out. I am sure people try to get away with bringing their dogs in ...but this guy was legit and was treated like trash. He was clearly shaken and embarrassed! DISGUSTING BEHAVIOR!!!! I will tell everyone that I know, what I saw, with my own two eyeballs!
author: Gina H.

description:
Bland. Bland. Bland.  Oh... did I say it was bland?  Oh yeah... it's bland.

There is nothing more than I can say for the food.  We tried the Queso Chips appetizer (think melted velveeta with soy-chorizo-something on top), fried chicken (seriously.... its smelled and tasted like Tyson fried chicken), and the ribs (ok but not much flavor).  All the sides were equally as bland.   Its like they opened a bunch of cans of food from a wholesaler.  

I had a simple margarita...  it was one of those strangely overly sour margaritas with a salt rim on only 1/4 the glass.  Not sure what that was about.

Cut to the chase.... we won't go back and don't recommend it.

Funny thing that the space used to be an Indian Bazaar food store for years which specialized in Indian spices.  Too bad the WoP chef couldn't have kept some of those spices.
author: Victor P.

description:
Wonderful food and drinks!  The devil tooth is the best!!  Chips with melted cheese surprisingly unique.  We had the sliders, fish tacos and the mango and harvest salad and everything was very tasty! 
Service was ok and hence why this place misses a perfect 5 stars.  Our waitress took 15 min to even greet us or get drink order.  When we finally got our drinks it took another 25min for her to return and take our dinner order.  We were watching her too to cut her some slack in case she had too many other tables.  But nope, she was just slow and then got distracted by other coworkers. 
All in all a good experience and we will be back.  If they want to take this place to a new level they need to step up service.
author: Jez S.

description:
I should have written this update in a timely manner. The owner had read my previous poor Yelp review, and offered a $25 credit to come in and try them again. So a friend and I returned, on a weeknight, and had dinner. The service was much better. The guacamole and fried chicken we ordered was good. 
With such great Tex/Mex options in San Francisco, you can do better. 
But it's a fun, casual joint to enjoy a cocktail and appetizers.
author: Bonnie B.

description: Food was decent to good quality on scale of San francisco,but very small portions. The steak fajitas has probably 5oz of steak, many bell peppers and no sides. For $18. $10 for  guacamole. At least the beer was 18 Oz for $7. Very very over priced.  We went on a Sunday afternoon, didnt have to wait. I won't be back.
author: William O.

description:
I've passed this place about a million times and from the outside, it looks pretty great: beautiful wood out front, a large and spacious interior and pretty delicious sounding menu items. 

I finally decided to bite the bullet and eat there on a night my friends and I were willing to splurge a bit. We all ordered drinks, appetizers and big steak dinners. I was so so so hoping to be blown away, especially since the other reviews are fairly positive and as a native Texan, I've been desperately searching for a place that reminds me of home, but I was wrong. So. Wrong. First of all, there wasn't any queso on the menu (never had a chance..Tex Mex? Hm). 

But anyways, this place truly infuriates me.  

The food was far below average. The steak was tough though not overcooked (which leads me to believe the quality was shit) and the flavors were just plain confusing and weird. They did not tickle my pickle. 

The guacamole was pretty decent, but I was so upset by my steak (and then the bill which ended up taking about $30 out of each of our pockets) that it was hard to look on the bright side (which was the guac).
author: Allie S.

description: Decent sit down Mexican restaurant in the Mission. Good margs and tasty smaller mexican dishes. Good for groups. Cute decor.
author: Leah B.

description:
All Hype, No bite

I went to WOP with three other friends last night and it was nothing special. I recommend Techo de Lolinda over this place any day. We ordered one pitcher of margarita, I had a Devil's tooth cocktail, guacamole, queso, flautas, for the table and I had the crudo tacos.

1. Margarita pitcher - I didn't have any of the margs, but my friends said they were good

2. Devil's tooth - I didn't feel a thing after I drank it....-_-

3. Guacamole - delicious, I recommend

4. Queso - delicious, I recommend

5. Flautas - Nothing special at all, I do not recommend. They were also kind of sweet. The only highlight was the crema that came with them. 

Crudo Tacos - OK. If i went again i would probably order them because they're probably consistent, but they were absolutely nothing special...

The service was great.
author: Jazmyn W.

description:
The very first time I had dinner here is was amazing!!! Second time around, huge disappointment. My boyfriend and I showed up at 7pm, got seated and never saw our server again except when she brought the check. 

The drinks and food portions have decreased significantly! They only offer a "half" grilled artichoke when it used to be a full for the same price! Ordered an old fashion drink and it was the size of a shooter!  Don't think we will ever go back, left hungry and there are much better choices in the mission district.
author: Maria C.

description: Enjoyed my brunch.  Had a Chile with eggs and corn dish with potato fries and veggies.
author: Jer M.

description: Smallest shared portions ever. There were four of us and we were all super hungry. We wanted to split some "shared" plates that were on the menu. We asked the waitress if there would be enough for all of us to share and she said yes. When we got our meal, they were TINY and only 3 pieces on each plate (why does every restaurant put 3 pieces of food on a plate for a shared menu??!!) I'm assume they want you to fight to the death for the last one? The tacos/enchiladas were so tiny I though this was a joke. By the end we could only get a forkful each person/each plate and it worked out to be $73 per couple for barely a full plate of food. Too bad as the actual food tasted good but will not do the shared plates again and probably won't return.
author: Ranee W.

description: We ordered the fish tacos and chicken enchiladas. The tacos were great, the enchiladas so-so. Friends ordered the fluffy tacos and they looked great - we will go back to try those.
author: Stacy D.

description:
They do brunch now. This must be news, because I can't think of any other reason why we should have been able to just show up and sit down like this. Not waiting in line for at least an hour for any halfway-decent brunch place on Saturday morning is just unheard of in San Francisco. But there was no wait.

And the food is great. They have a full bar. The brunch on offer is unique enough to be creative but not so unique that it will scare away our new friends who just moved to the Bay Area and haven't gotten used to the culinary liberalism here yet. 

It isn't even crowded. Or loud. I can totally hear what everybody is saying. Definitely coming back. Hope word about this doesn't spread *too* quickly. But then again, they have a lot of seats.
author: Amy T.

description: I just made a mistake and ordered the steak here. Don't make the same mistake as me because I realized that they don't have real steak here apparently. I guess I should've known since this is a texmex place. The rest of the food looked better so I would like to try it next time.
author: Andrea T.

description:
