This is one of my favorite places to eat in the mission. I'm from Texas and I do have to say that the decor and ambience is right on. It has a west Texas feel with the rustic wooden tables, leather seats, hanging dried chilies, and rusted metal ranch items like spurs and ranch brands.

The French toast and the Pecos Poached Eggs are my favorite, the biscuits are really tasty, and the butter they serve with pancakes and the like has a slight spice to it which was different but super good. My husband likes spicy stuff and barbecue so if you're into that, they have items for you too!
author: Angela P.

description:
Happy hour menu's tacos were soooooo good. Each taco for $2.50, they're gigantic and sweet and dripping with sauce. Also shared a guacamole, which was fantastic. Their sangria was pleasantly strong; margaritas just a tad bit too sweet for me. 
Would definitely return (for another happy hour).
author: Clara H.

description: Wow! What a busy area, but we got a table. Anyway we started out with queso guacamole and ceviche mmmmm. Then some great margaritas. I had crispy brisket tacos 5 stars. There was 6 of us so bring your wallet $$$
author: Donald M.

description: Every time we come here I like this place even more.  Met some friends for drinks and dinner.  We wound up only getting as far as a few shareable plates (and a few rounds of drinks).  Everything was tasty and the service was great!
author: Trilo B.

description:
Came here last night for dinner and I can say it was fairly decent. My group started out with margaritas. The Prickly Pear Pecos Margarita was DELISH. Smoky and sweet, it was an interesting take on an old favorite. 

Then we had chips and salsa. The chips were perfectly crisp and salty. The salsa was fruity but also very spicy. I think they made it with lime juice. Not traditional, but great. 


Lastly I had the Ancho & Apricot Pork Ribs. Overall, I would give them 3.5 stars. They fell right off the bone, but the flavor of the meat was lost in the overwhelming sauce. The butter beans were too salty. However, the coleslaw was very good! 

Lastly, the ambiance is very trendy and cute. But, as has been my experience with many other trendy Mission restaurants, the clientele all but gave me ulcers. I almost choked on my pork ribs when I overheard the woman at the table next to me loudly boast about not vaccinating her children. So there's that...
author: Casey M.

description: We accidentally ended up at this restaurant last friday night. Our party was seated right away by the friendly Hostess. Me and my bestfriend had a Margarita with añejo tequila. It was amazing but very pricey! We had the crabguacamole for our appetizer and it is delicious! Me and my boyfriend shared the steak fajitas. It is dissapointing because the meat was very chewy. We didn't even finish the entire plate. My bestfriend had the Fried chicken with Collard greens and creamed corn, it is very tender and flavorful. Love the creamed corn! Here comes dessert! We shared the churros with chocolate and Mexican caramel sauce and it is insanely delicious! Can't remember the exact name of the Peach dessert with vanilla ice cream and it was good too. I think people should try this place in Valencia instead of going to Limon Rottiserie next door.  We will back for sure!
author: Maryann P.

description: Carnitas tacos here are phenomenal! Great atmosphere and solid service. Can't ask for much more.
author: Yiorgo L.

description: BASIC BASIC BASIC. I guess maybe because I'm Hispanic I expected their tex-mex spin on food to be a bit more flavorful, but that wasn't the case. I sat at the bar , so grabbed a cocktail. I believe I got the roadrunner: mezcal it was savory and balanced ; good job hipster like bartender. Service was prompt . Server was sweet. BUT I probs won't be coming back not suggesting it to my friends... It just lacked the BANG effect on such a cool street.
author: Brenda E.

description:
You can't go wrong here. Amazing cocktails. Great food. Good people.
The skillet corn bread is a must!
author: Ray C.

description:
Alright - I'm not sure how much you should trust me considering that I was plastered after the first cocktail, 'Blood and Curses' (which was spectacular btw). 

I remember a few things about the dishes I shoved into my mouth though. One was the brisket sandwich - pretty good but only get this if you're craving a good chunk of cow and looking for butter and starch. Go for the poblano or the artichoke - solid, healthier options. Honestly, I have no idea what happened after those last bites.
author: Dora C.

description: Wow is a great word to describe this restaurant~ Tyler and his brothers run a great fun restaurant~ the food is awesome! It reminds me of the great food you find in the southwest ~ fresh food great drinks~ and Tyler just completes the restaurant with his great personality and beautiful collection of Native American artifacts~ I recommend all the food here but my favorites are the Chicken with cornbread molasses n cowboy beans~ YUM!!
author: Duke Of Frisco X.

description: Great spot for groups & a solid atmosphere, but ultimately everything I ate was average: Corn Bread, Mac & Cheese, Corn on the Cob, Ribs, and Fried Chicken.
author: Jeff F.

description: The atmosphere is very nice. Sat on the bar and watched the cooks do their work - fascinating! Service was good as well. Ordered the "3 west of pecos fish tacos" which was excellent!
author: Shahar K.

description:
Good service, good atmosphere, but food is heavily salted. I've been 2x in the past 6 months, once for brunch a little while back and once this past week for dinner. Both times my dining companions were a little turned off by the salt quantity. 

For example: oversalted house-made chips could have been saved by guacamole, but guac was also salty and made extra salty with the addition of rock salt (great for presentation, but too much with the chips). Even the salad was salty. I had the same experience with a poached egg dish I had months ago. I've concluded that the chef must be a smoker because the food would be fantastic with about 1/5 the salt.
author: sarah m.

description:
Kinda flummoxed by the negative reviews here.  I've gone . . what . .20 times now, and WOP has been consistently delightful. The food has been invariably well seasoned and cooked, and the service has been friendly and attentive. So here's my advice to you prospective diners:

1) Go
2) Order the Prickly Pear Margarita   . .spicy and sour and sweet and . . . SO GOOD
3) Get the cornbread skillet. It's crunchy, moist, and comes with a big ol' scoop of butter melting into the middle. Mmmmmmmmmmm

Everything I've ordered has been good, but we especially enjoy the carnitas, duck tacos and the amazing ribs.
author: Jordan J.

description: Came here the day after Tacoliscious.  The margarita was smaller here and the queso rather bland.  The space is nice and the staff pleasant, but keep walking another block for a 5 star experience at Tacoliscious.
author: Brian G.

description:
Not really impressed.

The beer was good (had both the 18 oz-ers served in a "chalice"), the appetizer was good (had the green chile mac and cheese), but the main courses just didn't seem freshly made to either of us.

I had the brown sugar buttermilk fried chicken (new on the menu) - and it was really not so good.  The mashed potatoes must have been sitting for a long time - when you stick a fork in it to pick some up, the whole thing picked up like a single unit of mashed potatoes - not good.  The chicken was luke warm and a bit soggy.

My friend got the artichoke deal-e-o and he was less than impressed.

Bummer as the menu looks so great.  The service was very good, though, so I bumped up the 2 stars that I was gonna leave and gave em 3.
author: Jon B.

description:
I really wanted to like west of pecos more. How could you not love a bar that combined frozen margarita w/ sangria? But... it just wasn't up to par when it came to the important things: food and service 

I ordered the bbq ribs. My friend got the fried green tomato salad. His portion seemed a little small, salad with a little s, not a Salad, if you know what I mean. 
My ribs were just salty. There was no flavor to the bbq sauce. They were so so salty. The texture of the meat was decent. Not fall off the bone tender, but adequately tender. 

That frozen margarita drink? Tequila in the margarita tasted pretty cheap and well, it takes a lot for me to dislike tequila, especially in a frozen margarita. 

Service was not great. I liked the bartender who served me, but she was hard to flag down even when I was right in front of her and there were only 2 other people at the bar. Similarly our waitress was fine when we could get a hold of her, but that was super difficult. No one came to refill our waters and we had to ask for a box separately from the check (really?). 

I like the space and the location, but I don't think it's worth coming back, especially for the price.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Mixed reviews on Yelp left me unsure of what to expect. But let me make one thing clear: The food here is NOT bland. Also, the service is fantastic (if not overattentive)!

My friend and I strolled in on a Tuesday evening -- easy-peasy to get seated immediately. We were placed in the bar section on a tiny table with high stools, not exactly ideal for eating. When I asked if we could move, the staff were extremely apologetic about not being able to accommodate my request, as the other tables were all occupied. Totally fine, I mean we hadn't set a reservation or anything.

We shared 3 appetizers:
- Chips and guacamole = The chips were thick and crunchy, and the guac was chunky, creamy and at times sour. Seriously the opposite of boring.
- Green chile mac & cheese = This was a no-brainer. I'm obsessed with mac & cheese; to add green chile to it seemed like a brilliant idea. And it didn't disappoint! Rich, creamy and a bit spicy, I was in heaven.
- Kale tostada salad = We ordered this dish upon the recommendation of our waitress (bless you, lady!). It's now one of my new favorite salads in SF. Besides delicious kale and crispy tostada, there's black beans, cotija cheese, salsa and tomato vinagrette. Mmmmm.

Also ordered two margaritas each -- sour and perfectly made, though a bit pricey (made up the bulk of our bill). Definitely worth it though.

To top everything off, the manager sent over a slice of pumpkin pie (to apologize for not being able to move us earlier). So thoughtful and completely unnecessary, I have to admit I was touched! I'm not a dessert girl and I was full beyond belief, but I had a few bites and it was absolutely mindblowing. The crust tasted like it'd been glazed or something. Unbelievable.

Had a wonderful evening here and would absolutely come back. I've already raved about the kale tostada salad to a few friends. (Hopefully they never take this item off their menu.) Keep up the good work, West of Pecos!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
New southwestern spot in the Mish. 

We started with the trio of duck confit tacos, which were miniature tacos, crispy shells, a little skimpy on the duck though. 

The crab and shrimp stuffed artichoke fared better, good portion of crab and shrimp, fun to eat.

The ribs were fine, nothing special, a bit too sweet for my taste.

The albondigas were super dry, sauce didn't really help. I basically forced myself to eat this.

Cocktails weren't very good, mezcal is my liquor of choice right now and their cocktails didn't do it justice. 

Service was pretty indifferent, it could have made our dinner better, but pretty much made it worse.

Not impressed.
author: Derrick V.

description:
The fried chicken is the bomb! I'd like those Brussel spouts to be buried with me. 

I love the happy hour options and prices, but going here later is nice too. The staff is super friendly which is what brought me back after being unimpressed by the ribs. :)
author: Heather T.

description: So I never actually write a yelp review but for this place I had to. Great service. Friendly atmosphere. Helpful and goddamn good bartender. Went in with a couple of buddies and got five tapas at the bar with a couple drinks (=$65). Left perfectly stuffed since they gave us a free hot pastry with honey. The food, including fried green tomatoes, pork belly, carnitas pies, Mac and cheese, and chips with amazing rich guacamole all came out prompt and was all thoroughly delicious!! If you like tequila, tapas, and beer served in a huge ice cold goblet then you'll love it like we did at West of Pecos!!
author: brigie k.

description: Cinco de mayo is the bomb here. Please come and sit by the fire and ride the mechanical bull. I got to ride it and got thrown off and landed like a smashed potato. Im still screaming my head off. Please wear your cowboy boots and your Mexican sombrero. Get a margarita and have some fun
author: Isabel P.

description: The staff is really friendly and the food is fresh and delicious. One of my favorite things to get is their nacho cheese dip with chorizo. And they have he most impressive pair of bull horns adorning their wall. You'll be impressed.
author: Mary B.

description: Came here for Taco Tuesday and happy hour and was pretty pleased with the pork and beef tacos and the guac! The Habanero wings were okay, they had a little kick but lacked flavor. Prices for the alcohol is decent. Pretty good place for happy hour in the Mission.
author: Susie N.

description:
Holy.
Crap.
The pork chop...

Eat the pork chop.

Seriously.
author: Rebecca W.

description: Chevys on steroids:  creative use of non traditional ingredients in a western style.  Great selection of tequila and other alcohol, good bartenders to mix it.  Western woody decor, trendy alternative music on the sound system.  Pleasant wait staff.  I will add the fifth star after I've been here a few more times...
author: Darrin C.

description: Our party of 7 showed up at 7pm on the Friday before Halloween without a reservation. We had little expectation of being seated in under an hour, but the hostess and manager (Kristina?...I think) not only made us feel welcome, they found a great table for us in 10 minutes, joked with us, gave us personal attention and made sure our night started off right. Yeah, the food and drinks were good, too, but it's the way we were taken care of by all the staff that really made an impact. Thank you!
author: Scott Y.

description:
Generally, I'm not a huge fan of Tex-Mex because I just prefer really authentic Mexican food BUT this place definitely changed my mind!

Interesting tasty drinks -- try the Pecos (smoked salt added that extra zing!).

Appetizer wise is definitely suggest the flatbread, guacamole, cornbread (YUM!), y the corn was pretty good too. 

What really wowed me though was the chile relleno -- OMGoodness SOOOOOOOO good!!!!!!

On top of the great food the service was fabulous! We came in at 8pm, with 10+ people without reservations, y they accommodated us with a smile. So nice!!! The server was also crazy attentive y lovely!

I'm for sure coming back here :)
author: Maya-Luisa G.

description:
On a visit to the Mission this summer and in the mood for some Tex-Mex, we ended up at this place because of the strong yelp reviews. Needless to say it did not disappoint.

There was a 45 min - 1 hour wait but they have a nice bar and we were able to snag a couple of stools (not that easy on a Thurs. night). The bar was definitely a lively place, lots of energy...not a bad place to wait for a table.

Food - Messy Texas Ribs. Unbelievable! Everything you want from ribs if you don't mind a little fat on your meat and faceful of BBQ sauce. They were savory, they were tender, and they totally hit the spot.
author: Roy K.

description: Used to love west of pecos for an evening drink. I've eaten there too and the food is meh. However their new "policy" of not being able to sit down in the bar area unless you eat is rude and asinine. They turned us away when there was a bunch of empty tables that they could have filled for 20 minutes of drinks. When we told the hostess that we wanted to give them our constructive feedback on this we got an apathetic shrug. Oh well, plenty of other places to go in the area. I'm sure they don't care either way.
author: Rob D.

description:
This place was so yummy, it made me wish I had more than one stomach so I could keep eating.

Decided to try this place for the first time during a recent double date and we were pleased to find a laid back ambiance, good cocktails and great food!

We started out with the green chile mac & cheese (not the best i've had, but pretty good.) and pork belly (which comes with brussel sprouts and a deep fried egg.  Delicious!!)

I ordered the burger as my entree, which I wasn't blown away by..however, I was so full by this point I don't know if I could have given it a fair review.  I'll have to come back when i'm not overly stuffed on appetizers :(  The man ordered the ribs which he was very pleased with.  Make sure you order the corn bread.  Nothing makes me happier than a skillet full of corn bread!  It was super yummy and had real chunks of corn in it.  It also comes with molasses dipping sauce, which I wasn't a fan of but the man loved.  

Ended dinner with the chocolate mousse, which was delicious, but beware - it is SPICY!  Spicier than any Mexican chocolate i've had before, but still smooth, creamy and delicious.

Also note .... we looked at other yelper's dish suggestions and were sad to see that none of the items were on the menu anymore.  Our server said they change their menu every 6 months-ish so make sure you look at the menu on their website for the most recent selection.
author: Dana J.

description:
I won't be going back to this restaurant. Just before this review, you'll see one by my friend Betty for the same outing.

I concur with everything she said - poor service, unremarkable food. In fact, very poor service. We asked for a burger medium rare and it came out well done. The server vanished and never asked us how the food was. We sat next to the hostess stand and didn't get any attention for a very long time. 

My friend ordered a second glass of wine, and we had to wait and wait for it. 

The server was totally checked out, and the restaurant wasn't even close to full. It's unfortunate the service was so poor - there are some nice beers on tap, the bartender was very nice and helpful, and they played some really good blues music over the speakers. There's also plenty of space.

The food was OK, but not great. And the hamburger was crazy overcooked. And, as my friend said, there was a $1 upcharge for BBQ sauce. Are you kidding? The fish tacos were pretty good - they did a nice job on the spicy cabbage slaw. They were a bit drowned in their sauce, though.
author: Carter S.

description: Let me star by saying great ambiance. But the food was mediocre at best and the pitchers of margaritas at $36 a piece had zero tequila in them. Servers and wait staff were good.
author: Erin G.

description:
Been here three times now and each time it has been stellar, so one more star for consistency.

Food: delicious, creative. 

Seating: has never been hard to get (I went on a weekday night, weekend night, and weekend afternoon).  Minimal wait time.

A go-to place to take people you want to impress.
author: Mandy H.

description:
West of Pecos? More like Best of Pecos! I've been here several times and it just keeps getting better.  From grabbing a drink with a couple friends to large birthday dinners, this place has what you want. The cocktails are delicious and the food is authentic. My girlfriend is from New Mexico so apparently I'm an expert by association. If you like smoky tequila get the Mezcal Mule.  Want something spicy? Try the Prickly Pecos Margarita. I can't wait to try their brunch menu if I ever wake up before 3PM on a weekend.

One more bonus: I watched the Giants win the series while having dinner here and I can verify that the doors are strong enough to keep out marauding hordes of drunken Giants fans.
author: Galen R.

description:
I totally blew it on this one. My friend Justin O. (HI JUSTIN!) had already reviewed this place, but for whatever reason I skipped over his review. 

Wish I had read it before I ordered the carnitas. 

Justin (WHATS UP JUSTIN?!) had a bad carnitas experience here, and wrote a great review about it. So great that I'm going to copy a little here:

" " "
The big issue was that the carnitas, a fairly simple dish, were underwhelming b/c of the bland taste and lack of flavor...Tex-Mex is supposed to have bold flavors and none of these dishes hit the mark.

" " "

Justin (WHAT'RE YOU DOING LATER JUSTIN?) hit the nail on the head. 

The whole menu looked pretty appetizing, but everything else we ordered (flat iron, stuffed artichoke, guacamole) was also pretty flavorless. My dinner companions and I resorted to dumping hot sauce on everything just to taste something...anything.

I liked the ambiance. It's modern, with a little ironic (not too ironic) Western thrown in. They were playing accessible indie music the whole time and I saw a few goofy looking moustaches, definitely seems like they're catering to a hipper crowd than Chili's. 

Service was okay- somewhat slow, but quite eager to get us more margaritas (pretty tasty, pretty pricey).

Given the quality/price of the food, I won't be back here again.
author: Ryan D.

description:
OMG!! SOOOO GOOOD!!
This is my new favorite restaurant.

I went with my fiance, future sister and father-in-law. 
We sat in front under a heat lamp and next to the fireplace. 
The atmosphere is great - relaxing and sets an evening tone. 

The amazingly fantastic things we ordered:
Drinks (I can't remember the fun names) - one with whisky, one with tequila and jalepeno, one fruity. 
Woodhouse grilled Artichoke 
Fish Tacos
Brown Sugar Buttermilk Fried Chicken 
Chips and Guacamole 

All I can say is GO. ORDER EVERYTHING!!! 

Like I said -- My new favorite restaurant.  Enough said!
author: Thea M.

description:
Yum... never would have thought to go to this place for brunch but it's ah-maze-ing. 
The French Toast is perfectly browned and the warm deer hunter wine, can't bet it on a frosty winter afternoon. Yum.
author: Allison S.

description:
I'm into it.

This has turned into one of my go-to spots along Valencia. Great ambiance, awesome/knowledgeable wait staff, and the cocktails... oh, the cocktails they're simply amazing.

Pretty much everyone and their Uncle can find something they love off the menu, I recommend the guacamole (always) and the duck flutas, as for my Uncle he recommends the ribs.

Bonus points for always have Bulleit Rye on the shelves and having a bartender with a heavy pour.
author: Bridey M.

description:
Great ambiance and excellent service, but the food is just edible.

- Paloma cocktail: Too much tequila and bitters, lacking in flavor.
- Queso: Great flavor, but needs more cream
- Mac n Cheese: Green chile is a great touch, but needs more cream.
- Brussel sprouts: Well cooked, but a tad bitter.
- Pozole: Flavorless

We did not venture into entrees since the starters were disappointing.
author: Janett R.

description:
I have been to West of Pecos more times than I can count and I'm always excited to go back. My husband and I have recommended it to several groups of friends and everyone has loved it as much as we do. I think what is so special about the food at West of Pecos is that it is interesting, inventive AND tastes amazing. I am so tired of the way so many other Mission restaurants serve bland, pretentious food. West of Pecos is just an overall great place to spend time. The staff is warm and friendly, the atmosphere is cozy and welcoming, and although it is always buzzing with activity you can have a conversation without being drowned out by noise. 

It's hard for me to pick a favorite dish. Brussels Sprouts, cornbread, chips and guacamole, mac and cheese, chile relleno, corn on the cob... so many delicious choices!! And don't even get me started on the drinks. The Prickly Pecos Margarita is far and away my favorite, but I've tried may of the others and it's always a tough decision. Not a bad situation to be in, if you ask me. 

To top it all off, this awesome place is just blocks from BART so when you've indulged in a few too many of their tempting cocktails you can safely get yourself home. West of Pecos is the best!!
author: Amber A.

description:
Yummy, fresh margarita (on the rocks). Probably one of the best, most fresh margaritas I've had, and I'm from Texas and drink margs like water. 

Queso is a little too watery for my liking
Chiles relllano was good and had a good mix of other sides

For those craving Tex-Mex in the Bay Area, this Texan approves! 

#vegetarian review
author: Eric H.

description: Always a great experience eating here! A little sad they no longer have the bacon wrapped shrimp or the roasted salted peppers, however, seasonal menus seem to be a common thing now in SF. Hopefully they'll be back. The cocktails are also amazing!
author: Alan M.

description: Honestly, I try to look back at this place and none of my friends enjoyed the food, we felt like the service took forever, and the music and wallpaper really melted my brain. The macaroni and cheese was really salty and the calamari didn't feel fresh.
author: Akshay B.

description:
This place does not deserve to be in the Mission! I don't get how people are giving this place 4 and 5 stars! The food sucks and is not worth the price. We ordered the kale tostadas and guacamole and chips for appetizers. The kale tostadas were the only thing that was good, but everything else was blah. The guacamole was bland and I had to keep adding salt to it for more flavor. For dinner, we had the beef brisket and grilled artichokes with crab and shrimp. The bread of the beef brisket tasted completely fried, and my grilled artichokes with crab and shrimp sounded better than it actually tasted. Nothing too exciting.

There are so many better choices in the Mission to eat at...we just stumbled upon the wrong one. Do yourself a favor...if you walk by this place, keep on walking and spend your money some place else.
author: Jenn Z.

description:
I've been to West of Pecos a couple of times now for dinner and brunch and I have to say that the food is really great! I'm a bigger fan of their lunch/dinner options over brunch, but I'm not a big breakfast person anyways. 

I've had their burger which was fair and the brisket sandwich which is excellent. It's really saucy and the Texas toast is a great touch. Their home fries are huge and not my favorite in terms of fries, but not too shaby. I've tasted their ribs too, which were great and very flavorful. 

It has a great ambiance, so I'd recommend going for drinks (their margaritas are kind of strong) and snacks (I absolutely love their chips and queso and guac)!
author: Kim S.

description:
Ummm, how is this place not packed on a Saturday morning?! I've been here for dinner, and raved about the food (baby kale tostada salad is fresh, super tasty, and really a meal in itself; fish tacos are deelish, too!) 

But brunch is my new dig. I've tried the Stuffed Poblano Chiles; and Austin Breakfast Tacos. Both amazing. Even if you're looking for something more traditional they've got the eggs benny perfected; the maple glazed pork belly is the most delicious thing you've ever tasted; and the french toast looks awesome (though I haven't yet tried it).

My fave in the brunch spread, I have to admit, is sipping down those Pecos Pimms Cups. I'm not even a cocktail kinda person, but they're sooo delightfully refreshing and tasty, especially while looking out through the open windows to the buzz of Valencia street.
author: Karina K.

description:
I really, really wanted to love this place. When I heard there was going to be a Southwestern restaurant opening, perhaps even focusing on New Mexico style food, I was really excited. I dearly love the green chile things they do down there, and was psyched to be able to get some locally.

Unfortunately, this is most certainly not that. The only thing with green chile on the menu is the mac & cheese (?!), and it has barely any.  Sigh.
Our grilled corn on the cob was tough and chewy. The ribs were also on the tough side.

Their cocktail menu has gone through quite a few changes since they opened, and I'm glad to say it's improved dramatically. Originally, almost everything was way too sweet, but it's much better and more balanced now.

If only the food would catch up.

The space is cool - very Southwestern sort of feel. And it's pretty huge, though still often busy.
author: Don H.

description:
One of the BEST restaurants I've ever been to.  The ambiance is incredible, the food is to die for (authentic New Mexico with an SF twist), and the staff are all super sweet and accommodating. There is a tiny wait, but it's well worth it!

You have to try the sopaipilla and cajeta ice cream!!!!!!!
author: Natalie W.

description:
Yes to everything about this place.

On our last days of a budget trip in SF we decided to splurge(kind of) and West of Pecos is right near our apartment. Here are all the good things I appreciated..

- decor is clean, simple and warm with just enough kitschy texan things to make it work
- menus are beautifully presented
- waiters are friendly are welcoming and a little cheeky

We ordered 2 mains and 2 sides and all were so so delicious. We left extremely full and satisfied and the bill only $52??? crazy!! (of course we gave a tip)
author: Mikaila D.

description:
I love love love this place for group dinners!  The owners are very enthusiastic and love to welcome their patrons.  The space is lively and homey.  If you are looking for fun, good energy, yummy drinks, and amazing food, COME HERE!

So, I am a huge Mezcal fan.  I love this stuff, I would bath in it if that were socially acceptable.  SInce bathing in alcohol might be offensive, I like to go to establishments that serve it.  Anything on their drink menu with Mezcal is a winner.  My fav is the Mezcal Mule.  Delish.

Food wise, I recommend-

Carnitas is heaven, complete heaven.  You will not be disappointed.  If you are then obviously you are a robot. 
Duck tacos are amazing.  A must get.
queso yessssssss.

I loved pretty much everything.  The only thing I don't care for is the mac and cheese.  It's kinda out of place here.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I can only review the happy hour which I thought was great.
The tacos ( duck and carnitas were delish!)  I havent seen the tacos on the happy hour menu for a while so i hope there not gone. Chicken wings and other things were fine.draft beer and wine were fine.
Service was friendly and unpretentious( which I can't say about many of the newer mission restaurants. I would say the only dissapointment was the margarita from the machine I have tried it a couple times and it was weak and unflavorful I had to order a side shot with it. The margaritas at aquis restaurant  in the southbay are awesome
they could learn a thing or two from them. I will definitely return to Pecos and hopefully will have a chance to check out the restaurant.
P.s bring back the happy hour tacos!
author: she o.

description:
Overall this was a miss for me.  Too much cheese, not enough fresh, bright flavors.  My vegetarian main of the poblano pepper was pretty bland.  It's adorable inside, and people were happy and all that.  But breaking down to the food it just wasn't there for me.

Maybe the big issue is trying to make TexMex in a land of Mexican.  Like walking into a Kobe beef steak house and asking for a Whopper.  Driving past a Four Seasons to go to a Motel 6.  Passing up a Cadillac for a Pinto.  

I'd come in again for drinks, and then head to a proper Mexican place to chow down.
author: Monica R.

description: 4 stars for a good rendition of Tex-Mex in a city overrun with Cal-Mex and Burrito joints. Wanted to like it more, but it gets 3 stars because service was slow, a couple of the dishes served were Luke-warm, and my "bottom-less" coffee was never re-filled. Another server did come by and clear our dishes after a long wait.
author: TXSebas T.

description:
Came here for my BDay drinks w/ my girlfriends.  Been wanted to try them out.  We decided on bunch of food to share but we were all disappointed for the GREAT lack of flavors in everything except the chile rellenos.  I mean if you screw up on the very basic chips & guac, then you got a real problem as a Mexican or Tex Mex joint.  A little dash of salt would be nice in the guac.  Take a little care to separate the big pile of chips that were stuck together in the fryer which ended being soggy and not fully cooked.  

Service was also lacking which was unfortunate.  We waited quite a while for our waitress to come around only to realize she forgot once again our drink order.  Margi is not tough to make yet so easy for these guys to screw up, truly sad!

The highlight of our evening was to have desserts & nite caps across the street at Locanda.  Glad we're able to salvage the evening after all.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Good experience we had some drinks.  The margarita pitcher was way too sweet but the pork belly app was money.
author: Joe M.

description:
I just ate here a week ago. West of Pecos is relatively new, so maybe still working out the kinks, but the experience and food could be a lot better.

The major complaint I have is the value - the food is priced fairly high given the quality. I have had better Tex-Mex at Chile's.  The big issue was that the carnitas, a fairly simple dish, were underwhelming b/c of the bland taste and lack of flavor. SEASON THE MEAT, PLEASE.

The lobster salad again was decent, but fairly tasteless in the grand scheme - Tex-Mex is supposed to have bold flavors and non of these dishes hit the mark.

We also had the guac and again ran into an under seasoned dish. Adding tomatoes to avocado is NOT guacamole.

I will say that the corn on the cob and the corn bread are AMAZING, but those are side dishes and not moving the needle for me to come back.
author: Justin O.

description:
Been here twice now and I have to say that I'm impressed.

The service here is always great. The owners also run Woodhouse Fish Co., and that restaurant features some of the best service I've ever had. You can tell a place is doing something right when they have happy, friendly staff and low turnover.

My wife had a Pali "Keefer's Ranch" 2011 Pinot Noir and I had an Almanac Fresh Hop: Chinook IPA. Both were excellent on their own and with our meals. They really know how to find new and interesting drinks to pair with their food.

The crab and avocado app was tasty yet simple, and the garnish of sprouts gave the overall feeling that I was eating the ultimate "California" appetizer more than a tex-mex inspired dish. Whatever, it was great.

The food is just plain good. My wife had the flat iron steak and I had Margaret's pork chop. The steak wasn't as good as she remembers from a few months ago; either they changed how they prepared everything or (more likely) it's a completely different menu item. It was still cooked to order (rare) and delicious. The pork chops were surprisingly moist and juicy; the mashed potatoes and veggies were a nice pairing; and I don't know what "Arkansas black apple sauce" is, but damn is it good. We finished everything off with a  chili-infused chocolate mousse with ginger cookies (which were a bit hard, honestly).

This isn't in our budget as a regular restaurant, but we'll definitely make a trip here a couple of times a year.
author: Chris H.

description:
This was an easy 5 star review.

First off, the restaurant looks fantastic. The decor is well thought out, there's a good flow, the bar looks great, and is set away from the dining area which I really like. It wasn't too loud, but it felt lively. 

We started out with drinks at the bar, both of which were excellent cocktails. 

For dinner, we started with Guacamole, which was super good with big chunks of avocado, and served with really good chips and their caesar salad, which had a really flavorful dressing.

My wife got the ribs and I went with the carnitas. They were both excellent. The ribs were the star of the night though, very tender, meaty, with a great glaze/sauce that didn't overpower the meat. Carnitas were served simply, with more guacamole and tortillas. 

Service was great, attentive and quick. Prices were very reasonable as well, all the entrees were a couple dollars lower than what I'd expect, can't complain about that, so a great value to boot. Overall, everything was fantastic and we'll be back.
author: Avi W.

description:
The waitress we had was a complete sweetheart! The bartender tall guy with beard was total A**hole, I don't say this lightly as we had a group of friends to have drink and snacks near the bar, we had a server but as people arrived we placed orders at the bar. My partner wanted something called a prickly pear okay I am a wine drinker don't know what that is he came back do you want salt on the margarita.  The confusion on my face jerk was thinking you got my order not a reason for you to roll your eyes, and slam the drink down when the server let us know we had a tab and i askedif it was alright to put everything on that tab.
I have spent years in hospitality, I get it her tip win is your loss this time.  But loyalty to a place and a great service staff goes a long and is very fruitfull overtime 
Take a clue!
author: David a.

description:
It had been too long since my wife and I had been to Pecos. Top-notch service and ambiance; killer, creative drinks; a great beer list and rich, creative food are what keep us coming back. Tonight's experience was just as amazing as ever and got me thinking about my first time. 

The first time was with my wife, my parents, and my 92 year-old grandma. I appetized myself  with asparagus and now I must order that every time I go to Pecos. Best asparagus. Ever. I had ribs for an entree and they were delicious - sweet with a little spice. 
The most impressive thing I noticed was that we were able to have a conversation  without raising our voices. The dining room was almost full, we were seated near the hostess stand and it still wasn't loud. Major points.

The second time was for an after-work drink with my sister. I had a Sidewinder and she had an Owl Hoot. The Sidewinder, apparently is a very refreshing beverage that will fuck you up if you drink two. Live and learn. And eat guacamole, which was fresh and chunky and when we ran out of chips the bar server brought us more without even having to ask. Service!

My most recent time was with 6 other good friends. We had a reservation (highly recommended - they get busy) for 7:00 and I think everyone actually showed up on time and we were seated right-away. I had a little taste of nearly everything and all was good, but I liked my steak the best. 

And the asparagus. Gotta have the asparagus.
author: Dave M.

description:
Overall, I liked the food (Southwestern) and I liked the drinks a little more.

Old Viejo (old old?) mezcal cocktail was a fun choice for the happiest hour -- smoky Mezcal is a nice after-work sipper -- and they also make a lovely house margarita.

Real-cheese queso (monterey jack and cheddar) with blue-corn chips: good. My Texan husband seemed to think it was A-OK, too.

Green chile cheeseburger is wrapped in a flour tortilla, and it comes with one big ol' green chile, with potatoes on the side. It's like a burger burrito, which, cool. Good also.

Terraza tostada salad had a nice mix of vegetables with theme-appropriate black beans and corn. Loved the dressing on this one.

The place has tons of atmosphere. I'd definitely bring my in-laws here -- who'd get a kick out of the scene -- or come back for drinks and apps at the bar, but maybe not another sit-down.
author: Tara R.

description:
This IS NOT tex mex, people. This is someone making california mexican and saying its tex mex.  The flavors were boring. The food was not made well.  The guac had chunks the size of half an avocado it it with no seasoning.  I ordered the ribs, I could barely get the meat off the bone and the sauce was just not good.  I will eat a lot of things that aren't perfect, but I only ate 2 of 6 ribs.  2!  It was that bad.

BTW I lived in texas from the age of 10-21.  The only redeeming quality of this place was the ambiance and the company.  Will not be going back.  I had such high hopes that a place would cut through all the california mex, but sadly I'm left hanging...

If you're going to open a mexican joint in the middle of the mission, it damned well better be excellent!
author: jessica b.

description:
Ate here for the first time tonight.
Service was quick and friendly
Food was really good.
The make your own lemonade was divine and fun to make.
author: jeffy e.

description: Well, I have to say I really enjoy the atmosphere. So much that I forgot to take any pics. The service was pleasant and the finger food incredible. The chorizo and cheese dish, agua fresca, and the drinks my sis had were great! The prices reasonable and the workers there were very polite and attentive. I will return!!!
author: Roger H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but I just can't say I did. 

The service was absolutely terrible. The waitress was forgetful and very slow. We ordered appetizers and nothing came. Then the waitress comes back and asks us if we would like to, "start with something?" So we re-ordered. The food came fast, too fast. So our drinks, appetizers and entrees were all on the table at once. No one came to clear our appetizers plates until the meal was finished. What a mess

The food was very good. No complaints there. But, when I consider the price and the terrible service, I won't go back. There is better in the neighborhood.
author: Mark F.

description:
- Service is great.  
- Ambiance is good.  Noise level is definitely at the decibel level that all Mission restaurants apparently need to achieve.
- Food prices are definitely within a reasonable range, although the drinks seem overpriced for what they are.
- Food is mostly bland.
author: Vandana N.

description:
I've been here on two separate occasions.  Once for apps and drinks and once more dor dinner.  We enjoyed our first time there and the people who worked there were nice.  Though there was a problem with my drink that they got wrong 3 times.  But aside from that it was fine.

The second time we were in a group of 6.  We were drinking, having fun, and we enjoyed the apps we shared like the potatoes and mac and cheese, and we enjoyed our food as well.  Most of us ordered the carnitas.  Though they were not loaded with flavor like in some other places, I thought they were pretty good considering.  One slight problem which was corrected, our orders were all cold when they were brought out.  A few of us were ok with it, but the others (including me), thought we should bring it to someone's attention and see if they could heat them up again.  The manageer came over and was very nice and apologetic about the whole thing.  He quickly brought us new and hot plates of carnitas and insisted we keep our original plates to take home and heat up later.  Sold!

Ther service is good, the ambiance is festive and kitschy and the food ain't too bad either.  I just think it's hard for a place like this to make it in a sea of amazing restaurants.  I think it's the equivalent of Chevy's or something.  But what do I know.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Great food!!! But customer service needs some work. It's the little things guys like not asking if ur done before you take my plate or bring the chips and guacamole out together. However the background music is amazing I love listening to led zeppelin while I eat!
author: Gabriel M.

description:
My original review was removed. I can only assume at the request of the owner because it was not specific enough. (Which I think is BS on Yelp's part)

The owner reached out to me after my review. He was cordial and seemed to honestly be looking for input to improve his restaurant.

Nonetheless, I do want our experience to be shared here on this forum. 

My wife and I were there a couple of weeks ago on a week night. I had originally planned to write the review as soon as I got home but got distracted so excuse the lack of specifics.

After walking in, there were two people at the host station and a mostly empty restaurant. For some reason they told us that we couldn't be seated. They offered us the bar. We looked at each other and thought it was strange but said ok. The full menu was not available at the bar. I don't recall exactly what we ordered and haven't looked back to confirm. Anyway, the food was not so special. The service was slow and disdainful. We both thought that the server wanted us to leave. The bar had a couple of other people but was slow. I thought maybe it was us? After we ate, which was quick once the food arrived we left and the place was still wasn't full. Anyway, the place looks great, perhaps we ordered badly and we caught our server on the wrong day. I'd be willing to come back and will edit my review if my experience is closer to most of the other reviews here.

EDIT: I've been back a few times in the 3+ years since I originally wrote the review. I really don't like the food. It is very bland and the margaritas don't have enough lime. I'm surprised by many of the rave reviews.
author: Raj T.

description: Other restaurants for brunch were about a half hour wait so my boyfriend and I happened to try this place out. It was surprisingly not crowded, we were seated right away, great atmosphere, quick and good service and the food was one of the best brunches I've had in SF. The maple pork belly side was so delicious!! I ordered the Austin style tacos and my boyfriend ordered the carrot cake French toast. It was really unique and amazing food and not even that expensive. Good quality and price. Definitely recommend this place for brunch. We left super full and happy!!!!
author: Ali R.

description:
I decided to take my mother to the City after she heard about this place somewhere.  1st of all I usually start judging similar places based on the Margaritas. So we both started with a house Margarita, which I admit was very good, although it came in a very small glass and was mostly ice! ($8)

We ordered, I had the Carnitas: They weren't typical carnitas because I found mine to be very dry, and unfortunately the only sauce to accompany it was some sort of Mole which was rather sweet and not very much. The avocado and corn relish accompanying it however was good. All in all not a very satisfying meal. NO HEAT WHATSOEVER! I Had to ask for some sauce because they don't give you any kind of salsa. Dry like I said.

Mom had  Albondigos   which is lamb and Chorizo meatballs in a broth. I tasted hers and agreed that although the meatballs were good, the broth wasn't and there wasn't enough to satisfy. 

I would not recommend this place unless you enjoy: small expensive drinks, small plates and a very stuffy environment in some trendy place,. No Thank You, I hope there are better places to eat in The Mission.
author: Chris W.

description:
In short, I ordered the pozole and I thought the base flavor was delicious and much spicier than the Cal-Mex variations that have been served to me at other restaurants or by my friend's mother, a native daughter of Texas now living in Bakersfield.

I ate at the bar and I struck up conversation with the main chef about the soup. I told him that I could always go for more hominy and that my friends momma always served sliced green cabbage and toasted tortillas on the side as garnish for the pozole. Drop these crunchy bits in for a a second and then chow down to enjoy some wild texture.

Within a minute then chef presented me with a small plate of cabbage and tortillas.

Five Stars, bitches.
author: Scott D.

description:
Wonderful new addition to the always expanding Valencia Restaurant Row. We didn't think that things could get any better than Beretta, Locanda, Bar Tartine or Range.

Much more of a party atmosphere, and big heaping helpings of very tasty Southwestern fare. Also very friendly and helpful servers.

Lots of delicious small plates, with veggies, fish and meat for everybody. And loved the cornbread in the hot skillet . . . We could have eaten that all night.

Nice to see that the Woodhouse Fish Company team is keeping busy keeping us all happy and well fed.
author: Dirk W.

description:
Meh. This place is totally average. 

Guac and chips - guac was ok, chips were bland
artichoke and crab ceviche - blanddddddd and small portion
fish fajitas - this was the only decent thing we had. The corn tortillas are delicious.

I dunno. It just didn't knock my socks off. Would rather go to Tacolicious a few blocks away and spend less $$.
author: Nicole M.

description: Good food, good margaritas, friendly and fast service.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Congratulations to Dylan, Rowan, Tyler and the West of Pecos staff for putting together this delicious and fun new restaurant on Valencia.

We had a table full of small plates that were very tasty. Can't wait to get back there for the rest of the menu.

Favorites of the night - Ceviche stuffed Artichoke, Skillet Cornbread, Pozole, Prawns, crusty Corn-on-the-cob, whole fish Fajitas . . . . All complimented with assorted Tequila on the rocks.
author: Mickey A.

description:
West of Pecos is another long awaited mediocre establishment. 

The food was terrible. Everything was overcooked. Our potatoes were fried till I could barely bite through it. The corn on the cob was soggy. The ceviche in asparagus was not a good flavor combination.

I was hoping it would at least be a decent watering hole, but we had two rounds of drinks and they were not worth the calories.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
The staff was a great.  The food was tasty..we started with the guacamole and the queso.  Both were delicious.  I had the carnitas, which were really good. Friends had the ribs, duck, albondigas, and the fish fajitas...all was really good.

What i don't care for here was the layout of the restaurant. We were seated in the side room which makes you feel closed off from the rest of the restaurant...just odd. Also, don't know why, but there were a bunch of bugs flying around...it's a pretty new restaurant..make sure the place is clean would you!

I will be back for the food
author: Dilly M.

description:
Another good addition to the Mission. West of Pecos is giant and gorgeous (which seems to be a theme among the newest additions to Valencia street). They have a very friendly staff and a big space for happy hours in the bar. The drinks were all great!

The one downside was our food -- maybe it was poor ordering on our part -- but my dining companion got the green chili burger, which sounds amazing on the menu. When it came, it was both too hot (temperature) and way too spicy to eat. We'd asked the waiter lots of questions about the dish and received no warning on the spice! I had the veggie dish, which was also way too (temperature) hot to eat. Not only when it arrived, but for a good 15 minutes afterward. 

Finally, although the staff is very friendly, it's hard to track them down when you need something. We'll give this place another shot -- maybe it's just new restaurant kinks to work out.
author: Gretchen S.

description: wow.  unreal queso/chorizo dip....I find myself thinking about this dip more often than I would like to admit.  This restaurant has a great atmosphere and style to it and the food is seriously delicious. I ate there last night and shared a green chile cheeseburger and alaskan cod fish tacos...so good! The plates look small, but I ended up bringing so much food home.  On top of the fantastic food they also have a very good and unusual variety of drinks at the bar.  I had the faith healer which is a type of aloe vera cocktail and it was so good I ended up having another.  This is a fantastic place to stop for dinner with a fantastic atmosphere.  If you happen to get a chance to talk to the manager tyler you will be able to see where this place gets all its personality from!
author: Ruth M.

description:
I was pretty excited to check this place out during opening week, and it did not disappoint!

- Astoundingly friendly service. Great decor too.
- House margarita had some awesome floral kicks and some real spice to it, but was really well balanced. Great drink.
- Shrimp taco-thingies (appetizer) were absolutely phenomenal.
- Fish fajitas also phenomenal.
- Best flour tortillas I've ever had (obviously homemade).

I have a feeling this place will be in the rotation for some time to come.
author: Chrix F.

description:
Had dinner here last night. Made an 8:30 reservation the day beforehand for four, but had to move it back a bit to 9 since we were running late. They were very courteous when taking in the reservation and updating the time change no issues. Came in were seated pretty much right away. Very nice lighting, big comfy booths good ambiance overall. It was pretty busy being a Friday night in the Mission but the owner (I believe) came over and helped us out with drinks before our waitress came to take our order. There were lots of options that all sounded tasty and since they said it was family style we got a few small plates and a few of the larger plates to share:
-corn on the cob
-mac &cheese
-cornbread
-tostada salad
-carnitas
-Crab and shrimp artichoke
-lamb and chorizio meatballs

Our meals came out within 20 minutes- and I was surprised since we had gotten the small plates first- but I figured they were just gonna bring it all out together. It ended up that our small plates actually went out to the wrong table. The waitress apologized several times- and put the order in right away. We were a bit bummed as all the food wasn't there to share - but the owner swung by again and apologized himself and comped the 3 starters we were missing which really was going the extra mile. I thought the food was good- the  cornbread was amazing!
But the service was awesome. You don't see a lot places like that in SF where they take ownership of bad experiences and fix it. Would recommend for that alone- Very large space- good for groups- we will be back :)
author: Nicole S.

description:
Fantastic! I love this place- so glad it came to the mission.

I feel the people that don't love the cornbread aren't eating it with the jalapeno butter. Ask for extra and slather it on there for the best cornbread experience of your life. 

The ribs are delish- I get them every time I come here.

And go for the carnitas- you won't be sorry. 

Ugg, I just made myself hungry writing this post.  Looks like I'm heading there again tonight.
author: Jordan F.

description:
I'm a compulsive Yelp user and check reviews for everything--restaurants, grocery stores, bars, laundry services, doctors, apartment rentals, etc--before I go myself. I'm ashamed to say that while I use Yelp on a daily basis this is my first review. (sorry!) 

First, I didn't expect this place to be authentic Mexican food at all. (I know my favorite burritos, tacos and salsa in town and would have headed there without a second thought.) My girlfriend and I were feeling nostalgic and were really aiming for basic tex-mex/american style food that we had growing up in the Midwest. The bar was low, guys. Long before I had real Mexican food, I grew up eating Chi-Chis, Chevy's, Don Pablos and Taco Johns. 

All four of those places are better than West of Pecos. The service was terrible. The place was maybe half full and we had to wait 10 minutes for a table. Okay, that's fine, we'll wait. After being seated and being given menus our server asked immediately if we were ready to order. We asked for a few minutes to decide. Apparently that was a big mistake. We didn't see her for another 15 minutes to get our drink order. By then we were ready to order our drinks, appetizers and our meals. 

We ordered margaritas, chips and guac/salsa, the steak fajitas, a salad and vegetable sides. Then the wait began. Literally nothing for 20 minutes. No drinks, no appetizers, no "this will be out shortly". Nothing. 20 minutes later they brought the margaritas, the chips, the guac, the salsa, the entrees and the sides all at the same time. The tiny table for two was completely full and the server was knocking things off trying to shove everything on us at once. 

As for the food:
-Nothing was seasoned. No salt on anything. 
-The steak sucked. We asked for medium rare and got rare on one end and medium well on the other. Completely flavorless. 
-Portions were tiny. For $21 the steak fajitas consisted of 4 slices of steak and a few pepper slices. They couldn't even bother to include onions. I'm used to overpaying for things in the Bay Area but come on.
-Salsa was terrible. We asked for the mild and the "spicy". I couldn't tell which one was supposed to be spicy... I asked for hot sauce or a side of jalapenos as well. Anything with some heat. They brought me 5 slices of pickled jalapenos that were also bland. 
-The elotes was $7 for an ear of corn that tasted completely like sour cream. Thanks for cutting it into 4 pieces--that's not a hot mess at all. 
-The guac was flavorless (salt seems to be a crime here) and consisted of large (1/4 of an avocado) sized chunks of under ripe avocados. 

Finally we gave up and tried to waive down the check (took another 10 minutes). We knew that we were stuck with overpriced and bland food but couldn't believe the extra charges on the bill. Our $10 chips and guacamole included a $2 up charge because we asked for salsa. Really? That was annoying considering all of it tasted bland/the same but the best was that they charged us $4 for three tortillas. There was really nothing to do but laugh at what a joke this place is.

Oh and then when we went to pay for all of this crap, the server disappeared and my girlfriend had to go and find her. Because of course. 

TL;DR Overpriced, bland food with terrible service. Chevy's and Taco Bell are lovely compared to this place.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
We were stoked to see WoP open last night, so after dinner #1 up the street, we stopped in for more food & drink. There is a lot of potential here & the entire staff seem very willing to make it happen. 
The drinks are stiff & made with precision, be amazed by the frosty chalis the draft beer comes in. All the glassware is cool actually.
We just had the prawns, which were a little awkward to eat, but delicious. We also had the arugula with goat cheese & sundried tomatoes, also good. To go we brought our friend the mac & cheese that comes with chiles & ham! We didn't sneak a taste unfortunately so you'll have to wait for his review.
I like the look & feel of the old Indian Bazaar, it's all reclaimed wood & very homey. 
I look forward to seeing this place thrive - and begin doing brunch down the road!
author: Colleen B.

description:
Pecos Punch is amazing. Reminds me of an alcoholic version of a cantaloupe aqua fresca (my fave). It's $8, and totally worth it although I'm not sure how much alcohol it has in it.

Went with a few coworkers after a team event and sat at the bar area. Nice because it's big, but you're limited to the bar menu which is rather pricey.

We got:

Chips & Guac -- good, fresh
Queso Dip with chorizo -- amaze, yummy, fattylicious
Duck Flautas -- didn't try
Cornbread -- ok, but nothing to write home about
Chicken Skewers -- alright

I might go back for chips, salsa, guac, queso dip and a pecos punch, but that's it.
author: Amber M.

description: I was really impressed with this place. Nice host. Great food (other than queso, which was tasteless and small portion - I KNOW queso). Ribs, carnitas, and cornbread were all top notch. Nice waitress. They did a brilliant job of the space to boot.
author: Andrew K.

description:
We ate there last night with my wife and parents. We had ressies and we were seated immediately. All told, we had 7 different dishes. The cornbread, ribs, and hangar steak were all excellent. The duck flautas, arugala/goat cheese salad, and scorched corn were very good. The veggie dish was mediocre, and the beans that came with the veggies (not the drunken beans) were extremely bland and not worth eating.
Service was friendly but a little slow. Space was very cool, particularly the entrance way to the restaurant - which will be nice if you have to wait for a table. It has a few kinks to work out, but we'll definitely be back for more good Tex Mex food and cocktails.
author: Scott G.

description:
We were one of the first customers when they opened. I have been to restaurants when they firs open and it's often a hit or miss affair. For example, Gracias Madre has terrible cardboard-like tortillas when they first opened but they were soon perfected.

So we ordered the corn on the cob and it was bursting with flavor and a great starter. 

We shared the grilled veggies and they were also really high quality greens and cooked and presented just so. The other big dish we tried was the fish - lightly fried and plenty big. cooked to tender perfection.

I did not try the cocktails but the bartenders were fun to chat with and I made a mental note of their creative drinks to try later.

Service was smooth and energetic - I could see that these folks are excited to start a new venture and happy to be in such a beautifully designed space. My joke is that it's "west of weston wear" but of course it's not hard to find.

My suggestion is to find some selection of southwestern peppers and make a unique dish along those lines since that's my favorite memory of the southwest. Also, I would have more to try here if there were more vegetarian options. I look forward to seeing how their menu evolves.
author: ari s.

description: Yes this place is expensive for small plates of tex-mex but they are tasting and the drinks are refreshing.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Great drinks, good mix of crowd, reasonable prices for drinks. Will definitely have to come back for food.
author: Claudine V.

description: We've been here for dinner a few months ago and came back today for Sunday brunch after a walk in the neighborhood. Wow!! Was i delighted! Now lactose free, dining out is sometimes challenging. Today I ordered pork belly Austin tacos, with no cheese. My oh my!! The BEST tacos ever! Two flour tortillas (just the right size and delish) with scrambled eggs, pork belly, sliced avocado, light salsa and amazing aioli! Honestly, my favorite taco, fantastic breakfast/brunch. I paired it with sangria--okay well, two sangrias--but it was noon when we arrived. I am already plotting my return... Quite possibly next weekend!!
author: Marilyn S.

description:
Worthy of a Pulitzer Prize for eloquence in short-form menu writing, the creators of West of Pecos clearly are aiming very high with this sleek, sprawling spot in a bustling part of the Mission.  Ultimately, the food satisfies but doesn't excel, and the mouth-watering menu sounds a good measure better than the results coming from the kitchen.  

Of the range of items we tried, the scorched corn on the cob with sweet chile crema was the best, a take on traditional elote with a pleasantly balanced sweet and smoky feel.  We also enjoyed the grilled asparagus with ancho chile hollandaise and bacon, though the hollandaise overwhelmed the asparagus a bit, and I tend to think that the best asparagus dishes don't need so much jazzing up.

Our carnitas were "hearth roasted", not pan-fried and crispy as with other versions, and the result was a less flavorful but more moist dish.  The generous portion of avocado/tomato/cotija "salsa" on the side was intriguing but lacked much punch.  The homemade corn tortillas on the side?  To die for.

We were less impressed with the green chile macaroni and cheese, a good concept with a startling lack of flavor.  We added salt to make it somewhat interesting.  Even with a plethora of intriguing ingredients, the Terraza Tostada Salad had too much going on and didn't really work.  What was advertised as creamy chive dressing ended up being, mostly, an awkward blob of sour cream underneath the salad.  

I appreciate what this place is trying to do, and I may well go back, minding my own caveats - there were a lot of other tasty looking dishes on the menu, and in the hands of servers passing us by.  I just won't expect to be blown away, and I'm sure I'll leave with a smile.
author: Derek W.

description:
After a long day of hiking and searching for my lost discs in Golden Gate park, West of Pecos was the perfect place to eat.  

The service was attentive without being overbearing, the atmosphere was really nice without being posh, and the food... well, the food was AWESOME.

We decided to start with the Green Chili Mac and Cheese and some Sopaipillias with Honey.  My friend said that he can't stand Mac and Cheese when it is too rich.  Needless to say, the green chili was what you tasted first, and the cheese second.  The Sopaipillias were amazing.  Just the right combination of sweet and flakey, we each at ours with only a few bites.  You have to order the Sopaipillias with your meal.  

For our big dishes we were told that the Ribs and Carnitas were the best things on the menu.  My Amigo got the carnitas, and ate every last bite.  The ribs are wonderful.  I have never had a pork rib that was individually prepared before now, and it made me question my cooking style.  Each rib was like a candied barbeque pork lollypop, or some nonsense like that. Seriously, they were super delicious.  

The biggest treat was dessert.  The Sopaipillia with ice cream and caramel was so good it disappeared in one bite.  The flourless chocolate cake was also very tasty, but as I am not gluten free it wasn't my favorite of the two treats that we enjoyed.  Each dessert was garnished with some fresh raspberries that were the perfect way to end the meal.  

I never got to try any of their drinks as I was driving, but looking at what was on the menu I have got to return.  Great place, great service, wonderful atmosphere, delicious food, I am assuming great drinks, and we got out of there for about 30 bucks a piece.  Five stars, all the way.
author: Allen W.

description:
Wow, this place is like a Texas theme park version of Texas. Western shirts and all. I am from Texas and I have to say I loved it there. They have Queso!! No, in the Texan sense Queso is not just cheese. It's one of the things that sets Tex-Mex apart from all other versions of Mexican food. If you know what I'm talking about you will be very pleased. 
  I had the cheese burger. Don't let the whole english muffin thing deter you, as it almost did for me. Initially I thought it would be gross. But, well, when I tasted this thing literally the whole time I was eating my mind was saying "WTF? W..T..F..." It was SO good. Best burger in town.
author: Johna G.

description: The burger was of average taste. Nothing special. The fish tacos were good, price to high for what you get. Atmosphere was good(had a western style vibe). Food over all seems expensive. In my opinion price doesn't match quality of what I ate. Not a bad experience over all.
author: Matthew F.

description:
Took my mom and her friend visiting from Australia here because I love the food/margaritas and there was also an event going on nearby we were going to after. Food was great as always but service was lacking. It honestly felt like our "hipster" waitress assumed we were all from out of town and acted really annoyed we weren't local. I personally live 2 blocks from there and have never been treated that way until I bring my mother there, who was obviously asking about the menu and how she liked working in the Mission. My mom is super sweet and the girl was utterly annoyed.

Of course, we wanted a picture with our Aussie friend, and she dryly took the photo and walked away. Did I mention we were one of TWO tables in the entire bar at 5pm on a Wednesday? My mom wanted to post her picture online so I asked the waitress for another round of drinks and the wifi password please.

She stared at me, uttered "um..I don't know" and then literally never came back to our table. 

I won't be going back. West of Pecos, you're not THAT cool.
author: J K.

description: The queso is an addictive drug, so delicious. Service is still awesome. 2 things: Please bring back that delicious frozen sangria/margarita like NOW , and that lobster enchilada maybe needs to take a vacation and try something else in it's place. The flavor profile was meh. But I have had so many YES moments at your establishment I ride hard for West of Pecos
author: Lauren V.

description:
Came down to the Mission to hit up Craftsman & Wolves (see their review too) and decided to stay for a late dinner. West of Pecos looked good, busy but not too packed at 7:30pm. We were seated right away, but unfortunately the spot was an itty bitty table directly behind the hostess stand... not exactly all that comfy and loud with the commotion of other diners coming in and out of the restaurant. 

Seating aside, the service was attentive and we ordered guacamole to start and their chips are quite good, the guac could have used a bit more salt but that's probably personal preference. I got the Texas Ribs which had an ancho pepper/apricot sauce that was very nice, not too hot and not too sweet (the slaw on the side was sloppy but I was really only interested in the ribs anyway). Husband got the Green Chile Cheeseburger and he loved it, said it was cooked perfectly but the fries that came along with it weren't all that great. 

I guess when it comes down to it, their main dish is well executed and interesting but their sides need a bit of work. 

With all the restaurants on Valencia, there are probably better options than West of Pecos if you're any bit of a food snob.
author: Littany W.

description:
Came here last night with a party of 4, although we only had reservations for 2. They told us the wait would be 30-45 minutes but it was more like 15-20. They texted us when the table was ready. Yay for exceeding expectations!

I love the decor. Beautiful open kitchen. The heavy seats at the tables are hard to move around, but are really comfortable. It was really busy and loud inside, but surprisingly we could still hear each other just fine.

They had no problem with us ordering family style. We got a bunch of stuff and liked everything:
--Albondigas: My favorite. Super flavorful. I would've liked these to be served with a spoon, though, 'cause there was tons of tasty sauce.
--Ribs: Really great. Perfectly cooked and not gristly or fatty at all. They call them "messy" but they aren't really at all.
--Cornbread: I'm not normally a cornbread fan and I thought this was fantastic. Super crispy and sweet-and-savory at the same time.
--Corn tortillas: Really good, clearly handmade. Perfect accompaniment to the albondigas.
--Corn on the cob: Novel and flavorful, really good but not mindblowing.
--Mac and cheese: I loved the cheese mixture in this, but thought it could be more well-seasoned. It was also supposed to have ham in it but I didn't notice any.
--Green chilies: These were good, but nothing special.

Our waitress was super friendly and personable. I didn't get her name but she had really cute long braids. 

Before I came here, I thought they seemed a little overpriced, but after seeing all the care taken with presentation, service, etc. etc., I think it's a really great value for a nice dinner out with friends. With 1 drink a person + tip, it came to less than $20 a person.

I will be back to try more!
author: Lynae Z.

description: Meh. If you're from Texas, you will be disappointed. Nothing is as flavorful as it should be. The menu looks great, but the food and margaritas don't deliver. I was really hoping it would be different. Still searching!
author: JJ F.

description:
This place is OK. I don't know what the hoopla is all about! 

GREEN CHILE MAC N' CHEESE - 4 stars - a tex mex variation of an american classic and pretty darn good too!

CRAB & SHRIMP STUFFED ARTICHOKE - 3 stars - this dish was mediocre! def. not a signature dish of the restaurant. you can def. pass on this one as you won't be missing much!

MESSY TEXAS RIBS - 1 star - these were the worst ribs I've ever eaten at a restaurant. why you might ask? because they were cold! eating cold ribs is not very yummy!

CAMPFIRE CORNBREAD MUFFIN SKILLET - 5 stars - Oh my lord!!! This would be the single reason why I would come back to West of Pecos. The best cornbread I've ever had! If you dine here, you MUST order the cornbread skillet! So moist, so tasty, so delicious! 

OUTDOOR TABLE BY FIREPLACE & HEATER - 5 stars - this is why i'm giving West of Pecos 3 stars instead of 2 stars b/c there are not many places in the Mission District that offer you outdoor patio seating w/ fireplace and a heat lamp over your head! The ambiance is so much nicer than the inside!

I think my overall experience would have been better if I ordered something else besides the ribs and stuffed artichoke. Def. worth a try if you're craving Tex Mex!
author: Victor C.

description: Amazing pulled pork pies and guacamole! Cocktails are even better too- try the pisco punch and the house margaritas. Prompt and super friendly service. Worth a visit!
author: Tamara S.

description: Honestly I don't remember their food, but their Arnold Palmer is a Tejava (one of my favorite bottled teas!) and lemonade that you can mix to your heart's content, which I found delightful. I'd go back for that.
author: Keito U.

description: The carnitas tacos where just amazing! Not such big fans of the fish tacos or the chunky guacamole (I prefer regular guacamole). But we will definitely be coming back. It has a great atmosphere and good service.
author: Clara V.

description:
Good drinks- the margarita (house) was very good. Great wine/beer selection as well.

Food was good- we had:
-Cornbread: heaven- seriously, like pancakes. Delicious. YUM.
-Heirloom Tomato Salad: Decent- unremarkable, but fresh goods, so ok.
-Duck: Supposed to be infused with Lavendar- not sure that I'd like that, but I certainly didn't taste that. Was totally fine duck with little extra flavor. Unremarkable but not bad.
-Chicken: Ditto- well-prepared, but unremarkable.
-Albongidas: Yummy- I would do this again, but I'd suggest they give a bread to dip and a spoon.
-Ribs: A hit- I didn't try, but my table mate loved them.
-Cowboy beans: As someone who rocks beans, this was disappointing to me, but fine for the table. Could use some TLC on the overall flavor.

Serivce was great- atomsphere is kind of suburban at its best. Refreshing in a way for this suburban kid raised and now in the city (albeit for 20 years).

We liked it- hopefully they can take all of this top notch cooking up to applying real special flavors that differentiate the food itself.
author: Chuck H.

description:
I have only come here for brunch, but about a dozen times now.

I come for the Sangre del Toro, it's delicious.

The artichoke is great and so is the queso.

I have enjoyed every visit, the staff is super nice too!
author: Jen T.

description:
I LOVED this place, my dining compadres felt medium about it...probably because I out ordered them all. I got the ribs. Go there, get the ribs, you will be SO happy. 

I also recommend the guac--it has corn in it, awesome! Also really liked the cornbread, it came with a little pitcher of a molasses based sauce that was delicious.

Also really enjoyed my marg. Would go back, no problem.
author: Colin S.

description:
Sooooo delicious, I had the pork chop it was amazing! And I'm typically not the meat lover but that meat just incredible! I would definitely recommend it to my friend! 
Plus the atmosphere is really great, you feel like you enter a Wild West cowboy bar!
author: Valentine C.

description: Took a family from out of town thought it would be a fun alternative to a more casual taqueria....if the kids don't like the mac and cheese there is something wrong. If the vegetarian sends the vegi food back...something else is wrong. I felt terrible for bringing them here. If it is the case that one has to order particular items to enjoy the food here...something is wrong.
author: Sarah w.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 2/5
Atmosphere: 5/5
Value: 3/5
Total: 3/5

Cool place, very nice vibe. I really liked the food, to my surprise. The meat was very well cooked (i.e. not dry, tender) and flavorful. Note that I'm French and don't have much tex-mex experience, nor do I need strong favors to taste something. The menu was original, I was very curious about several dishes.

The service ruined it for me though... The lady seemed to not really care, she would drop a plate on our table without even looking in our direction, once she walked by and emptied the very bottom of a pitcher of water in my already full glass without caring to look my way or slowing down her course. Please don't use my glass to finish your pitchers.

When I asked for a box, she took my dish and put it in a small box, without all the side salad and veggies. When I asked about it, she admitted "they" (?) had not put the salad in it, but she offered to bring some, which she did. No apologies though, and she wouldn't have told me anything, had I not verified. Overall the service felt disdainful.

The food was good but because of the bad service, the high prices don't land well. I don't like pretentious places. I regret it wasn't better because I wanted to like West of Pecos more. I may try it again... We'll see.
author: Olivier C.

description:
Fun, open layout.   Came for a girls dinner out and it was great because we could share a whole bunch of dishes to taste a variety of items.  Some really interesting dish combinations that we had to try just cause.  Most dishes were flavorful.   Our server was super friendly and very helpful.

Three stars cause it's super loud and really hard to have conversations with everyone at your table.
author: Mabelle A.

description:
Update: had dinner with a gf and the service was bad this time. Server definitely forgot to put our order in. We waited extra long and when we asked him we got no apology or explanation. He just acted like we never ordered that dish...i saw a bunch of the workers and mgmt look over at our table but no one really seemed concerned...so the service is a bit inconsistent. Crap happens, I get it,but I was majorly disappointed and put off. I don't plan on visiting again anytime soon.

Met with a friend for brunch after a crazy night out. I got the chilaquiles and a bloody Mary. My meal was great and the Bloody Mary had a chipotle kinda kick to it.
The owner, Tyler came and had a convo with my friend. He was super rad and down to earth as was the entire staff. I had a good time and I hope this place sticks around for a long time .
author: Yvonne Q.

description: If I lived in the neighborhood I would be coming here a lot for happy hour. Tasty cocktails and tortilla chips. Overall solid food. My only critique is that the restaurant interior is a bit too dark.
author: Alex T.

description:
Went there last night around 9pm and did not have a reservation. After waiting about 10 minutes we got seated!! 

The drinks and the food great. I did not have high expectations, as there are so many places opening in the Mission these days, but I was greatly surprised.
