I would recommend the "Crumbled Goat Cheese & Wild Arugula" - simply devine - the dried tomatoes was a good surprise. The "Pollo Asado Al Carbon" (half chicken) was delicious - well seasoned! We had the campfire cornbread skillet and was so yum, had to take the rest home.

Go check out this place. I think they are still fining their feet with service, but the food and the atmosphere was awesome. Planning to go back soon.
author: David V.

description: Stumbled in on a Sunday evening and we were immediately seated. The vibe was super relaxed and right away the staff was friendly and inviting. We ordered about 4 appetizers and a few drinks.. the bacon wrapped prawns were AMAZING. The menu often changes. I'd defintely go back and try a whole new set of appetizers as we were pleased with everything on our table. We left feeling satisfied and happy.
author: Cena V.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more. I read about West of Pecos on Eater SF and they mentioned that the same guy that owns woodhouse owns it. I really like woodhouse and go there often (it's near my place) so I figured I'd like West of Pecos. Also, when I tried to go there a few times, it was really hard to get a reservation so I assumed the place was great. Unfortunately, that wasn't the case.

I went today and things started off well. My boyfriend and I got a huge margarita and chips with queso. The queso had chorizo in it and was wonderfully spicy. The margarita was light and really refreshing, but the serving size was a little deceptive. It came in this huge glass with 2 straws so it looked huge enough for the two of us, but was filled with large pieces of ice so it went really fast.

Next up, we got the green chile mac and cheese and the duck flautas. Both were pretty under-seasoned. The mac and cheese was good, but would have been incredible with more salt. The duck was pretty underwhelming. It tasted like it had no spice in it. The best part of the flautas was the fire roasted tomato on the side, which was perfect.

Next we got the lamb albondigas. These had the opposite problem. There was so much paprika and chilli in it that we found ourselves coughing with every other bite (and we're South-Asian, so we're used to smokiness and heat!). We only had one each and packed the rest to go, figuring we could put them over rice at home to tone them down.

Dessert was the tres leches flan. It was decent, but again could have benefited from a little bit of salt to bring out the flavors.

On another plus side, the staff was excellent. Our waitress was really friendly and had great recommendations and the bussers were fantastic.

Again, I REALLY wanted to like this place. It's walkable from my apartment and I love tex-mex. But I feel really let down, and I'm not sure I would recommend it.
author: Saad A.

description:
I came in here with some friends looking to pass some time.  It happened to be during Pride weekend and most places in the Mission were crowded and overwhelmed.  I had never heard of West of Pecos but it looked a little more relaxed, so we thought we'd give it a try.  There was a large bar area, and even though all the seats were taken, it didn't take long for some to open up.  The drink menu had a good selection, and the food smelled great.

I ordered a shirley temple for my friend who wasn't drinking alcohol, and was shocked that the bartender said they didn't have any grenadine.  I don't know if they were out or if they don't stock it, but the bartender got creative and made a shirley temple with prickly pear juice...it actually tasted pretty good, and we loved the ingenuity.  

I ordered the prickly pecos margarita at the bartender's recommendation, and couldn't believe how disgustingly sour it was.  Every sip I took, I literally couldn't stop myself from making the "wow that's sour" face.  The serrano pepper in the drink was actually a good flavor compared to the sour, and I don't normally like spicy.  I definitely wouldn't order this drink again, but it just wasn't for me.

Instead, I wish I had gotten the mezcal mule, which I saw someone drinking after I ordered.  That seems to be the specialty of this restaurant, and it comes in a metal cup which just seems different.  Next time I will get that, and stay for dinner too!  It's always nice to see a new restaurant, especially when they're trying something new for the area.  I hope they do well, and look forward to coming back!
author: Gabrielle L.

description:
Tex-Mex is wonderful- when done right. The owners of West of Pecos did a fantastic job in making this place authentic and the menu a perfect blend of gourmet and comfort food. I recommend the cornbread and any of the cocktails, especially the Pecos Punch. 

The decor is fantastic- new but entailing a Southwest/Texas charm and ruggedness. One of the highlights was one of the owners bringing the check to our table- something every owner should try to do. He was friendly and seemed to genuinely appreciate our business.

The feeling was mutual.
author: Hannah B.

description:
This review is for the bar menu.

Decided to try this place after being given a 45 minute wait for Locanda. WofP also gave us a 45 minute estimate but the hostess told us that bar seating may be open. We got a nice cocktail table by the window and settled down to eat.

Decor: I really love the theme and large open space. The place wasn't too dark (maybe because we were sitting by the window) and there was plenty of room to walk around. I really appreciate restrooms with sinks that don't require me to touch any part of the basin or faucet when I'm washing my hands.

Service: When she finally got around to us service was excellent. Food came out quite fast and water was always refilled.

Food: Eugene and I ordered four small plates. 

Stuffed artichoke ceviche: Great smoky flavor and decent portion size. Comes with a small salad with a vinaigrette that packs a tiny kick. We were a little unsure about how to eat this but the dish was delicious.

Green chile mac and cheese: Not too cheesy but the dish lacked flavor. I would suggest more salt and some hot chili flakes to spice the dish up.

Potatoe wedges: For some reason I thought these were mashed potatoes. The dish comes with a sausage cheese sauce but this also needed salt and some kick. The wedges themselves were seasoned well with parmesan and sea salt.

Ribs: Ribs were very good. They were not the best ribs I've ever had (that title goes to Phil's in SD) but the dish was quite enjoyable. Just the right bit of tangyness but I would have like more wood smoked flavor.

West of Pecos is a nice place to bring your friends but be prepared to shell out some $ if you want to get full. I wish my dishes packed a little more punch. P.S. Don't be scared to ask for salt.
author: Stephanie W.

description: This was my first visit to West of Pecos, but I went with a friend who loves the fried chicken there. Service was friendly and prompt with pre-dinner cocktails & appetizers. And then our main courses never made it to the table. There were two servers attending us; one great, the other hopeless. Wires were obviously crossed, and when the good server finally got back to our table, she said our dinner order had never been put in. She apologized profusely & offered another round of drinks while we waited for our meals to be prepared. Very nice offer, but we were charged for these "another 15 minute wait on top of an already 20 minute wait" cocktails. Our main dishes were good; nothing stellar. Some portions were small; others were not. Most food items were overpriced; especially the slow-roasted pork enchilada with virtually no meat in the very, very small enchiladas. And they charged extra for rice & beans to accompany this already miniscule "dinner!" Will some restaurateurs never understand the importance of consistently good service & food before they have to close their doors forever? Needless to say, I will not be returning to West of Pecos.
author: Gordy J.

description: This is definitely my go to restaurant. It started as a date night spot for my husband and me, and soon became not only a spot for the family, but also a spot to meet for business. The food is sophisticated and diverse enough to accommodate all occasions. Same goes for the environment and the staff. Definitely try the prickly pear margarita and the Mexican cornbread with the side of warm molasses. YUM! You will not be disappointed :)
author: Vivian R.

description:
We overdid it on the chips and queso (sent back once since it had meat bits on top that we didn't know it came with...)--delicious!  Drinks were top of the line.
I had the chilies rellenos and thought it was fabulous.  Friendly service, great drinks and pricey but I thought it was worth it!
author: Jill B.

description:
My absolute favorite restaurant in SF right now. Period. I've tried around 10 dishes so far and they are ALL near perfection. The seasoning and concoctions are pretty amazing. I love menus that think outside the dining box and this place certainly does that! The drinks are also so interesting and worth a try. I'm not big on drinking beer/cocktails unless they're really sweet (it's my tastebud's fault I promise!) but my friends who have tried their bar menu have all really enjoyed tasting each drink. The bartenders have all been great to order from as well.

The staff is always exceptional. Smiles, greeting, checking in on their tables, able to accommodate their customers. Their text-reservation system is GREAT. We walked in on a busy Saturday night and was told their was at least a 45 min wait, we put down our name and headed over to Blondie's for a drink. We "pardners" (hah!) were texted 20 mins later with an open spot! Really good and new kind of system. 

The decor is one of my favorite aspects here. I'm a sucker for chic interior decoration and this place rides that fine line most country western/tex-mex restaurants fail to find. There's no cheesiness here. Except...for maybe the security cameras that have little cowboy hats on...and if you don't think that's hilarious than you have no soul haha. Always something new to look at. 

The average restaurant-goer here are 30's and uber professional. A group next to us were discussing their upcoming trip to Sundance for example. Each table and party I've witnessed in the background have all been polite and respectful. I have yet to see any young trashy college party-ers here like a previous reviewer mentioned. 

The only negative aspects that I could find from my own personal experiences were that the fries and ketchup together were too spicy (to enjoy the actual flavor) and when on a romantic date next to the fires in the available outdoor spots out front, we encountered "the Mission." Being pandered for money, a rude hipster walked up to our table, stood between us and our waiter, grabbed our table candle, and lit his joint, smell of urine, ciggy smoke, crazy people, drunks, etc. This of course is at NO fault of the restaurant. But we definitely know for the future to dine inside. 

Great service. Different menu. Chic western decor. Interesting drinks. Easy location to get to. And pure yumminess!
author: Aura O.

description:
Slow boat to China

I would have given this a higher star rating since this is our second time here.  the food is great.   But the service? 20 plus minutes to receive our appetizers, than another 20 plus minutes for our dinner.

The manager finally came up and apologized for the delays that  due to a large group ahead of us the kitchen was backed up.  Our waitperson never acknowledged the issue.

We completely understand situations arise, let your customers know.  We won't be back..
author: Mark S.

description:
Being the same week as WWDC13, it was difficult getting a booking at a few places our group of friends wanted to visit. 

West of Pecos had a table and, in an act of serendipity, we ended up enjoying one of the nicer nights out since dining at Frances last week. The food, service and fit-out of the dining room and adjoining bar are great.

My pick of the cocktails is the Devil's Tooth. After tasting mine, two of my friends ordered the same and one wrote down the ingredients as she wants to try and recreate it when we're home again in Melbourne. If it's even half as good, we'll be happy.
author: Mathew K.

description: I went to this wonderful restaurant with my two girlfriends for Sunday brunch this weekend and we enjoyed everything about this place. The food was out of this world, the service was great - what else would you ask for! :) And the interior design is very cute. I will recommend this place to all my friends. Great job guys! :)
author: Tetiana G.

description:
This is my first ever Yelp review, and my incredible meal at West of Pecos is what finally inspired me to open a Yelp account. The food is top quality and unique and the prices are good. Everything this place does -- from the cocktails to the brunch menu -- is its own unique creation and you won't find another menu in the city that is quite like it.

For those of you who are looking for a new brunch location this is your spot! While many mediocre and overpriced brunch places have waits of an hour or more, West of Pecos seated us right away at a table looking out over Valencia street. Perfect spot for those of you who like to watch the city go by while your contemplating your weekend and chatting with friends. The stuffed poblano and the New Mexico style eggs benny were two of the best breakfast items I've had (and I've spent the last 8 years frequenting the many brunch destination around SF).

Very clear five star food, service and ambiance at West of Pecos!
author: Jason Y.

description: I'm always surprised why this place isn't always packed, but I Iove that I can always get a table without waiting. They have amazing fish tacos, but we opted for different menu options this time around. The chile mac and cheese has a great kick but isn't overwhelming. We also had the tuna poke tacos which could have had more flavor and we're very small. The lobster enchiladas are tasty and had plenty of lobster, so it was worth getting. Lastly, we had the churros, which are delicious. The dough is slightly undercooked but the outside is nice and crispy. It's served with caramel and chocolate sauce for dipping, and was a great end to the meal!
author: Sam W.

description: Boooooring! Chile relleno was flavorless. Cornbread was wet and tasteless. Pork trio was both over- and under-spiced, and the beans were hella-salty. Not worth the money.
author: Chris W.

description:
I'll start off with the disclosure that I love Southwestern/New Mexican cuisine.  The first time I had green chile soup, didn't realize that my mouth would be on fire moments later but strangely enough, I keep coming back for more.

So naturally, I was super excited upon hearing of West of Pecos opening (by the Woodhouse Fish Co folks).  Then I was even more excited reading the menu online - green chile mac & cheese, green chile burger.

Maybe my expectations were through the roof but I left feeling a little disappointed.  The mac & cheese was fine but nothing spectacular other than a scoop of green chile that my friends carefully avoided after their first unexpected bite of fiery heat.

Likewise, the green chile burger was not what I expected.  Burger patty with a big piece of green chile covered in a tortilla (instead of a bun).  Didn't mind the unusual take of the burger but I just thought the patty was dry and the chile wasn't that impressive.

But to end on a good note, I did have a bite of the sopaipilla (puff pastry sprinkled with honey) with ice cream, which was delicious and brought back memories of my time in Albuquerque and Santa Fe.
author: F. P.

description:
Nice casual atmosphere and pretty good food. One of the main reasons I come here is because they are the only place in SF that makes a true tex mex style chips and queso......soooooo gooood. The chicken is ok and the ribs are good, not spectacular but good. and the cesar salad is good but kind of a rip off, they barely put anything in it!! The side of creamed corn is amazing!!

overall : good, but GREAT if your looking for some 
artery-clogging-deeeelicious-chips-n-queso
author: L V.

description: Great first experience! First of all, the place is HUGE, which is extremely unusual for the Mission. I came with two of my girlfriends and we had an amazing waiter, who told us all about the history of the place and the owners and did a fantastic job describing all of the drinks and food and even tailoring the orders to our preferences (I think his name was Adam, but he was awesome!).  I love love loved the prickly pecos marg and had the pollo asado al carbon.  The portions were huge and I finished about 2/3, but will 100% be coming back to try the ribs!  There is also a bar area with TV's, so I could def come back to watch some games here in the fall.
author: Raina D.

description:
I always have a great time when I come here. The service is warm, the food is delicious, and they have a really creative drink menu. Recently I've been loving the Lobster Enchiladas, Brussel Sprouts, and the Tuna Crudo Tacos. The Flama Verde is my go-to cocktail.   

I think the main reason why I love coming here is because of the atmosphere they've created. It's just a fun place to be! And comfortable. It's a great place to post up for a while with some friends.
author: Kelly H.

description: Nothing quite like a Mescal cocktail for brunch. Menu is focused and simple. Eccentric and pretty well done. Service is very inconsistent.
author: Nicolas E.

description: Went to West of Pecos last night and left very underwhelmed. I've been there in the past, maybe a year ago, and the food was super tasty. But last night...it just wasn't. The service was slow as well. Margaritas were mediocre. They've got so much potential, hope they can find they're groove again.
author: Erin L.

description: This place is terrible for refusing service to a group of 9 people. You would think that a restaurant would want business like that. Even when we asked if we could split up and sit at different tables the hostess still said no. The hostess was incredibly rude and I will not be back.
author: Mandee J.

description:
yum. 

this is one of my favorite go-to places in the Mission. the bartenders are great, attentive, friendly, and skilled in their drink-making wizardry. i'm a big fan of their Devil's Tooth cocktail, and as i write this, i am wishing that i had one.

stopping by here for happy hour is a treat. they have cheap tacos and a cheap margarita up for grabs at happy hour (i recommend the chicken tacos, just sayin').

this is also a great place to go to for brunch on the weekends. the polenta and chorizo is a must have.

the servers are attentive, know the menu, and are really good at what they do. it's always a pleasure to come here.
author: meeks b.

description:
Recently hosted two friends from out of town and they were blown away. Vegetable soup was the best I've had. Friends commented on the chicken skewers which are skewered with actual rosemary sprigs - awesome touch. 

Have been back since for other occasions. Wait staff is super friendly and the ambiance is perfect for friends, date, or just drinks at the bar.

Highly recommended.
author: Matt W.

description:
Since my last review, I have been a few more times. This place is winning me over. I added another star. They are continuously adjusting the menu and really finding a sweet spot. The staff is accommodating to large and small groups alike. Their small plates come off the grill with in short order, and sometimes you just need to reorder the last thing you had because it was so damn good. Right now the Lobster enchiladas are all mine, I could eat them for days. You might want to order your next drink after your first sip though. 

 Walked in off the street. The host was able to seat us right away. Nice looking cozy interior. Our waitress came over and asked if we wanted drinks. We ordered some cocktails and an appetizer. The appetizer arrived way before our drinks, both delivered by other staff. None the less the mac and cheese was very tasty, love the jalapeño kick. But our waitress still hadn't come back to take our dinner order by the time we had finished our mac and cheese she was no where to be seen. The rest of the meal left a bit to be desired after the menu looked very promising. The pork chop was over cooked and but the mash and apple underneath was very nice. The artichoke was under cooked and the shrimp was obviously frozen and kind of soggy mush, but the citrus aioli was nice. I will visit this place again, hopefully to bump up my review. Maybe it was an off night.
author: Carl P.

description:
Brave of them to open right next door to my favorite restaurant in the entire city, Puerto Alegre! 

I can't claim to know a lot about food in Texas, having only eaten a few times in Austin, but I really enjoyed our food. I'm looking forward to going back again and trying the queso dip and some other dishes!

My drink was also great (Mescal Mule), and I was really jealous of my date's Chile Relleno. Plus, the staff was super nice! Could maybe do with a little yes "Yahawing" though ;)
author: Veronica B.

description:
My good friend and I decided to grab some dinner before he flew off for two months of globe trekking. It was a surprisingly warm summer type evening in November and all the restaurants along Valencia were packed with people in shorts and t-shirts enjoying cocktails. Our original destination (Tacolicious) was something like a 2 hour wait, so we worked our way back towards the car looking for another place. I think both of us had Mexican food on the brain, so we gravitated towards West of Pecos which looked like it had some room at the bar. 

At first, I was a little hesitant to eat at West of Pecos because it looked a little bit like a chain restaurant with its instant TexMex deocrations. Don't get me wrong, I don't mean that in a necessarily bad way. The place is very nicely decorated and clean and inviting, but I kind of like eating off the beaten path a little when I'm in the Mission. Anyway, I couldn't have been more wrong. We sat at the bar and both of us ordered the carnitas. The dinner came with a very generous serving of roasted pork in a delicious barbecue red sauce with a side of avocado and freshly made tortillas. The whole thing was really delicious and my friend who is a bit of a restaurant snob even gave it a resounding thumbs up. 

Our waiter was really efficient and nice and kept our drinks filled. Like I said, the place was meticulously clean and I always like seeing an open kitchen. I didn't have an alcoholic drink, but my friend had a margarita which he really liked and the bar seemed really well stocked.
author: Jason W.

description:
Waited for our table at the bar and ordered the Mezcal Mule.  Fantastic.

Ordered the steak for dinner.  Decent, but so overpowered with garlic I could hardly taste the steak.
author: Robert B.

description:
4 stars for the service, 3.5 stars for the food, 5 stars for the tequila selection,  4 points for the decor, -1 star for the prices.  

Speaking as a former Texan, WoP isn't "Tex-Mex", but rather "Tex-SantaFe-Cal-Mex", or "Pan-Southwestern Fusion".    Keep that in mind and you'll enjoy the food more.

West of Pecos is in a double storefront, making at a huge space by mission standards, and they needed the space; on a Friday night it was really busy including a party of 20.  The have a terrific outdoor waiting area with benches and mini-fireplaces (yes, really).

The staff were friendly, attentive, and OMG young (I don't think I saw a single waitstaff member over 27).   I like the service uniform of Tshirts and/or western shirts and jeans.  

Tequila selection was very impressive; no Patron, no Cuervo-owned labels, and a couple of Tequilas I hadn't heard of before (amazing, considering the amount of tequila I've drunk).  Order it straight up!

Food was mostly quite good.  Pluses and minuses:

Good:
* Chips + Guacamole: avocados mashed to order.  Yay!
* Corn on the Cob: good, reminiscent of Mexican flea market corn
* Carnitas: excellent, great sauce, properly slow-cooked
* Corn tortillas: handmade that day in a pizza oven.  Yum
* Refried beans: surprisingly good, more of a sauce than anything.
* Decor: funky Tex-Mex Kitch. Plaster longhorn.   Axe handles for door handles.  I like it.

Not-so-good:
* "Caesar" salad: Southwested up with pepitas and stuff, more wierd than good.
* Chile Relleno: unmistakeable leathery texture of reheating destroyed any other flavors.   Flavorless, mushy batter.
* Spice: nothing on the menu was at all spicy.  Yes, you want and need mild options for folks like my sweetie.  However, you should also have OMG hot stuff on the menu for me ... or at least offer housemade hot sauce.
* Dessert: the 3 desserts on offer had zero to do with Mexico, Texas or New Mexico.  Where's the Flan?  Tres Leches Cake?  Sopapillas?  Or even ice cream?
* Noise: LOUD!!  Open kitchen, huge restaurant, 100% plaster and hard surfaces.

Then came the main drawback: a light meal for 2 people, including a couple drinks but no dessert, came to $90 with tip.  That puts them firmly in "fancy restaurant" prices.

Anyway, a good start on a new cuisine for SF and the Mission.  If they survive the next year (I think they will, based on traffic) I expect to come back and upgrade this review once they work off the rough edges.
author: Josh B.

description: Went here for paint nite on a Wednesday which was also during it's happy hour. Fast and friendly service, fresh guacamole; drinks are OK - the sangria had a unique cinnamon / nutmeg taste to it.
author: Natasha N.

description:
Not a fan of their latest menu. They just changed menus and they're trying to be more upscale and expensive (think tapas for $12+).  The chile relleno is now crap - gone is the frying, sauce, and Oaxaca cheese. Major disappointment. 

Of course the margarita and chips con queso were good. 

I'll be back for appitizerd at the bar, but the restaurant is out for now.
author: Dan E.

description:
West of Pecos gets points for the great ambiance and decor, but only mediocre marks for the food. 

We had the corn on the cob, cornbread, lobster salad, and three cheese poblano. Everything was decent but pretty bland, and definitely not great value given the prices. Please, West of Pecos, spice it up a bit!
author: C M.

description:
New chef + updated menu + awesome atmosphere = perfection  

The food was outstanding and I would describe it as more South Western than tex-mex. The decor and atmosphere are warm and inviting, it is a beautiful space. 

We ordered many different things and shared - my preferred method of trying as many items as possible. Order anything and everything with pea tendrils!
author: Kjerstin S.

description: Highly recommend West of Pecos not only for their food (very good) and their margaritas (very, very good) but also for their service.  I was planning a group dinner and West of Pecos were very accommodating.  A lot of SF restaurants can't or don't like to take groups of 10+ but the West of Pecos staff were welcoming.  Our server - I think his name is Ignacio - was great... attentive, friendly and patient when we hadn't looked at the menu and needed more time. Finding a good place for groups is tough but West of Pecos is a great choice (not far from BART either).
author: C S.

description: Dined here last night and have to up them to 5 stars for adding salsa. That was my only beef with them, and not only did they rectify their wrong, but they make an incredible, smoky, chunky, fresh salsa with heirloom tomatoes. Holy shit, it's good.
author: Serena Q.

description:
So I have been here on many occasions before and have not had problems, but this last time I went in was far from what I was expecting.

Our server first off was very depressing.  I could barely hear what she was saying & she had no life in her whatsoever.  We ordered chips & guac, which was good however our server disappeared after we received the order for at least 15-20 minutes.  We had not even ordered our food yet & she was nowhere to be found!  Then, she finally came back around to us and took our order, all of which I needed to make sure had NO CHEESE in them.  She immediately verified that they did not, but then told us the flatbread could not be made without cheese-Disappointment #1.  Then 10 minutes later she comes back and tells me they JUST started putting cheese in the Flautas, so she asked if we still wanted them.  Well, considering I told you I cannot have ANY dairy/cheese, the answer would be No.  Then our order came.  The tuna tacos had absolutely no flavor at all.  The sliders were delicious, however they were so soggy it seemed that they had been sitting around for way too long after being made.  The Peppers which I was so excited for were so bitter I could not even palate them & when I told our waitress about this she said "oh yeah, sometimes they get that way" (which is weird because I ordered 2 orders of these at Beso last week and NOT ONE was bitter!)  The brussel sprouts we ordered were good, but not great, although they were my second favorite thing we ordered.

We could have eaten more, but were not very excited about the experience so decided to end the meal there and call it a night.  I truly hope this was a one-time occurrence for West of Pecos because I would like to be back!  It will take a lot of convincing for my friend I ate here with to be back, as this was his first and only experience with this restaurant.
author: Gary H.

description: Great food, really nice service. Had the chips and guac. Really yummy, fresh flavor, followed by fish tacos. They are fried- I should have read the menu ( as I don't eat fried food) so I took the battered part off. It was still super delicious and the slaw under has a great lime flavor. Great overall!
author: Dasha W.

description:
We went there for brunch one Sunday.

Service was extremely slow and food was very mediocre. This in addition to the lacking ambience makes it difficult to recommend them although this might just be a one off experience.
author: Nosherwan M.

description:
I want this place to be amazing but some uneven service and the pricing make me a little hesitant. 

I've been twice and the first time I went, I was extremely happy. We got a salad, green chile mac n cheese and the lavender duck breast to go along with a few margaritas and I was ready to rave about the place. The salad rocked, the mac n cheese was dangerously good and the duck was perfectly cooked. 

I went back two nights ago and we had an heirloom tomato salad, mac n cheese and the pollo al carbon. The salad was light and fresh but the mac n cheese wasn't as good. It was too mushy and needed to be cooked a bit longer. The chicken looked mouth-watering but was more ok than awesome. 

There's a lot of thought put into the food here, or at least there was in the menu and I really appreciate that. The New Mexican food has its own style and I think this place could become special. 

Unfortunately, I'm not sure the execution is there every night yet and for the prices they're charging, it has to be. On the plus side, you and a date could easily split one of the main plates and a few appetizers and be satisfied because the portion sizes are really generous. 

Good stuff but could be better. A bit pricier than maybe it should be.
author: Marin P.

description:
S E R V I C E
Super friendly, greeted at the door with a warm welcome by the man behind Woodhouse Fish Co. Tyler- always makes you feel right at home.  Attentive and professional service, the entire staff waited on us.  Pixie, my friend is a regular, and my first.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Walking into the Wild Wild West from the streets of the Mission, a cozy feel inside, not too loud that you can still hear each other talk: country wooden furnishings, and a painted bull skull in the bar area, fun and hip!

We were a group of six, West of Pecos is good for large groups. 

ORDERED
Lamb albondigas (meatball style) was with chorizo, spicy tomato and green chile broth and corn
Dried Lime & Pumpkin Seed Caesar romaine hearts, roasted tomato, caramelized white onion caesar dressing
Flat Iron Steak red chile & cheese enchiladas, chipotle-marinated sweet onions
Crispy Padron Peppers toasted almonds, queso fresco
and don't forget to try the cocktail Paloma!
Go now!
author: Susan S.

description: Great drinks and the mac & cheese was amazing.  Can't wait to come back.
author: Angela D.

description: Great new hot spot. Might wait but the food is off the chain!
author: James M.

description:
Food: We ordered the artichoke, chips and guac, and the corn on the cob all to share. At $18, I kind of expected a little more than one artichoke with those tiny freezer aisle shrimp on top. The chips and guac were fine, not overly salty as other reviewers have mentioned. The corn on the cob, was a "no show." By the time we finished everything else we were ready to leave. Overall impression of the food was "fine, but nothing to write home about." 

Service: Waitress was cheerful and fairly attentive. Our food came out way before our drinks. As mentioned, the corn on the cob never showed but our waitress had no problem taking it off our check. 

Clientele: Marina with a dash of Bridge and Tunnel. Douche canoe.

Atmosphere: This place is reminiscent of Chiles. It felt like a Disneyland version of the Mission, for white people too afraid to step foot in an authentic Mexican restaurant. This was the major turn off for both of us. 

I'd equate West of Pecos to eating at an Olive Garden in Italy, or a Panda Express in China. How embarrassing.
author: H.S. G.

description: I really like the atmosphere and service and the food was above average as well. I had the Fried Chicken and the Coffee rubbed brisket sandwich both of which were awesome!!! didn't have desert so not sure about that but their drinks were good as well...
author: Arash H.

description:
I was *sort of* impressed - the staff was friendly and everyone seemed to be competent and happy to help each other out. But knowing that it is owned by the Woodhouse folks meant that I was just a tad disappointed, because I wanted to like it that much...

We split small plates, left full and was surprised by the price (under $50 for the two of us):
- Cornbread (best dish by far)
- Chicken skewers (I loved how this was crispy outside moist inside, but it was too much rosemary for me)
- Mac and cheese (nice chili falvor but needed a touch of salt)
- Cowboy beans (tastey but the serving size was too big when compared to our other dished)
- Our drinks (once they came, took about half the mean and asking twice) were good - how margarita yum!

By far the worst thing about this place is the "kitsch" factor - all the wait staff had bandannas around their necks and many had cowboy boots - they can totally tone it down, the food, decor, and name scream "New Mexico", the outfits dont need to. 

Last: A few people said this, and yes it was kind of loud, but mostly because the booze is flowing, so I don't mind that at all :)
author: Kate M.

description: Great Puffy Tacos, Awesome Atmosphere, and even better people!
author: Edward L.

description:
Very disappointing experience. This place really needs to be in the Marina, not the Mission. What a pretentious place and an embarrassment for the neighborhood. The place  was packed when we arrived . It was a Friday night around nine so, we expected to have to wait for a table - not a big deal. We figured we would wait in the bar. Since it was my turn for the next round I went to the bar to order my drinks. I found a spot to wait to order my drinks and I waited, and waited, and waited, and waited, and waited ..... There were two bartenders behind the bar. Not one looked up to say "hey, be right with you". As I was standing there for over twenty minutes , my two friends managed to order our drinks from a waiter . As I continued to stand at the bar a customer sitting at the bar said to me "been waiting for while , huh". I said "I guess I don't have blonde hair and big tits" now that got  the asshole bartenders attention. He looked up and said "take it somewhere else". Mean while the guy that took our drinks forgot and walked by us at least five times and ignored us. We were like "what the hell".  We finally flagged him down asked if he had forgotten our order. He just said "I'm busy" so why take our order then. I spoke to the manager , clearly inexperienced , and had no idea how to handle it. Sorry doesn't help - fix the service problem. That's what you do . 

Will never go there again and will make sure my friends in the foodie blog world write about what an embarrassment to the SF food culture West of Pecos is.
author: Rob M.

description:
Went here to catch up with an old friend from Texas.  We weren't expecting much from Tex-Mex in San Fran and well... the food is around a 2 star compared to what we are use to.  

With that said, the house margarita was excellent and the staff was friendly.  Taylor from the Amazing Race spent a good five minutes chatting with us so that was really nice of him.

We had the following:
Green Chili Mac and Cheese - 3 star
Corn Bread - 3 star
Arugula Goat Salda - 2 star.  The dress was bad. Good thing we had it on the side.
Texas Ribs - 2 star.  The meat was decently tender but the sauce was too sweet.

Margaritas... 4 star!  Get one or three of these!
author: Tim Z.

description: If you're looking for a Tex-Mex equivalent of The Cheesecake Factory (think slightly better than Chili's) then you're in for a treat. If not, then I would look elsewhere.
author: Amin S.

description: Great food, good service, interesting decorations. We had the cornbread, chicken mole, and churros. Churros were out of this world. They are a must have.
author: Julia M.

description: The hipster bartenders at this place suck. They totally ignored our order for a pitcher for 30 minutes. When we told our waitress- she reordered it and then nothing. Came out. She reordered it 5 minutes later and they finally got to us - 45 minutes after we entered. There are much better places to go within the block then this lousy bar.
author: Nilay P.

description: Yum yum yum yum yum. Best queso I've ever had. Puffy carnitas tacos, amazing nachos, maple brussels. Great service. A poppin spot!
author: A. S.

description: Good food, very fresh, well cooked and good attention to detail. It's expensive, but nothing unreasonable, the food is worth the price. The staff is very friendly and down to earth. The environment is clean and well designed. Good stuff. Will come back.
author: Christopher S.

description: Great patient service. I had the harvest salad and the crudo tacos. Ahhhmazing. Their mixed drinks look out of this world! We totally panicked and chose this place because it was near our air bnb rental. Sooo happy with the decision.
author: Dorie Y.

description: Queso and chips make for a great appetiser. The lobster enchiladas are full of flavor, but not enough to share around the table. The Great Pork Trio has 3 cuts of pork with an amazing garbanzo sauce. Go for it. Also, if you are fan of mojitos or caipirinhas - order the "Faith Healer" as the cocktail of choice - it's refreshing and smooth.
author: Brandon L.

description: The steak and au gratin potatoes was amazing as was the house margarita.
author: Frank A.

description: We walked in on a whim on sunday morning. And we made the right decision. We ordered from the brunch menu. The croissant french toast, american breakfast, fried chicken and churros and eggs benedict were all divine! fresh, well cooked, not greasy, tasty and authentic. Will go back for sure. Service can be perked up a bit but food is 5 stars!
author: Sarah M.

description: Dissapointing......you should not have to ask for chips and salsa!  Their mango beet avacado salad was too tart.  The tostadas were tasty but again, tart.  Lobster enchiladas were tasty, had a kick to them.  Lobster was on the chewy side.  Did not get to try their drinks. Small portions - seems overpriced for what it is.
author: Ketan D.

description: Boot scoot 'n' good times at West of Pecos! I love this restaurant so much. The cocktails always have me smiling. My favorite is the Devils tooth. It's bourbon and tangerine and sooooooo delicious. The food is fantastic. I love the fish tacos and the chili relleno. The thing I really love love love about this place is the atmosphere and the people who work here. Everyone is just so cool and they make you feel welcomed and it's good vibes all around! I highly suggest this restaurant to anyone who loves good food with fun friends. Check it out!
author: Camille B.

description: Kelsey did an amazing job! She was also such a pleasure! I will definitely come back soon!
author: Charles H.

description:
West of Pecos is a stand out in the Mission!   The food is delicious and the service is outstanding.   

We had a large party of females and our server managed that extremely fine balance between patience and attentiveness.

Definitely coming back to WOP.

And bonus points ... I accidentally left my new jacket and when I called the next day that had it waiting for me.
author: kathy l.

description: we had a reservation on a friday night, and everything was pretty tasty and it was a fun atmosphere! we shared one of those punch bowls, and i had the lobster enchiladas. it was in a convenient location (to BART and surrounding bars) and we had great service all around, including a free round of tequila :)
author: Antoinnae C.

description:
If I had to sum up this restaurant in one word, it would be flavorful. The pecos margarita is probably the best and prettiest margarita I've ever had. Sweet, a little spicy and a little smoky. Really enjoyed the chips and queso appetizer and the chile relleno entree as well. 

West of pecos feels like the grown up version of that place next door that always has a line. I'll be back very soon!
author: Margarita B.

description:
Deeee-licious!
Just go and enjoy....
Oh and co owner Tyler MacNiven was hands on quirky and delightful you could tell he loves his restaurant.
All 6 of us loved the food and the whole experience.
author: Katy Z.

description: Ambiance was cozy, great loc, and no wait. But the pork trio I ordered was possibly the worst pork dish I've had in a restaurant setting--flavorless, dry and flavorless. Hopefully it was just a one-off!
author: Edmond A.

description: Decent people.  Clean. Friendly but non existing service.  The vibe was nice. One nice sized TV placed very oddly, you'd have to be sitting in one of 10 seats to have a clear view. Fun spot if just lazy day strolling. Food looked & smelled good. We only had drinks and guacamole with chips and enjoyed tgem.
author: Trish T.

description:
The avocado and peas tendrils appetizer, topped off with the woodhouse grilled artichoke.  AMAZING.

My partner had Margaret's porkchop, tasty, flavorful and tender.
author: Mark S.

description: I love this place. My group of 4 split 4 non-main dishes and it was the perfect amount to satisfy us. The hostess was excellent and provided us with guacamole and chips because of a small mishap that happened, so 5 stars especially for the service as well. Will come back to try other dishes!
author: Jamie P.

description: Simply delicious food and desserts, like an upscale Mexican restaurant. Cool atmosphere, friendly staff, and again, fantastic food. If you get the chance to meet the owner, Tyler, I recommend it. The guy's a character and everyone seems to know him.
author: Julian H.

description:
I'll start with sauce, hot sauce. They have an amazing, house made hot sauce. It isn't overly spicy and has a great flavor, the kicker, it's burnt orange in color. I've never had a burnt orange hot sauce but I like this one. This place from top to bottom is just great. They have a wide variety of seating options: two outdoor tables with little fires by each, private dining room seating and a good sized bar with huge windows that look on the street. We were lucky enough to get one of the tables outside, the little fire kept us at just the right temperature and increased the ambiance by volumes. 
The specialty cocktail list is really nice. They have a selection of 4 hand crafted margaritas as well as 5 other speciality cocktails. Combined my group had almost one of each and every single person was more than happy with each drink. Our server was nice enough to recommend different drinks for us and each time she picked just right. The service was friendly and efficient!
We had the queso and guac as starters and each was devoured in no time. I had the fish tacos and was pleasantly surprised, this is when the hot sauce really won me over. We also tried the green chile cheese burger and the artichokes, everyone was very content. The portions are good sized, I recommend sharing if you aren't super hungry. 
I really recommend this place for a Tex-Mex dinner. There's a great variety that exists here that allows the diner to set the mood of their experience. I rarely see this type of flexibility in one location. I recommend it for parties under 10 or for casual dates. If you're waiting for a table one of the bartenders will happily make you a drink while you wait.
The only con for me was in the men's bathroom their was a rattle snake skin that had an alligator head sewn on it. In retrospect I barely remember it.
I really recommend the queso and the Puebla Old Fashioned, but more then likely you will be happy with whatever you consume at this treat of a spot.
author: Silas F.

description:
Stumbled upon this place yesterday while walking around the Mission district with my boyfriend on a random day in the city.  I ordered the fish tacos, and he ordered the roasted artichoke, stuffed with crab and shrimp.
The artichoke was good, nicely cooked and flavorful...the crab was tasty.  The shrimp could have used a little work, as there were pieces of the tails on some of the shrimp still.  Other than that, the artichoke was good.  My fish tacos were delicious!  The fish was good, although I may have liked a breaded and baked fish instead of deep fried.  The cabbage on the tacos was pickled and added a nice flavor, as did the chipotle sauce.  I did have one suggestion for the tacos would be to use something other than lime wedges to hold up the two end tacos.  There were three tacos on the plate, and the two at the end were held in place by lime wedges.  When I got to the last taco on the end, as I picked it up the tortilla fell apart because it had become soaked in lime juice.  So, it made for a sloppy last taco, but it was still delicious nonetheless.  Food was great, service was prompt and friendly.  I would recommend this place to friends and family.
author: Sara W.

description:
PLEASE NOTE: this review is based only on their Margarita....

One of the few American traits that makes me feel truly patriotic, is the free pour cocktail. We invented the cocktail. When one travels abroad to say Europe or Canada, one realizes that bars must pour very weak 50 ML measured pours, resulting in shitty weak drinks. Perhaps this is why the English stick to beer. At any rate, West of Pecos subscribes to the penny pinching measured pour method with their Margaritas resulting in you guessed it; a shitty, weak Margarita. I'll cut to the chase... We spent 68 fucking dollars on 2 pitchers of the stuff. When we politely told the very courteous waitress that the Margarita was weak, we were told that we had to purchase an extra shot for 7 more dollars.. This resulted in over 70$ worth of Margarita. This is totally unacceptable. One door down at Puerto Allegre, one never complains of a weak Margarita. Penny pinching owners of West of Picos, please tell your bar staff to throw away their jiggers, and let them do their jobs and free pour.. Either that, or get a bigger jigger!
author: Tim E.

description: I really enjoyed my dinner here. I have to say the $38 pitcher of margaritas was a bit expensive but nonetheless delicious. The bacon wrapped shrimp was obviously tasty and so was the three pork special.
author: Irina M.

description: We didn't have much on this trip, stopped in for some margaritas, chips & guacamole. The margaritas we're okay, not my fav but tasty enough. The chips & guac were excellent!
author: Mindy N.

description:
This place gets a one star for the friendliness of the manager.

I apologize that this review is late, as I went there in the summer.
My boyfriend and I went in on a Saturday night around 8 and was told that the wait was about 45 minutes. Ok, not a problem as it was busy and that's a normal wait. The hostess took my bf's cell # and we were told that he would receive a text when our table was ready. We went across the street to get drinks.....an hour and a half later, we still had not received a text.
A little tipsy and extremely hungry we went back in to find out why we never received a text. The restaurant was now half as full. The manager apologized that we never received our text and sat us immediately. He even sent over complimentary guacamole and chips.
I'm not a guacamole person, so I asked if we could get salsa. I was told they don't have salsa. WHAT?! This is a TexMex restaurant, right? I have family in Texas and have eaten at various restaurants in the South West and never have I come across a place that did not serve salsa. No bueno!
So finally we order and our food arrives. My boyfriend ordered a burger, done medium well and I ordered the ribs. 
My ribs were dry but the sauce was good, so I ate it. The portions are not that great for the price and definitely would not pass in Texas.
My boyfriend's burger on the other hand was basically raw, to the point that it crumbled when he bit into it. He was so grossed out by it, that he lost his appetite and did not want another in exchange.
Once again the staff was extremely nice and the manager took it off the order. 
Finally we get our bill and are ready to blow that popsicle stand. Except that our bill came out to $58 and some change! 
Mind you, the bill should have listed 1 entree and 2 bottles of beer. This was the last straw! We took it back over to the manager and he was super apologetic, removed the excess drinks that showed up and handed us a card for $25 to apply to our next visit.

The card is still in my wallet. So many things failed during that visit, that I have not gone back. Maybe I'll just use it for drinks, as I would be too embarrassed to take anyone else.

Hopefully they have stepped up their game by now.
author: Anica S.

description: I love this place. Great atmosphere. Friendly staff. Amazing food. We went on a Saturday night. Crowded and a line, but not a crazy long line. We made a reservation online about an hour before so we got right in. I got a classic margarita. It was okay. Tasted like it had salt in the cup as well at on the rim, so it was a little too salty. We went crazy with the appetizers and skipped the mains. We ordered the Mac & cheese (highly recommend! Creamy with a crunchy breading and jalapeños sprinkled on top), the pork and flatbread with fried egg (star of the meal. You can't come here without ordering this!), mango/avocado salad (very good; delicious avocado spread), bacon wrapped shrimp on a skewer (this was good, large shrimp and crispy bacon), cornbread skillet (soooo good. One of the best cornbreads I've had and came with a maple syrup), and the artichoke with crab (this is the one thing that I would probably skip next time. The crab was delicious, but the artichoke was too buttery and greasy). If you can, see if you can sit outside. Looked like only two small areas out front, but they have the cutest little wood stoves to keep you warm at night. Much quieter outside too. If you sit inside on a busy night, be warned that it get really loud so not great for a first date or intimate conversation.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
We went the first week WoP opened so they may have been working through some kinks in the menu. Granted, i'm still only giving it 3 stars. food was hipster-tex mex, meaning it's not real tex-mex.  duck tacos were pretty good, margarita was so-so. guac was okay. thought the food in general lacked a lot of flavor, asked for hot sauce to douse our food for more flavor...

think i'd give it another chance maybe after they've been open for a few more months...
author: Sandy K.

description: The best ribs in San Francisco.  No other restaurant has ribs such as the ones at West of Pecos, the meat is tender, and tasty and the sauce is like no other.
author: James D.

description:
came here for happy hour tonight, and it was just about perfect.  the $5 frozen margaritas were awesome...I was afraid they'd be weak and fake-tasting, but they were strong and delicious.  also had the chips and guacamole.  it was a little underseasoned but really quite good.  also, the NBA playoffs were on, which is always a plus in my book.

we had no problem grabbing a table in the bar area around 5:30, but when we left at 7 the place was packed!  take note.

bottom line: fantastic happy hour with great service.  it may just be the perfect way to unwind after a long day.  give it a shot.
author: Amanda L.

description:
West of Pecos would not survive in the Mission without their amazing P.R. team whoever they may be. We found them via 7by7 mag and all I can say is if I wanted to eat at a glorified Chevys this would be the place. We went on a Friday and it was packed. If you want a Mission experience and eat in a hip Mission restaurant with amazing foods cooked by studied chefs this IS NOT the place. 

Clientele: Bridge and Tunnel maxed times 10

Food: Pricey for what it is. Both salads we ordered had thick ranchy dressing. Not sophisticated but heavy and tasted fast foody.
Chili was long strings of meat with a soupy base with kind of a pungent taste
Chili Relleno tasted like Chevys and lacked anything out of the ordinary.
Guac and chips. Chips were delicious. Guac had enormous chunks of avocado. Need to be thinned out and need a spoon to dish out
Mac and Cheese sounded amazing but tasted ordinary with little flavor
My husband ordered the steak which was tasty but again lacked sophistication. 
The food here is greasy and sloppy. Sorry to slam this place but it belongs near the ballpark or Union Square, not The Mission
Drinks: The beers were super good and cold. The margaritas had bazaar enormous ice cubes which was fun but the drinks were not very cold! They also lacked the mixology sophistication for the price. 
Service: Our server rocked. That gets a star
The Decor: Cheesy kind of corporate feel trying to be hip and warm with a lot of wooded furniture.
author: Annie A.

description: The Pecos provides an very nice ambiance of Southwestern goodness. The signature drinks are superb and the selection on the menu does not disappoint. It's good to make a reservation if you can~ Close to everything else in the Mission~
author: Shawn S.

description:
This ended up being the last place of the night last Saturday, and MAN...was it good. Expensive, mind you - they don't have rail drinks because they don't have "rail" alcohol. Everything is good, so their cheapest drinks are still like $9. Just an FYI on that...
but that said, I got the top drink on their menu and I'm really trying to remember the name of it right now and I'm having a really hard time - it had two words...anyway, it had bourbon, ginger and vanilla in it and it was SO GOOD. My husband got an order of chips and guacamole, and it was like the best guacamole I've ever had, and I'm only just now learning to even like guacamole. (yeah yeah, I know, please keep your hissing and booing to yourself, I'm making an effort) Seriously though - it was SO GOOD. Again.
We got there around midnight and it was last call though, so they're not open as late as other bars, I think because they're mostly a restaurant. They had a cool table for us to sit at outside though, which fit six of us.
I'd like to go back and get some more of that guacamole. Oh man.
author: Erin A.

description:
cute ambiance, yummy queso dip, delicious sourdough burger, blistering peppers were tasty but kale tostada salad was just okay.  

banana cream pie was yummy.
author: Wen B.

description: Great experience! No wait, food prepared quickly and delicious. My roommate and I had the flat iron steak and it was great! Perfect proportion! And the waitress was gorgeous ;)
author: Krzysztof S.

description: Yay for no wait (Sunday pride around 8pm) and delicious food. I got the kale tostada salad, which was more tostada (3 mini ones, in fact!) than kale, but suuuper tasty.
author: Richa A.

description: This is not Tex-Mex. There is anything Mex on the menu. The mains were overpriced and poor quality. The queso was great and the chili had a lot of flavor. We ordered margarita pitchers and they were very small for $36 which the price was not listed on the menu. The pitcher didn't even fill four short glasses. Service was real bad. Our waitress stopped by twice - once to take our order and second to drop off the bill. I will probably go back but not to the restaurant. I'll just do the apps in the bar.
author: Kelly C.

description: Great place to get drunk and not have to stand in one crowded spot in the mission.
author: Daniel F.

description: Love to pop in here during Happy Hour. They have awesome margaritas that they sell by the pitcher. The only place in this city that has queso (Texas style). It's great for groups and large enough for parties, and their service is spot on. Though I have not eaten dinner here I don't doubt that their food is less than great!
author: Danielle L.

description: Loved the food, drinks and ambiance in the bar. Service was excellent, too! I'll be back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Theresa L.

description: San Fran texmexes it up. Get cornbread and steak. Excellent. Not as frisco as you'd think, which is what I liked about it as well. Not the healthiest food, but dealable. Not sure if there are any texmexes like this around, so get it and go.
author: Jono S.

description: This place is so overpriced super incredibly. The food is no better than going to a taqueria and getting some carne asada. It's not bad bad food but it's very overpriced. The drinks taste decently, but not worth it. I
author: Jordi R.

description: Killer cocktails and chips con queso make this place a great stop even if you do not plan to eat dinner.  We had the flautas and crab stuffed artichokes which were also pretty good but didn't try the main courses.
author: James W.

description: Favorite restaurant in the mission, might be my favorite in all of SF. I've been here over a dozen times and never disappointed. Amazing food, service is always stellar. The fish tacos and breakfast tacos are delicious!
author: Kristin K.

description:
I'd normally never eat "tex mex", not sure why, just was never impressed with the cuisine before. Went here because it was the only place available for a party of 4 on a Saturday night. I was impressed! 

Here are the fantastic things that we ordered:
The ribs. I never order ribs in restaurants (unless its a franchise restaurant), cause they'll  just give you 2 tiny skinny little ribbies. But not here! Good portion!

Woodhouse grilled artichoke. The best! You get the whole artichoke... AND it's filled with crab and shrimp. Amazing.

The ambiance was casual, yet somewhat classy. The kinda place you can even bring your conservative relatives to. The service was pretty good too. I'd be back.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description:
I've been to west of pecos several times and was always happy with everything.
 Steak is great! Fish tacos are also delicious.
I also recommend the Mac and cheese from the small plate menu.
author: Nazanin S.

description: Had late dinner here last night with a friend and we ordered the Green Chile Mac & Cheese, Brown Sugar Buttermilk Fried Chicken, and Chips & Guac. The Mac & Cheese was okay but I the fried chicken, really really good! I can't wait to go back and try other items on their menu. I think is one now on my list of favorite restaurants in The City!
author: Barbra C.

description: Fresh food.  Great drinks.  The place can have somewhat of a Marina vibe sometimes, but the bartenders and servers are always friendly.  I've been several times for dinner, and a couple times just for drinks.  It's a nice spin on the Mexican food thing and they've got decent options for your vegetarian and gluten averse friends.
author: Laura S.

description: They don't take brunch reservations so we decided to wing it. By the time the three of us were ready, it was almost 230pm on Cinco de Mayo sunday. I wasn't optimistic, but they said they would fit us in with just a 20 minute wait.. That's better than i was expecting! But then after only about five minutes, they had a table for us, so, great! Service was very good the whole time. I also liked the tall backed chairs and  loved the southwestern decor. We shared the skilled cornbread to start. It had chile butter and you pour molasses over the top, which is the first time i'd done that. We all liked it, but not as much as I've seen people raving about. It was good, but not stand-out. I had the stuffed poblano chile (I usually get sweets for brunch but theirs didn't look too interesting). It was good, with a subtle smoky taste, but not too overpowering. I didn't realize I was very hungry, but this did not fill me up. My friends both got the dungeoness crab frittata. It looked small, but they both said it was more filling than it looked. I tried a couple bites since I was still hungry. The crab part was very good, the frittata part was fine, we all agreed, nothing special. We ordered drinks, which didn't come out til after the food was served. They had some interesting tasty drinks on the menu. My friend got the mezcal mary, which was really pretty. It wasn't super thick and foody like some bloody marys. I tried a sip and it was way too smoky for me, but I don''t generally like bloody marys. He does, and he enjoyed it. My other friend and I got another drink i don't remember the name of, and is not on their menu on their website right now, but it had egg white and was very fruity and pillowy, and slightly soda-y. It was pretty thirst quenching and not overpowering at all. I wouldn't even realize i was drinking alcohol vs a regular drink, so we both enjoyed it. My friend said that was his favorite part of the meal. I think mine would be my chilie, if there had been more to it. Overall, a nice dining experience, we all agreed that while we liked it well enough, it was nothing special and with all the great brunch places around, we'll not likely be back. Maybe I'd try lunch or dinner though, or just go for drinks.
author: Merredith L.

description: AWESOME!! Brussel sprouts and and corn are perfect appys and the chop is FANTASTIC! Went there for brunch as well and LOVED it.  They have excellent GF options and veg options.  I will go here many many more times.
author: Min M.

description:
Made a reservation for 10 people and we all had an absolute blast.  

Excellent food.  Unique and tasteful ambience.  Good drinks.  Friendly staff.

Highlights: ribs, cornbread with molasses, lavender ice cream.  Recommended!!
author: Peter F.

description: This place is delicious and the portions are enormous. The brisket sandwich + the queso + cocktails = heaven on Earth!
author: Nisha G.

description: Revisited. Cocktail list is *much*better, and food came out at appropriate times. Great to see they've worked out the kinks they had early on.
author: David C.

description: Food was five stars. Minus one star for the bussing. They took my husbands plate as he had his food in his hands still eating. That's just one of my pet peeves. I will definitely go back, we enjoyed our server and the food and drinks.
author: max k.

description:
One of the best restaurants in the city.. hands down.  The food is phenomenal w/ great quality cuts, the value/ price is good for what you get and the service is also topnotch.   Great for a group of folks that loves eating meat.  Ordered lots but felt great after wards!

Key we enjoyed:
- Flank steak -- better cut of meat than expected, perfectly cooked med-rare, and the sauce + rings were a great add-on
- Corn on the Cobb... we almost skipped it.. but really glad we didn't
- Green Chile burger ---  serious
- Mezcal mulezzzz --  not joking. unreal
- Duck tacos --  pretty good, no regrets, but not out of the world
author: Jared N.

description: Love this place! I had the best pork chop of my life here, and my girl lived her fish tacos. The guacamole and chips were money and the prices were really fair. Can't wait to go back!!
author: Curtis A.

description: Took my sister here for her 21st birthday brunch. Delicious food, reasonable prices, pitchers of cocktails. What more could you ask for!?
author: Mani K.

description: Strolled in on a lazy Saturday around noon for a solo brunch at the bar. Uncharacteristically calm for a weekend brunch, the bartender was patient with my silly subjective questions about items on the menu. I ordered the stuffed poblano chili, normally I'm not too excited about vegetarian items, but it was perfectly sized, topped with bits of cojita cheese and a rich drizzle of cream to complement the smokey roasted pepper.  I was reluctant to take the bartenders suggestion of a bourbon drink as a "refreshing" cocktail, but he was right. Bourbon, tangerine, vanilla, ginger combined to become a savory, delicious finish to a perfectly prepared experience.
author: Timothy D.

description: Yet another trendy place on Valencia that serves great food. I reckon you should get your mitts on the cornbread skillet and the ribs.  You'll lick your fingers clean.
author: Nick F.

description:
Went there for dinner with two friends for the second time and once again they messed up our order.  The server brought us an appetizer we didn't even order and we order two pork chop, but she only brought one order of the pork chop so I had to wait another 20 mins for my entree. When it finally came out, the pork chop was raw in the middle and when I brought showed the server the raw pork chop she asked "did you order it medium rare?" I don't know about anyone, but who the hell orders their pork medium rare?!

The server looked confused that I didn't wanted to eat my raw pork chop and asked if I wanted something else, but I said no thanks since I lost my appetite.  Luckily I didn't get sick.
author: Brian H.

description: Great atmosphere and the food keeps bringing me back..  I always get the Faith Healer.  My other favorites are the lobster enchiladas, pretty much all the tacos and the deep fried Brussels sprouts (I don't typically like Brussels sprouts but then again I do typically like fried things).
author: Dinesh P.

description: Everything we all ordered was excellent,  too bad we filled up on the great appetizers and drinks, to properly enjoy our meals.  Will come back again.  Cool atmosphere,  the two tables out in the entry, look like fun.
author: Winny S.

description: Sticking to my original review even after the supposed business upgrade.  It's just not happening, sorry guys.  The brussel sprouts were like I make at home, the salmon was fine, but not spectacular, the corn had too much sweetness poured on it, the mac n cheese was ok.  No chance this is going to compete with other hot spots in this city...Tacoliscious and it's neighbor Mosto, or my local fave Papito, unknown hit and miss gem Reaction...all of these are just delivering something I could never do at home.  Sorry kids.
author: A A.

description: A little bit of Texas in San Fran... absolutely love this place. They always seem to have new items on the menu, this place doesn't get old. Love their ribs!
author: Sarah K.

description: The best burger I have ever eaten! Plus the eclectic style matches the owners parents restaurant in Woodside!
author: Alex C.

description: This review is for brunch only - I very much enjoyed my brunch in this restaurant.  I wish they opened a little earlier for brunch on the weekends, like maybe 10 instead of 11 - I would come here more often.  They have lots of vegetarian and pescatarian options on the brunch menu, although it doesn't seem to be the same for dinner so I probably won't stray from brunch here.  I had the stuffed poblano; a fire roasted pepper stuffed with eggs and some cheese served with a crema and fire roasted beans.  This was so delicious and the textures were perfect together.  I'd definitely order it again.  I loved the variety of cocktails that they offer with brunch.  They have savory and spicy cocktails too, beyond bloody mary's, which I prefer to sweet drinks.  I had the Flama Blanca; a white tequila cocktail with jalapeno! Yum!
author: Jessica L.

description: Let me first start by saying that I really like this place. I come here at least twice a week for either happy hour or brunch. Unfortunately, my latest experience here could not be more disappointing.  Four of us showed up at 6 pm on a Friday evening.  We had been wanting to try one of their cactus bowls for some time and this was the perfect opportunity.  When we arrive we notice the main room in the restaurant was half full and the bar area was almost at capacity.  The tables inside the bar area were almost all filled except for one.  This table however has had a sign saying that you had to be seated by the hostess.  In my experience most bar tables are first come first serve.  I speak with the hostess and tell her that the four of us would like to sit there.  She proceeds to tell me that it is a full service table and that we would need to order food to sit there.  I respond asking well what if we are going to buy a $65 cactus bowl.  She said she would have to see what she could do.  So I go back to my friends in the bar and tell them what's going on.  Meanwhile a group of four people who were actually there ahead of us and wanting to do the same thing left.  We get the attention of a server working in the bar area and tell her we would like to sit there.  She says she is going to talk with the hostess and see what's going on.  When she comes back she tells us she can't seat us because it is policy on Friday and Saturday to have these seats for groups who are going to eat food.  First off, I get it.  It's not beneficial to their business to have a single person come into the bar, sit at a table and sip on a few drinks over the next few hours.  In this case though you gotta be kidding me.  You had one group just walk out, we are there saying we want to spend money, and your restaurant side is only half full.  Policy or not, if I'm running this place I make sure you are seated.  I seriously haven't been this disappointed since the Warriors lost games two and three to the Cavs in the finals.  The waitress then says we can sit at the bar.  The only problem with that is there are only two seats there.  Obviously ordering a large cactus bowl is not going to work.  There were a few more exchanges and when it became apparent that she was not going to budge we went on our way.  That is two groups of people they lost.  I wonder how many people came in after us and did the same thing?  I really want to keep going here because they have great drinks, happy hour, and brunch.  Sad to say I will be thinking twice next time.  When your "policies" turn away regular customers something needs to give.  In this case it looks like we will need to find somewhere more accommodating.
author: Brian B.

description: Absolutely delicious brunch! Great service too. We tried the carrot cake french toast (so yummy and moist and not too sweet), the kid's mac and cheese, the crab and avocado tostada (so fresh), and the brisket hash. Everything was yum! Definitely have to come back and eat here again.
author: J R.

description: Carnitas pies, mac n' cheese, and the pork chop were all delicious. A steel cup of Pecos punch was a nice accompaniment.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Pretty cool Tex-Mex spot.  $5 frozen margs for happy hour were surprisingly potent.  For dinner, the ribs and fried chicken were great.  Decent size portions, fun atmosphere plus friendly service is getting harder to come by in the city, so props to WoP
author: Toby C.

description: My sister and I went here to celebrate our birthdays on a Friday night and we made reservations because they get packed. The drinks were tasty and the food was very fresh and moist! Their guacamole and bacon wrapped shrimp is delicious and the fish tacos are so fresh. Would definitely recommend this place, but definitely make reservations!
author: Lana J.

description: The menu is somewhat limited and dishes hit or miss, but I love the buzzy atmosphere, relatively reasonably priced drinks in the gentrifying Mission, and the cozy fireplaces outside. Steer clean of the chili (which tastes like a bowl of BBQ sauce), but do try the yummy fried chicken. And if you can get there before 6:30pm M-Th, there's a happy hour menu with great deals -- $5 frozen margaritas and sangrias and $1.50 duck/chili/black bean tacos and other small bite fare.
author: Kate A.

description: Great ambiance!  However the food was average at best. We ordered halibut, fried green tomatoes, and the green chile Mac and cheese. Fried, greasy, and not too tasty. The drinks aren't bad- the pico punch is decent
author: Romita J.

description: I love this restaurant because it reminds me so much of home! Most of the Mexican food in San Francisco falls on one extreme of the spectrum: either very authentic or super "Californian" style (more fresh, less spicy, a bit lighter in fare). Tex-Mex is entirely different from both of those and it's what I grew up on. I'd describe it as zesty, cheesy goodness. Tons of queso and LOTS of pepper plus a little bit of BBQ. Anyway, I was digging' the western ambiance / branding and also very much into my steak being covered in a ton of cheese with a side of tequila cocktails.
author: Sabrina M.

description: Had a great Brunch here!  Delicious and well crafted menu, beautiful ambiance, and reasonably priced.  I will be dining here again!
author: Catherine S.

description:
I lived in New Mexico for seven years. The best thing about the southwest, other than the beautiful scenery, is the cooking. So WoP let us see what you have...

OK WoP you feel authentic southwest, with your large open space, wooden floors and thick tables. OK, so far so good: chili's from Hatch, prickly pears, and head chef from Santa Fe (you know, the other SF). Alright, I'll let my guard down... a little.  Food time.

A few of us tried the Lavender and Chipotle Duck Brest, Pork Carnitas and Lamb.  It was damn good, damn good I say.

One Mezcal and one tequila drink later, I feel like I'm back walking on, well... San Francisco Street.  For those of you that do not know, San Francisco St is a main drag in Santa Fe that runs you into the Plaza and crosses old Route 66.   

If you've ever been lucky enough to just pack your motorbike and really explore the southwest; from Ja Texas, to Jemez Springs NM, to Flagstaff AZ,  WoP really was able to bottle a little of that, yet bring that fun uniquely SF vib to it without having anything feel gimmicky, it feels like the watering holes I spent most of my twenties inhabiting.

Look forward to passing through again real soon.
author: scott r.

description:
wednesday night for bar snacks and drinks
cocktails were good - sat at the bar for food
Chili was really good, Gauc was ok - nothing special 
Disappointed that at 1030 they ask for last orders and start closing around us 

would go back as an option in the Mission but not first choice
author: T J.

description: Hand crushed tomato Bloody Mary was so refreshing! Followed it with a Southwestern breakfast late on Sunday morning; perfect eggs, warm crispy tortillas, fresh buttery avo and salsa. New favorite brunch spot for sure
author: B R.

description: Food here is amazing! We had a taste of quite a few dishes. The guacamole = really good, BBQ chicken = heaven (especially the corn cob that comes with it, Mac n cheese = average. The place was really busy but we got seated quickly. It's a lively bar/restaurant. I'd eat here again. Good service!
author: Kelly M.

description:
West of Pecos is awesome.  It has a really cool southwest meets old wild west type vibe.  The staff is very friendly.  There is plenty of seating area and also a huge bar area with lots of sit-yourself tables.  Great atmosphere for a friday night out or dinner/drinks during the week.  

The food is great.  The cornbread, roasted chicken, fried brussel sprouts, chile and flatbread are some of my favorites at this new Mission staple.  I had heard from a friend that they hired a new chef recently so i went to go check it out for myself.  All of my favorites were still on the menu plus a bunch of new things.  I found the food to be even better than in the past.

I'll be going back soon to try more of their new additions.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who is looking for a lively atmosphere where they can have great drinks and even better food.  

West of Pecos Rocks!
author: Judd H.

description: This place always looks crowded - we grabbed a seat at the bar. Standard tex mex fair and drinks were ok. You can do better in the mission.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Best brunch spot in the mission. 

In an homage to Marie Antoinnette - and I hope that I won't be treated similarly - let the peasants eat boogaloos. West of Pecos is where it's at. 

TO SUMMARIZE:
1. EXCELLENT Food
2. Great Ambiance
3. Great servers

Get some. 


Recommend the Pecos Pimms cup. West of Pecos and San Quentin are the only two places where you can drink out of this cup, specially designed to be hard to turn into a shiv. Google it.

Owner must be a badass. 

West of Pecos brunch.
author: A H.

description: The drinks are awesome. I had a prickly pear margarita & their duck tacos --- I have to say I could have just eaten 2 servings of the duck taco appetizers as my main meal --  they are the DELISH!
author: Shivani S.

description:
I ate here last night and my overall experience was awesome! 

The brothers who own the restaurant know what their doing!  

The decor is sexy, the  atmosphere is fun and hip , food was fantastic, and the drinks were good too.  

Extremely Clean and Cozy.  

Great place to meet with a group of friends for tacos, beers, and margaritas. 

Duck Tacos: yes.
Guacamole: yes.
Margarita: yes.
author: Alex A.

description:
My friend and I were walking down Valencia and saw the sign West of Pecos (pre opening) it shocked the living mexican out of both of us. Being two girls born and raised in west of Pecos, we were more than ready for some home cooking. 

Friday night dinner, the restaurant was busy but we were sat right away. I had a great view of the kitchen staff. The head chef looked less than pleased but they didn't seemed like they were in the weeds, just busy. 

Drinks: House Margarita, smallest ever and tasted like generic lime simple syrup. Not good. I miss the good old days of big goblet margaritas that were refreshing and got you hammered. There is no place in my margarita for whiskey ice. I had to add ice from my water glass to chill it. What is happening to the margarita? Please rethink this drink. Pecolata or something was so gross...the finish tasted like chloraspetic.
